title: Eoin O’Malley: Simplifying the Israel/Hamas war as ‘good guys vs bad guys’ dehumanises all
body: It's easier for humans to see the world simply as good versus evil. Photo: Getty

The ongoing human tragedy in Israel and Palestine is matched by political failures all round. It is not just political leaders. Conflicts often make ordinary people take full-throated positions that ignore the nuanced if often brutal roots of the conflict. Wars seem to force us to stake our position, to choose sides. Saying “both sides” isn’t an option.
But your side inevitably does bad things. Still it is your side — you picked it — so you had better be consistent and find a defence for those bad things. Often that defence is to deny reality.

title: Ireland fully supports International Criminal Court’s Gaza probe, Tánaiste says
body: An opposition party has called for Israel to be referred to the ICC
Micheal Martin said Ireland is a ‘consistent supporter’ of the International Criminal Court (Brian Lawless/PA)
Tánaiste Micheál Martin has said Ireland is a “consistent and strong supporter” of the International Criminal Court (ICC) in investigating the Israel-Hamas conflict.
It comes after Sinn Fein announced its intention to bring a motion to the Dáil seeking a referral of Israel to the ICC by Ireland.
The Tánaiste and Foreign Affairs Minister said the ICC is the “cornerstone of the system of international criminal justice”.
In a statement on Sunday, he said: “Ireland is a consistent and strong supporter of the court, and of its independence and impartiality.”
Mr Martin said the ICC has jurisdiction over “the situation in Palestine” and the prosecutor opened an investigation into Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem in March 2021.
The investigation covers all crimes within the jurisdiction of the court, including war crimes and crimes against humanity, alleged to have been committed since the date of referral in 2014.
“This gives the court jurisdiction over any crimes committed within Palestine, and/or by Palestinian nationals outside it, including in Israel.

“Importantly, the current prosecutor, Karim Khan, has made absolutely clear on a number of occasions over the last month that this investigation covers the current conflict, including all events on and from October 7 this year.
“He has confirmed that there is an active investigation ongoing in relation to the situation in Palestine.”

Mr Martin added: “Ireland will continue to fully support the ICC in its vitally important work in investigating all the situations before it, whether that be in Ukraine, Darfur, Palestine, Libya, the Democratic Republic of the Congo or elsewhere.
“All victims, everywhere, are equally deserving of justice and accountability.”

title: Nelofer Pazira-Fisk: Colonial ambitions groomed the Middle East for intolerance
body: Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu with masked IDF soldiers. Photo: Reuters

As the cannons were still thundering on the front lines — men falling like leaves on the fields of death and glory of the Great War, a war to end all wars — the French and British were conniving to divide the collapsing Ottoman empire between them.

title: Letters: Changing the Artane Band’s name is just gesture politics
body: The Artane Band performs regularly at Croke Park. Photo: Getty
Sir — I am a former member of the Artane Boys Band, having been a proud and enthusiastic member for seven years through the 1990s. These years were hugely formative for me.

During the life of the old St Joseph’s Industrial School (1870-1969), Artane in Dublin was a mainly rural area, and so the name of Artane became synonymous with the school. For some who are not familiar with the Artane of today, they still wrongly associate the name with the now-closed industrial school.

However, for many years, Artane has indeed been a fantastic and large community which takes great pride in its band, and is much bigger than the industrial school that was once located there. Neither it nor the Christian Brothers owns the name Artane. The Artane Band of today is an independent organisation and draws its identity from its proud ethos, musicianship, camaraderie and community.
The motion that was passed by Dublin City Council last Monday, calling upon the band to have its name and uniform removed, has greatly disappointed me and many others.

I have huge sympathy for the victims of abuse in St Joseph’s Industrial School in Artane, which closed its doors in 1969. However, I do not believe that a way of rectifying those crimes is to do away with the identity of the Artane Band and of its members.
The band today — and the Artane School of Music of which it is a part — has no relationship with the individuals of many decades ago who perpetrated such cruelty in St Joseph’s.
It is run to the highest professional standards by a dedicated staff and management, and their number one loyalty is to its many young and talented members.
Suggesting associations between an amazing group of young people today and some horrendous perpetrators of abuse from decades ago is deeply unfair, and damaging to these young people.

I strongly suggest that the council members reconsider this motion and instead work to ensure that the young people within its jurisdiction have the proper care and opportunities that previous generations were wrongly denied.

Sir — I participated in the Pro-Palestinian march in Cork on November 4 and can assure Eilis O’Hanlon I saw no evidence of antisemitism (‘In a world full of horrors, why is it only ever Israel that excites deep loathing?’, November 5).
The focus of attention was on calling for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza and an end to Israeli military and settler harassment of Palestinians in the occupied West Bank.

Eilis must know it is standard Israeli propaganda practice to claim that antisemitism is on the rise as soon as they engage in yet another campaign of murder by attacking homes, schools, churches, mosques, medical institutions and ambulances in Gaza, in a relentless aerial bombardment of an essentially defenceless people.
We must continue to repeat loudly that anti-Zionism is not antisemitism, despite Israeli propaganda efforts to conflate the two.

Sir — Hamas is a terrorist and barbaric organisation. It is impossible to eliminate its members from Gaza. The killings and mayhem there serve only as effective recruitment engines for the next generation of deluded fanatics. Netanyahu is inducing a new generation of ruthless paramilitaries that will prove a huge threat to Israel.
Dr Wahba Abdalmajid, the Palestinian ambassador to Ireland, gave a classic exhibition of ducking and diving evasion on the core issue of Hamas terrorism in a revealing interview with Niamh Horan (
, November 5).
I concur with Eilis O’Hanlon. It is possible to be anti-war and pro-Israel.
Sir — Eilis O’Hanlon is selective in her recollections and, as is now customary, labels any criticism of Israel in the West as antisemitic.

Students of history and those with good memories will recall then taoiseach Charlie Haughey standing up to Britain and its prime minister, Maggie Thatcher, over the sinking of the Belgrano during the Falklands War in 1982 with the loss of 368 lives, mostly young sailors who were in their teens.
Charlie Haughey united the country over Argentina

This action precipitated a massive rift in British-Irish relations when the Irish government of the day withdrew its support for European sanctions imposed on Argentina after its invasion of the Falklands and, as a member of the Security Council, Ireland called for the United Nations to promote a diplomatic settlement.
It was one of the few occasions when Haughey had the whole country behind him in support of Argentina.
Sir — As a young man many years ago in London, I lodged with a Polish-Jewish family. I say lodged, but in time I became almost a member of the family. I read the
each week.

Ignace, the father of the house, told me his family had a milling business in Poland. He spoke of the Holocaust once, perhaps at my instigation, I’m not sure. Some members of his close circle disappeared, never to be seen again.
Is it not ironic that there is many a man in Palestine, like Ignace, mourning lost family and friends, annihilated not by the gas chamber but by the bomb?

Sir — The tragedy of history is that it is repeated — we learn nothing. This is an unwinnable war. Neither Israelis nor Palestinians can destroy each other. Neither the US nor Iran can win the war for either side.
It’s time to end the carnage, free the hostages and broker a lasting solution. Otherwise, it will go on and on. Deep down, everybody knows this.

Sir — Shane Ross wrote a cynical article (November 5) about Taoiseach Leo Varadkar’s trade mission to South Korea, saying that “North Korea’s Kim Jong Un must have been quaking in his boots when he heard that Ireland’s premier was prowling around his borders”.

Your readers will recall that in November 2014, minister Shane Ross with junior ministers John Halligan and Finian McGrath had intended to travel to North Korea for a meeting with the same Kim Jong Un. The supreme leader (I mean Kim) was throwing a few shapes and launching a few ballistic missiles. Our three heroes were going there to sort him out.
However, they cancelled their mission when it became apparent they were becoming a national laughing stock. I doubt if Kim was doing any quaking then.
Shane also criticises Leo for going abroad to get photo opps, something Micheál Martin wouldn’t do. But Micheál was in China for the past week, photo opps wall to wall, and he is away this week too.
Irony is lost on Shane.
Sir — School suspension and expulsion numbers have increased significantly across Ireland since the Covid-19 pandemic, according to new figures from Tusla.

Knowing that students who experience suspension are more likely to disengage from the education system, become involved with the juvenile justice system and are more likely to experience homelessness, what are we doing to prevent the escalation of these issues?
At YMCA Dublin, we run an Alternative Suspension (AS) programme, which supports students who are at risk of disengagement from education or have been suspended.

As an alternative to the traditional exclusionary school suspension approach, this is an internationally proven intervention. Students are empowered to work through their difficulties in a constructive manner.
Last year, we saw a 43pc reduction in negative behaviours among participants.

Such supports need to become a national priority to help support vulnerable students, prevent educational disadvantage and transform future outcomes for young people. If we fail to invest in our youth, who will?

Sir — Someone once said the professions have the country by the throat. Reading Jody Corcoran’s article (‘Plunged into state of disrepair after brush with elusive, tardy tradespeople, October 29), it would appear that tradespeople have overtaken the professions in this regard.

This is nowhere better illustrated than in the story told about the New York lawyer who complained to a plumber about the exorbitant fee he had been charged. “I’m a lawyer,” he remonstrated, “and I don’t make that kind of money.”
To which the tradesman responded: “Neither did I when I was a lawyer.”

Sir — Your editorial last Sunday stated that women priests might be the last hope for the Catholic Church. It said some dioceses — for example, Perth, Australia — have “bucked the trend” of the decline in religion throughout the western world.
A third cousin of mine (born in Belfast) has been a parish priest in Perth for many years. Why don’t some of the Irish bishops contact him to discover the secrets of Perth’s success?

He has a sister who is a nun there. If she had been given the chance, I’m sure she would have been as successful a priest as her brother. However, she was never given that chance — and so the loss has been to the church.
If we are all equal in God’s eyes, maybe the church has some catching up to do — with God.
Sir — I was delighted to read your view that women priests might be the last hope for the Catholic Church.
It is going down the Swanee River. The number of priests has dropped amazingly since I was a girl.
The winds of change blow slowly in Rome. We could have married priests to save the church. We are all God’s children and the church will fall if Rome doesn’t hurry up with a solution.

Sir — I was selected to be on the Citizens’ Assembly on Drugs, organised by a government secretariat, which sat for six weekends between April and October. We sat in groups, we listened to presentations, had discussions and asked questions.
A steering group was selected from members of the assembly, but this mainly received information from the secretariat.

There was also an opportunity for outside groups or individuals to make submissions. Assembly members had no contact with these people or groups, and no input into the selection of presenters or topics.

There were 20 hours of high-quality formal presentations from over 120 speakers covering international, European and national perspectives, drug research, legal approach, rehabilitation, benefits and prevention.

The presentations concentrated on addiction being the result of trauma (six hours) and the solution being more funding for rehabilitation. Except for cannabis, there was little or no information on the nature and impacts of the most commonly used drugs in Ireland, no information on the science or biology of addiction, little reference to the problems of drug use for fun and its consequences, or how the drug trade is being funded by the more affluent in society.
There was acceptance that supply cannot be stopped and the approach was on mitigating harm.

At the third, fourth and fifth weekends, members were invited to propose solutions. These were steered towards topics that had been presented. At the final vote, members were presented with choices selected by the secretariat, reflective of the government plan, “Reducing Harm, Supporting Recovery”.
As there are other causes of addiction, the emphasis in the assembly on trauma and addiction left members, in my view, with a skewed view of the issue of addiction.
I feel the assembly was steered in a particular direction. At the final vote, we were voting on what the Government had already decided.

To me, the Citizens’ Assembly was not a democratic process, and it arrived more or less at the solution already decided by the Government. These assemblies are using taxpayers’ money. They should not be window dressing for government policy.

Sir — We will remember the names of Jason Corbett and Ashling Murphy, not just because of who they as individuals were, but how in their short lives they were beacons of fun, laughter, kindness and, most of all, love.
What must be remembered by those who grieve at their loss is the beautiful, pleasant and happy days spent with those who were loved.
That can never be taken away while we forget the sadistic murderers who have nothing left in their lives but time.

Sir — Eight-hundred teaching posts in Ireland’s primary schools remain unfilled due to a shortage of teachers. It’s anticipated that there will be an additional 1,200 vacancies within the next three months.
Disadvantaged schools and special schools, especially, are experiencing particular difficulties finding teachers, and the teacher shortage is having a huge impact on special education provision.

I have always had a great fondness for Irish history, language, literature, culture and traditional music. In the beautiful words of Pádraig Pearse, “tír gan teanga, tír gan anam” (a country without a language is a country without a soul), but needs must when the devil drives.

In my work as a career guidance counsellor, I regularly engage with young people who would love to become primary teachers. Unfortunately, many of them cannot apply because they are not studying Higher Level Irish at Leaving Cert or are eliminated for not achieving a minimum of 60pc in that exam.

I wonder, considering the acute shortage of primary teachers, if it’s time to relax the Leaving Cert Irish requirement a little to allow many suitable and enthusiastic young people to enter the teaching profession.

With the emphasis on oral, functional and interactive learning in the primary school language curriculum, I’d expect a young person with a minimum of 40pc at Higher Level or 60pc at Ordinary Level in Leaving Cert Irish would be capable of teaching Irish at primary level.
I may be incorrect in that observation, but it would certainly open up primary teaching to many fine young people who would love to become primary teachers.

Sir — On a recent trade mission to Korea, our Taoiseach and his team saw fit to raise a glass and propose a toast of “Sláinte” to their hosts. Each of the team held aloft a pint of the black stuff; there was no mistaking what product they were holding.
Our Taoiseach is a doctor and a former health minister. He knows only too well the harm and destruction that alcohol has brought to so many of our citizens

title: Sinn Féin to support Social Democrat motion on expelling Israeli Ambassador
body: Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald and Vice President Michelle O Neill pictured speaking on day two of the Sinn Fein Ard Fheis in Athlone. Photo: Frank McGrath
Sinn Féin is set to support a motion in the Dáil next week calling for the Israeli Ambassador to be expelled.

The party did not table a motion for Ambassador Dana Erlich to be expelled themselves but instead will support the Social Democrat motion and call for Ireland to refer Israel to the International Criminal Court.

Speaking at the party’s Ard Fheis in Athlone, Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald said the party did not put down a Dáil motion calling for the Israeli Ambassador to be expelled as the Irish Government has made their view on the expulsion “clear”.
Instead, the party will call for Ireland to refer Israel to the International Criminal Court in a debate in the Dáil next week.
She said sanctions for Israel have to be “addressed” and said Israel should be referred to the International Criminal Court by the Irish Government.

“They’ve made their view on the Ambassador clear, I disagree with them but they have set out their stall on that. Therefore, we will bring the motion to the Dáil next week that seeks a referral by the Irish Government, by the Irish State, to the International Criminal Court.
“I see no reason why the Irish Government wouldn’t come behind that.”

Ms McDonald referred to the Taoiseach’s comments that Israel’s actions in Palestine are like “revenge” and that there should be consequences for Israel and said she wants to see support from the Government on the motion.
She said the moment the Israeli Government agree to a ceasefire, she will “talk to them all day and all night if that is helpful”.
“Israel does not get a by ball on this. The world is shouting for ceasefire and he [Benjamin Netanyahu] is saying no,” she said.
The Government is set to sign off on proposals to reduce social welfare payments and putting a limit on State accommodation for Ukrainian refugees.
Ms McDonald said it is “problematic” and “inappropriate” to put a 90-day limit on providing State accommodation for Ukrainian refugees.
“We’ll see what their proposals are and then we’ll work constructively on that.”
Separately, British Home Secretary Suella Braverman is facing calls to be sacked after she said in a newspaper article the police were biased for allowing a pro-Palestinian march on Armistice Day.
In the article, the Tory politician also described pro-Palestine protests as “hate marches”.
Ms McDonald said Ms Braverman needs to “cop on”.
“I would advise her perhaps not to comment on things on which she has a very sketchy, if any understanding, of,” she said.
Ms McDonald said pro-Palestine protests saw people come out “in a spirit of peace and love and humanity”.
“So to label that as any way hateful is to my mind, absolutely unbelievable and bizarre quite frankly.”
She said Ms Braverman is “the least of our concerns and our worries here” but said the Tory Government should join the UN position in calling for a ceasefire.

title: ‘Seeing my mother being pulled out of the house by Paratroopers with guns...it’s the same s**t we see happening now’
body: Bohemians boss says he cannot ignore the plight of Gaza
Declan Devine
The manager of a football club knows better than anyone else how a comment on social media can land someone into deep, deep trouble.

Bohemians boss Declan Devine is one of only three Premier Division managers in Ireland who has an account on X (formerly Twitter) but is the only one to actively engage. And when he posted a message with the Palestinian flag – four of them – four weeks ago as a new phase of the Israel-Hamas conflict began, he provoked responses varying from unstinting support to deep rage.

title: Editorial: Despite horror of two world wars, peace remains a distant hope
body: Palestinians fleeing north Gaza walk towards the south amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas. Photo: Reuters
Smoke rises over Gaza as seen from southern Israel, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestinian group Hamas. Photo: Reuters/Evelyn Hockstein
The world must know what happened and never forget, Dwight D Eisenhower said at the end of World War II. A few years later, he said: “The only way to win World War III is to prevent it.”
Today is Armistice Day, when the 40 million people who died in World War I are remembered.
It was supposed to have been the war to end all wars, but it was not.
World War II followed. Combat deaths were estimated at nearly 15 million. Civilian deaths numbered more than 38 million.
Despite such an appalling toll, the evidence suggests we have learned little. Our species remains drawn to destruction.
As Martin Luther King put it: “Returning violence for violence multiplies violence, adding deeper darkness to a night already devoid of stars.”
This week, Israel agreed to daily four-hour localised pauses in its bombardment of Gaza. The temporary cessations of hostilities are called “humanitarian”.
But a return to the business of mass bloodshed resumes for the remaining 20 hours of the day.
Since last weekend, tens of thousands of Palestinians have left Gaza on foot. Many carry white flags with their hands held up.
It has been a massive exodus, yet US estimates say about 250,000 civilians remain in northern Gaza.
Israeli troops continue to advance, block by block, in street fights against Hamas militants, while using air-strikes to drive them out of underground tunnels.
As this happens, the Palestinian death toll – currently believed to be 10,500 – can only grow.
We must also remember the 1,400 Israelis who were murdered by Hamas, and the 240 hostages they continue to hold.
The pauses, while too brief, will still be viewed as progress, and a partial victory for pressure from the Biden administration.

The glimpse offered by Washington of how it views the post-war future of Gaza is significant. It wishes to see the enclave politically unified with the West Bank under the administration of the Palestinian Authority.
US secretary of state Antony Blinken also reiterated America’s position that Israel should not reoccupy Gaza after its war with Hamas.
For this to happen, the US and its Arab allies would have to revitalise the Palestinian Authority and try to restore credibility.
This week, we also saw G7 foreign ministers meet in Tokyo, where Gaza and Ukraine were discussed.
Globally, the potential for meeting jaw to jaw – to borrow Winston Churchill’s phrase – is too readily dismissed, making it easier for war to proceed.
Sadly, the UN Security Council appears increasingly redundant. Tensions between the US and Europe on one side, and China and Russia on the other, guarantee deadlock.
World peace and security remain the overwhelming wish of the vast majority of people on our planet. Despite two world wars, we are no closer to realising it.

title: Paul Cunningham: In the fog of war, it’s tough to do the job properly – and if you’re Irish it can be even tougher
body: RTÉ political correspondent Paul Cunningham, left, with cameraman Owen Corcoran in Israel as they cover the war in Gaza
Even before boarding the overnight flight to Tel Aviv, I knew that I’d have zero chance of entering Gaza and this would impose severe limits on what I could report.

Israel and Egypt had sealed the border crossings after the Hamas massacre on October 7. The 2.3 million people in that narrow strip of land now relied on reporters already inside the territory to give first-hand accounts of the Israeli bombardment and pending invasion.

title: US turns the heat up on Israel as Gaza officials say missiles hit region’s biggest hospital
body: US secretary of state Antony Blinken says ‘far too many Palestinians have been killed’
A Palestinian woman holds her one-day-old granddaughter while she moves southward after fleeing northern Gaza. Photo: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa

Israeli air strikes hit three Gaza hospitals and a school yesterday, killing at least 27 people, and a ground battle was under way at another hospital, Palestinian officials said, as the U.S. voiced fresh disquiet at the war’s mounting death toll.
In his strongest comments to date on civilian suffering, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken denounced the number of Palestinians killed – put by Gaza authorities at more than 11,000.

title: Joe Biden and Xi Jinping to meet face to face in bid to cool global tensions
body: Xi Jinping and Joe Biden during their last meeting in November 2022. Photo: AP

US president Joe Biden will meet Chinese president Xi Jinping face to face for the first time in a year on Wednesday, the White House said, in high-stakes diplomacy aimed at curbing tensions between the world’s two superpowers.
The interaction, on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit in the San Francisco Bay area, could last hours and involve teams of officials from Beijing and Washington.

title: ‘They joined to see the Holy Land at the king’s expense’: Why hundreds of Irish recruits joined the Palestine Police in the last days of British rule
body: Hundreds of Irish recruits joined the Palestine Police in the last days of British rule and were caught in the crossfire that accompanied the foundation of the state of Israel
Irish members of the British Section of the Palestine Police in Jerusalem in 1922
They travelled in their hundreds to Palestine with the hope of decent wages and a life of adventure in the colonial police.
When they arrived, Irish recruits found themselves at the centre of a bitter conflict and a vicious guerrilla war in the years before the foundation of the state of Israel.

title: Eilis O’Hanlon: Who dares to stand up to China? Not our leaders anyway
body: Tánaiste Micheál Martin with Chinese vice president Han Zheng in Beijing
The pronouncements of Irish politicians on international affairs have about as much influence in the wider world as a cow farting in Cavan does on the global climate.

That’s not to say they shouldn’t speak out when dismayed by other countries’ actions — as Tánaiste Micheál Martin did at his party’s ard fheis last weekend when decrying Israel’s military operation in Gaza as “disproportionate” and in contravention of international law.

title: Letters: Can US really be seen as an honest broker when it furnishes Israel with funds and armaments?
body: A person searches a building destroyed during Israeli air raids in Khan Yunis, southern Gaza Strip. Photo: Getty
Brian Cosgrove (Letters, November 8) draws nobly, and with succinct currency, from a worthy pair of wise assessors on conflict dynamics.

Referencing both philosopher Hegel and poet William Blake, he distils the fundaments of conflict down to two key contrasting modes of behaviour as embodied and enacted by Blake’s mythical figures Urizen and Orc and their cyclical propensity to ever-enduring conflict.
His analogy hits the mark with depressing accuracy regarding the current catastrophic carnage in the Middle East.

Unfortunately, his endearing exhortation for a shift towards dialogue rather than dialectical engagement as “one way of escaping entrapment in this vicious cycle” seems more than a tad elusive, despite Anthony Blinken as “the possible overseer of such a process”.

Given the age-old conflicted tapestry of social, political, ethnic and colonial dynamics of the Middle East, all manipulated by the variegated proxy players and their perennial machinations towards self-interest, the chances of a dialogic solution seems remote.
No quotient of urbanity will likely cut the mustard.

The history of US protectionism as acted out in Korea, Vietnam, Central and South America, Afghanistan and other places seriously challenges the notion that they could rise to anything like a neutrally satisfying outcome.
Funding Israel constantly to the hilt and furnishing endless armaments to boot, could the US really be considered an honest broker in the scheme of things – these terrible and terrifying things?
Hope is undoubtedly a fine thing, but truth must first out to expose the core realities before Orc or Urizen can ever contemplate settling down in harmony.
I understand Israel has agreed to reduce its bombardment of Gaza from 24 hours a day to a mere 20. What a wonderful humanitarian gesture.
As the massacre of the innocents continues in the Middle East, the EU states, by and large, stand idly by.
As Beethoven was a strong defender of the weak and a powerful advocate for justice, the EU must now be prohibited from using his symbol of hope, peace and fellowship,
, as its anthem. The hypocrisy is unbearable and unforgivable.

Peace without victory was the underlying concern of US president Woodrow Wilson when he, Clemenceau of France and Lloyd George of Britain tried to draw up a peace settlement at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919/20 at the end of World War I.

Known as the Versailles Settlement, it consisted of five separate treaties signed with each of the enemy powers and was dominated by America, Britain and France. Wilson hoped for a treaty founded on principle, not on the selfish interests of the victors.
US president Joe Biden and UK prime minister Rishi Sunak would do well to reflect on the views of Wilson.
When Mr Sunak visited Israel after the horrific attack by Hamas, he shook hands with Benjamin Netanyahu and said: “We hope you win.”
However, the Treaty of Versailles failed for many reasons. JM Keynes, a distinguished Cambridge economist, said it took little account of the economic structure of Europe.
Lloyd George and Clemenceau had clear support from their electorates. Lloyd George could not resist the demand for revenge. Clemenceau wanted a vindictive peace.
Wilson’s guiding principle was self-determination so that all people speaking the same language should be together in independent states.
Nevertheless, the Versailles Settlement, in spite of its shortcomings, bears the stamp of goodwill and justice, which Wilson gave it.
“Peace without victory” remains unburied.
When the last body has been pulled from the ruins of Gaza and the final death count determined, when ICC prosecutors make their decisions about who to charge and who not, I will always remember.
When it begins to dawn on our politicians and diplomats that we have once again allowed the unthinkable to happen, I will always remember.

When we again declare “Never again”, there will be those who would soon forget that the slaughter was conducted under American drone surveillance, using American weapons, with constant communication and in-person meetings between American, Israeli and European officials, with American aircraft carriers and strike forces sitting just offshore and that the White House publicly declared, in defiance of worldwide protest, that there are no “red lines” for Israel, I will remember.
It was good to hear Tánaiste Micheál Martin stand up to Vladimir Putin at the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Praise is also due to Taoiseach Leo Varadkar for cautioning the Israeli authorities not to overstep this “revenge” mission for the bloodshed of October 7 and thereby cause the “human rights” concept to be sullied forever.
It was positive for Sabina Higgins early on in the Russian invasion to attempt to introduce the peace talks process.
And it is proper that her husband, President Michael D Higgins, pushes for peace talks between Israel and Hamas.
I have been listening to the casualty figures coming out of Gaza and Israel since the attack by Hamas on October 7 and they are truly appalling.
The horror of what happened when Hamas terrorists entered Israel is unbelievable.

They killed at least 1,400 innocent people, including babies; they raped and murdered young women attending a peace concert; the naked body of one was paraded through the streets of Gaza, cheered on by onlookers. They also took more than 200 hostages, including families with young children.
Since then, we have had saturation media coverage of innocent inhabitants of Gaza being killed, including at least 4,000 children, by the Israel bombardment.
In the interests of balance, when footage of the bombardment is broadcast, surely it should be accompanied by footage of what Hamas terrorists did on October 7.
There is now growing support for the people of Gaza, who need humanitarian assistance. Hopefully, they will get it.

Those who are protesting against the Israeli bombardment must be commended for their humanity, but are they basing their protests on the casualty figures released by Hamas, a murderous terrorist group who control the news coming out of Gaza?

Why is the world media listening to anything a terrorist organisation has to say? The media should, by all means, continue reporting on the casualties in Gaza as well as in Israel, but with a proviso that the figures coming from a terrorist-controlled part of Gaza cannot be verified.
The Christmas season used to start on December 8. Now it appears to come earlier every year.
Nearer the big day, we will be reminded Easter eggs will soon be available in the shops. It seems we are too busy trying to catch up with the future to live for the present.
Every time I hear a weather forecast predicting “scattered showers”, I reckon this is the Lord’s way of ensuring we all get a fair share.

title: Eamon Ryan calls for immediate ceasefire between Israel and Hamas after meeting with Arab and Israeli ambassadors
body: Eamon Ryan

Green Party leader Eamon Ryan has called for an immediate and full ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas conflict and said there must be international focus and pressure on finding a long-term solution to the crisis in the region.

The call came after a series of meetings the coalition government leader had with the Palestinian ambassador to Ireland, along with ambassadors to Ireland from several Arab states, and the Israeli ambassador to Ireland.
Minister Ryan said a ceasefire was needed to ensure vital humanitarian aid could be delivered and to allow for negotiations to take place to secure the release of hostages.
The party leader said that the attacks by Hamas on Israel were horrifying, but that Ireland had been clear that the Israeli response must be in line with international law.
“The most important thing now is that we have an immediate ceasefire. Israel has to stop the bombardment and Hamas has to stop firing rockets and release the hostages,” Minister Ryan said.
"We have to move beyond four-hour pauses, which mean that the remaining 20 hours of the day continue to be filled with death and destruction,” he added.

An Irish-Israeli girl, Emily Hand (8) is among the 240 people being held hostage by Hamas after its October 7 attack on Israel in which 1,400 people were killed. Israel on Friday said it had revised the number of its citizens killed in the attacks down to 1,200, as 200 of the bodies have now been identified as belonging to Hamas terrorists.
The death toll among Palestinians has now passed 11,000, according to Gaza’s health ministry.
Minister Ryan also said Ireland would continue to work with the US and EU to ensure a ceasefire and to focus on finding a solution to the crisis in the region.
"We also have to focus on what can happen the day after the ceasefire starts, the day after the shelling ends,” Mr Ryan said.
"That is the most important day because that has to be the beginning of the end, when the international community focuses on this issue which has been ignored for decades,” he added.

The comments come a day after President Micahel D. Higgins met with a group of Arab nation ambassadors to Ireland at their request to discuss the current crisis in the Middle East, although he did not meet the Israeli ambassador to Ireland.

During the meeting, the President referenced his and the Irish Government's condemnation of breaches of international law that saw attacks on civilians by Hamas as well as the response to those attacks by Israel and repeated his call for the release of all hostages.

President Higgins also called for proposals to be brought forward on potential solutions to end the crisis. The President said that discussions that looked at the future of the region must focus on a two-state solution.

title: ‘Far too many’ Palestinians killed by Israel in Gaza, US secretary Blinken says as death toll tops 11,000
body: Palestinians stand by the bodies of the Hijazi family who were killed in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip in Rafah (AP Photo/Hatem Ali)
Thousands of Palestinians on Friday fled from around Gaza City's main hospital after a series of strikes that staff blamed on Israel hit in and around several hospitals overnight.
They joined a growing exodus of people toward the south amid intensified fighting as Gaza officials said the Palestinian death toll from the war surpassed 11,000 people.

title: Web Summit understood to stand over all-access packages for The Ditch founders despite pulling funding
body: On his ‘Chairperson’ information page within the Web Summit app, Ditch co-founder Roman Shortall has placed a ‘Free Palestine’ flag and text
Eoghan McNeill and Roman Shortall
The Web Summit is standing over VIP, all-access packages given to the co-founders of The Ditch investigative website, despite pulling its funding, it is understood.
The co-founders of the Ditch investigative website, Roman Shortall and Eoghan McNeill, were gifted VIP, all-access packages worth €25,000 to this year's Web Summit, which starts next week.
The tech conference cut all funding ties to The Ditch over the news website's description of Israel as an "apartheid" state committing war crimes.
The €25,000 'Chairperson' tickets entitle holders to gain access to speakers, organisers, politicians and other VIPs.
On his ‘Chairperson’ information page within the Web Summit app, Mr Shortall has placed a ‘Free Palestine’ flag and motto.
A spokesperson for the Web Summit declined to comment.

Earlier this week, Web Summit announced it would cut off all funding to The Ditch, which had been supported financially by former Web Summit chief executive and co-founder Paddy Cosgrave. It is understood it was to receive backing worth €1m over five years.

Cosgrave resigned as CEO last month and apologised as several influential tech investors and firms including Google, Meta, Siemens and Intel, pulled out of the event after he suggested Israel was committing “war crimes” in Gaza with its response to Hamas’s October 7 attack.
"As Web Summit moves to focus on our core mission, the board has determined we will conclude our funding relationship with The Ditch,” the Web Summit said as it parted ways with The Ditch.
"The Ditch is a separate investigative organisation with an independent editorial line. Web Summit respects independent media and editorial control,” the Web Summit said.
Mr McNeill was previously listed as “staff” on Web Summit’s mobile app, but it is understood that he now has the all-access “chairperson” ticket.

Earlier on Friday, new Web Summit CEO Katherine Maher said the Web Summit expected to see big tech companies which had pulled out of the conference return, though not on time for next week's event. She made her comments after Germany’s vice-chancellor Robert Habeck joined those boycotting the event.
She also said that the firm expects to see 70,000 attendees at the conference which will begin on Monday.
However, she added that the Lisbon-based conference was "oversubscribed" for investors, with 900 in attendance. Last year, the Web Summit invited almost 1,100 investors.
Mr Shortall and Mr McNeill were contacted for comment.

Despite its small size The Ditch has gained significant traction since it launched in 2021, specialising in breaking news stories grounded in information gleaned from public filings such as land registry and planning documents.
Mr Cosgrave had previously said his company’s support for the site was “incredibly effective brand marketing for Web Summit”.
Its stories have led to the resignations of junior ministers Robert Troy (FF) and Damien English (FG) and to major probe of An Bord Pleanála.

But it has drawn the ire of senior political leaders in Ireland, including Tánaiste Micheál Martin who in the Dáil described the investigative website as “a political organisation”, drawing criticism himself from the National Union of Journalists.

title: Johnny Duhan: Gentle path of forgiveness is the only roadmap to resolve conflict
body: The grace of Gordon Wilson once lit up a dark Remembrance Sunday by rejecting revenge
The cenotaph at Enniskillen in 1987, with the devastated community centre in the background. Photo: PA
Gordon WIlson, peace campaigner

In 1928, when Limerick’s British Legion Club was granted permission by Limerick City Council, through a majority vote, to erect a monument in Pery Square to commemorate the 3,000 Limerick men who died in World War I, one of the dissenting councillors is reported to have warned: “Erect it, if you like. But it will come down!”
And by God, come down it did — even though the cenotaph that was erected a year later was designed on the motif of Christ’s crucifixion. in an Ireland predominantly Christian at the time.
It took more than a quarter of a century for the prediction to be fulfilled.
At 2.50 in the morning of August 17, 1957, the IRA planted a bomb below the emblematic ‘Cross of Sacrifice’ — which not only obliterated the monument but also, according to a report in the
, caused extensive damage to surrounding buildings where “some people in the vicinity were thrown from their beds by the force of the blast”.

I was just seven years of age at the time of the explosion, but I remember accompanying my father (a member of the Legion Club) to Pery Square later that morning, where he took a lump of white granite from the rubble of what was left of the cross, as a keepsake of what he considered a vile atrocity.
Can the human race ever break free of the endless cycle of blood revenge?

It was not because he was Christian (in fact he was agnostic while I was growing up), but was in memory of his father, who had been a sergent major in the Munster Fusiliers with active service in India behind him, and his grandfather, who also had British army affiliations and once served in China, according to my old man.
All this came back to me on Remembrance Sunday 1987, when the IRA struck again with a bomb that killed 11 people attending the war memorial service in Enniskillen.

The most striking aspect of this tragedy was the unprecedented response of Gordon Wilson after he and the dead body of his daughter Marie were taken from the rubble following the explosion. Instead of venting ire and anger and calling for revenge, he surprised the world by announcing that he was going to pray for the bombers.

​It was Leo Tolstoy who brought my full attention to the uniqueness of the Sermon on the Mount gospel passage (Matthew 5: 38-46), where Christ goes against the Mosaic law of an eye for and eye and a tooth for a tooth — and replaces it with his edict of turning the other cheek and loving even one’s enemy.

A seemingly impossible proposition, but one Gordon Wilson proved is attainable and must be aimed for, if the human race is ever going to break free of the endless cycle of blood revenge that world history is mired in.
Gordon WIlson, peace campaigner

I remember my father once tried to explain away the reality of never-ending war to me, suggesting that it regulated the world’s population — a deeply disturbing notion that no doubt evolved out of the acceptance of the natural evolutionary principle of the survival of the fittest.

It was a brutal concept that Adolf Hitler’s hero, Friedrich Nietzsche, promoted in his anti-Christian philosophy of acceptance of eternal conflict in a universe governed by the rigid laws of eternal return.

In his deepest moment of agony and grief, infused with what can only be described as supernatural grace and strength, Gordon Wilson demonstrated that the one and only way to resolve human conflict, at its deepest level, is the gentle way of forgiveness.

After the heart-rending tragedy of the recent invasion of Israel by Hamas — during the eerie lull while the world held its breath, awaiting the inevitable reprisals that were certain to follow due to the extent of the casualties and the mounting anxiety for old and young captives — I posted what I feared most people would consider a pipedream on my Facebook platform.
It drew on the memory of Gordon Wilson’s significant contribution to bringing peace to Northern Ireland as a blueprint for what might be attained in the Middle East.

I ended my reflection with a song that demonstrates that seemingly insurmountable obstacles can be overcome when the summit aimed for is illuminated by the kind of beacon Gordon Wilson took his bearings from.

The fact that the source of his guiding light was a Jewish man who claimed to be God’s son may draw a quibble from agnostics and atheists — but genuine Islamists, as well as sincere Jews, respect the man who allowed himself to be nailed to a cross as an advertisement to promote the only viable solution the human race has ever been given for conflict resolution.
The song is called
​On both sides of the divide, in both conflicts, a measure of right and wrong applies to the opposing parties.

But as long as one side keeps threatening to annihilate the other, and the other keeps acquisitioning illegal territory to buttress the ongoing threat of annihilation, then the task will remain insurmountable.

title: Dáil will vote next week on expelling Israeli Ambassador to Ireland Dana Erlich
body: Social Democrats tabled motion in response to Israel’s killing of civilians in Gaza
Israeli ambassador to Ireland Dana Erlich Photo: Mark Condren
The Dáil will hold a vote next week on expelling Israeli Ambassador to Ireland Dana Erlich after the Social Democrats tabled a motion seeking to oust the diplomat.

The party’s foreign affairs spokesperson Gary Gannon tabled a motion today calling on the Government to “withdraw the diplomatic status” of the Ambassador “given the failure of the Israeli state to cease the deliberate targeting of civilians, journalists, UN staff and healthcare workers”.
A number of other parties have called for Ms Erlich to be expelled due to the continued breaches of international law by Israel during its more than month-long war in Gaza.
Sinn Féin has called for the ambassador to be expelled after pressure mounted on party leader Mary Lou McDonald from activists over her refusal to call for Ms Erlich to go.
Israeli ambassador’s position is ‘now untenable’, says Mary Lou McDonald

However, Sinn Féin has refused to table a motion calling for her to be stripped of her diplomatic status. Sinn Féin is the only opposition party that can table motions every week. The other smaller parties have to wait until it is their turn in the weekly rotation.
People Before Profit said they would table a motion later this month when they have an opportunity to use the Dáil to call for the expulsion.
Sinn Féin are using their motion next week to call on the Government to refer Israel to the International Criminal Court due to their continued attacks on civilians in Gaza.
However, the motion, which is being tabled by Sinn Féin’s foreign affairs spokesperson Matt Carthy, does not appear to call for the Israeli ambassador to be expelled.
Mr Gannon’s motion also calls for Israel to be referred to the International Criminal Court.
However, he goes further, in calling on the Government to advocate at an EU level for economic sanctions on Israel, including the suspension of the EU-Israel Association Agreement.
Smoke rises over Gaza as seen from southern Israel, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestinian group Hamas. Photo: Reuters/Evelyn Hockstein
The agreement includes a clause which allows the deal to be suspend for a serious breaches of human rights.
Mr Gannon is also calling for the suspension of the EU-Israel Horizon Europe Association Agreement and Israel’s access to the €95 billion Horizon Europe fund for research and innovation.
The Dublin Central TD also wants the Control of Economic Activity (Occupied Territories) Bill 2018 and the Illegal Israeli Settlements Divestment Bill 2023 enacted as a matter of urgency.

The motion also states: “EU Commission President Ursula Von Der Leyen’s unequivocal support for Israel, despite its flouting of international law, has seriously undermined the EU’s response to this crisis.”
“A war crime is defined by the nature of the act – not the identity of the perpetrator,” it adds.
Ireland's Israeli ambassador talks about Hamas, neutrality, and Michael D Higgins

title: Hundreds of trade unionists blockade BAE Systems weapons factory in Israel-Gaza protest
body: Hundreds of trade unionists blockade BAE Systems weapons factory in Israel-Gaza protest

Hundreds of trade unionists under the banner “Workers for a Free Palestine” have blockaded weapons manufacturer BAE Systems’ factory in Kent in protest over the Israel-Gaza war. Activists descended on the site in Chatham, Rochester, at about 7am on Friday and blocked its two entrances as part of an international day of action called for by Palestinian trade unions to “end complicity in Israel’s war crimes”.

title: ‘Send the Israeli ambassador home’ – Mary Lou McDonald goes off script in fiery Sinn Féin ard fheis speech
body: Mary Lou McDonald on Israel's ambassador and motion to refer Israel to the International Criminal Court
SINN Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald has called on the Government to “send the Israeli ambassador home” in unscripted remarks to her party’s ard fheis.

Ms McDonald repeated a call she made earlier this week for the expulsion of Ambassador Dana Erlich but her latest comments, which came in the middle of a sharp critique of Israel’s actions in Gaza, were not in the scripted version of her televised address in Athlone on Saturday evening.

The call to expel the ambassador received a standing ovation from around 1,000 party members as well as the party’s front bench, which flanked Ms McDonald on the stage. Ms McDonald said she agreed with the Government that Israel’s actions cannot be without consequence.
“That is why the Irish government should take the lead and refer Israel to the International Criminal Court,” she said before adding: “And send the Israeli ambassador home.”

Returning to the script that was released to the media earlier in the day, Ms McDonald said: "When the European Commission gives carte blanche to Israel to massacre Palestinians, we say, no. Never. They do not speak for us. The world calls for immediate ceasefires.”

She described Israel’s response to the “horrific” Hamas attack of October 7 as “barbaric, hateful, cowardly, war crimes” and described Gaza as “graveyard of children”. Earlier, the Palestinian ambassador to Ireland Dr Jilan Wahba Abdalmajid was given a standing ovation by delegates who shouted "free, free Palestine".
What do Sinn Féin supporters want if party gets into Government?

In a wide-ranging speech at the end of the two-day ard fheis in Athlone, Ms McDonald said a Sinn Féin-led government without Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil would deliver the biggest housing programme in the history of the state and “fix housing once and for all”.

In a speech which mentioned the word “change” 16 times, the Dublin Central TD said the party’s ambition is to “lead government in the south” without the two Civil War parties “for the first time in a hundred years”, and she declared housing as Sinn Féin’s number one priority, whilst heavily criticising the Coalition’s policies.
“They say housing can’t be fixed overnight. They’ve had over a decade. Their record – crisis. We need a new government to bring energy, pace, and the plan to fix housing,” she said.

She promised that Sinn Féin will build “genuinely affordable homes”, give a month’s rent back to every renter and freeze rent increases for three years. She promised to “cut red-tape and bureaucracy” and deliver what she said will be “the biggest housing programme in the history of the state”.

The Sinn Féin leader told her party: “The stark choice at the next election is between a worsening housing crisis under this government or a new government, led by Sinn Féin that will fix housing, once and for all.”
‘You never fail to hear our call for freedom’ – Palestinian ambassador receives standing ovation at Sinn Féin ard fheis

Ms McDonald also criticised the funding of the health service for next year, arguing that “not even in the darkest days of the Troika” was a wide-ranging recruitment freeze implemented as has been announced by the HSE in recent weeks. A general recruitment freeze across the public service was imposed during the Troika bailout more than a decade ago.
Ms McDonald said her party would cut health costs and invest in more hospital beds and frontline staff.

On the cost of living, Ms McDonald criticised the Government’s delaying of childcare fee cuts, exclusion of some homeowners from mortgage relief and increases to excise on petrol and diesel. She said the party would “put money back in your pocket” - but did not outline specific policy responses.

On climate change she pledged an affordable “national retrofitting scheme” and taking Lough Neagh, which provides 40 per cent of the north’s drinking water and has been contaminated with poisonous algae, into public ownership.
She said that her party wants to build a “unified nation of confidence and compassion, talent and ingenuity, claiming our future, our rightful place among the nations of the world”.

She described this as a “new Ireland”, and added it would be a country where “the Orange and Green reconciled. No place for racism, Islamophobia, Antisemitism, sexism, homophobia, transphobia, or sectarianism. Where there is no them, only us”.
She was speaking at the end of a two-day ard fheis at the Technological University of the Shannon campus in Athlone, Co Westmeath.

title: Peace rally to end the use of Shannon Airport by US troops to be held over weekend
body: Shannon Airport
An escalation in the Middle East crisis is the catalyst for a peace rally at Shannon Airport which is set for Sunday, November 12, at 2pm.

The gathering has been organised by activist group Shannonwatch, who are calling for the Irish government to ensure Shannon Airport is not used by US troops in support of Israel in light of the bombardment of Gaza.

“Since repeated calls for inspections of US military planes have been ignored, the only way to be sure this is not happening is to stop the US military use of the airport as a matter of urgency,” a Shannonwatch spokesperson explained:
The vigil will also be calling for peace and the ending of human rights abuses and war crimes in all conflicts, including Ukraine, Israel/Palestine, Armenia, Sudan, Congo, Myanmar and elsewhere.

Group representatives said that, in particular, children who have been killed due to wars in the Middle East over the past two decades will be remembered and commemorated by reading out their names and ages.

This will include the Palestinian and Israeli children killed since October 7 2023, children killed in Yemen, Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Syria, as well as children killed by terrorist attacks in Western countries. Peace activists at the rally will be invited to participate in the reading of the children’s names.

The event coincides with Remembrance Sunday, the day of commemoration in the United Kingdom for military, civilian servicemen and women that took part in the two World Wars, as the Shannonwatch spokesperson continued: “Ireland’s future generations should not have to commemorating our participation in more wars. Our lasting legacy should be one of promoting peace”.

title: Doctors perform surgeries without anaesthetic prompting ‘screams’ as Gaza’s largest hospital is bombed
body: Palestinian girl Orheen Al-Dayah, injured in an Israeli strike has her wounds stitched without anaesthesia, at Al Shifa hospital in Gaza. Photo: REUTERS/Doaa Rouqa.
The biggest hospital in the Gaza Strip was coming under bombardment on Friday, the World Health Organization said, adding that 20 hospitals in Gaza were now out of action entirely.
This comes as doctors are being forced to carry out surgeries on patients without anaesthetic due to a lack of the drugs, leading to screams of pain and prayers sounding through Al Shifa hospital.

title: Letters: Be it a state or a terrorist group killing civilians, it is still classed as a war crime
body: People mourn a child yesterday as they collect the bodies of Palestinians killed in Israeli air raids in Khan Yunis, Gaza. Photo: Getty
The massacre of Israeli civilians by Hamas on October 7 cannot be seen as anything other than a terrible war crime, and the taking into Gaza of civilian hostages, including children, is indefensible.
Hamas and Islamic Jihad should release these civilian prisoners immediately.
Let us hope that little Emily Hand is among them and will be returned safely and quickly to her family.
More than 4,000 children have been killed by the Israeli military in the past few weeks, and this massacre in Gaza, similarly, can only be described as an egregious war crime.
Worse, it is part of a series of murderous attacks on Gaza since 2006 that have resulted in many thousands of Palestinian deaths. Soon it could be tens of thousands.
Hospitals, ambulances, schools and refugee camps have all been bombed. Nowhere is safe. Many have argued Israel’s actions are genocide.
A key difference between the Hamas attack and what Israel does is that no major power has a problem with naming the crime when committed by Hamas.
Israel, on the other hand, is actively supported by the US and the UK and enabled by the EU as it brutally flattens Gaza and kills thousands of civilians.
There is nothing new in this. Israel has, for decades, acted with impunity against Palestinians and has treated the UN and other international bodies with disdain.
The deliberate killing of civilians is always a war crime, no matter the perpetrator.
US president Joe Biden’s tolerance for the high civilian death toll in Gaza engenders doubt in the rules-based international order he champions.
This is not my view. I consider the so-called rules-based international order no more than a contrivance for imposing the will of the West.

Rather, this is the view of “dissidents” in the US State Department, as revealed in a leaked memo. These dissidents are clearly appalled by the rising death toll in Gaza and are undoubtedly well-intentioned.
The dissidents also say: “We must publicly criticise Israel’s violations of international norms such as failure to limit offensive operations to legitimate military targets.”
I do not believe Israel has any right whatsoever to attack Gaza, but this part of the statement obviously reflects consternation at Israel’s indiscriminate warfare.

The memo also states: “When Israel supports settler violence and illegal land seizures or employs excessive use of force against Palestinians, we must communicate publicly that this goes against our American values so that Israel does not act with impunity.”

Again, well-intentioned, though many people consider “American values” to be discredited, having been shaped by genocide against the indigenous population, by slavery and by more than a century of imperialist aggression.
Nevertheless, the disquiet among some in the US government about US support for Israel’s offensive (to put it politely) is encouraging.
Perhaps Mr Biden will be moved to agree with the dissidents, who say the US should call for a ceasefire.
However, time is of the essence. Every day granted by the US to Israel for the continuation of its onslaught is another day in which hundreds will die or be maimed.
Unfortunately, there’s good reason to believe Biden will back Israel to the bitter end, whatever that may be.
One wonders what the ultimate objective of Israel is in its current war of attrition on Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank.
I venture to suggest it could be far more sinister than just the defeat of Hamas.
Are they planning the total expulsion of Palestinians from both those occupied territories into new refugee camps in the Sinai desert region and east of the River Jordan?
Zionists have long perceived a Greater Israel with biblical borders, including Lebanon and parts of Syria.
If this is their ambition, then sadly the current conflagration would spread right across the Middle East.
Your editorial (‘Sympathy for Israel will run dry unless it can work for peace’, November 8) holds out the torch for peace when all seems lost at so many levels of humanity.
Israel has done immense damage to humanity. UN secretary general Antonio Guterres is right when he says: “The nightmare in Gaza is more than a humanitarian crisis. It is a crisis of humanity.”
I believe he means we have debased ourselves, our values, our very being, our souls, that which sets us apart.

Of course, mankind has always been capable of appalling cruelty, but what is taking and has taken place in Gaza marks a stark change – the absolute acceptance by the powers-that-be that human life is no longer of value and is subordinate to the might of the all-powerful state, even a democratic one. Why do our protestations and those of the UN not matter?

We always had the reassurance that it was only terrorist states that thought nothing of oppressing and destroying human life, but it is shocking that a democratic state representing a good people would have scant regard for the plight of the innocent.
When good nations openly devalue human life, the very existence of humanity is at stake.
Tánaiste Micheál Martin said: “I think there needs to be more reflection in public discourse around the importance of diplomacy.”
Surely what is needed is more reflection about the importance of human life.
I was surprised this week to see a government backbencher address the Dáil while wearing a colourful sports shirt. This is unbecoming for a parliamentarian.

TDs should show a sense of decorum as they represent their constituents in the House and take a leaf from their leaders, Leo Varadkar, Micheál Martin and Eamon Ryan, as well as Independent TD Michael Lowry, who are always impeccably turned out.
Or look towards Westminster, where smart attire is de rigueur.

title: Israel needs to propose talks to end the conflict and find peace
body: A peace initiative will help Israel and help the world’s democracies place themselves on the right side of history
An Israeli soldier stands on a naval ship as it sails on the Mediterranean Sea, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas. Photo: Amir Cohen
​As Israel wages war against Hamas, it must simultaneously propose a path towards peace.

Clearly, it is difficult to talk about peace during wartime. Temperatures are running high and an understandable sense of pain and outrage has overtaken even the soundest of minds. So much so that there are those who cannot see past seeking revenge. But a peace initiative is the only way Israel’s ultimate security can succeed.

title: Israel agrees to daily four-hour pauses in fighting
body: A wounded boy is carried after an Israeli strike in Deir Al-Balah, southern Gaza Strip, yesterday. Photo: Hatem Moussa

Israel agreed to pause military operations in parts of north Gaza for four hours a day yesterday, the White House said, raising hopes of a respite in more than a month of fighting that has killed thousands and stoked fears of regional conflict.

The pauses, that would allow people to flee along two humanitarian corridors and could be used for the release of hostages, were significant first steps, White House national security spokesperson John Kirby said.

title: President Higgins meets ambassadors from Arab countries to discuss Middle East crisis but Israel not included
body: President Michael D Higgins
President Michael D Higgins met with a group of Arab nation ambassadors to Ireland to discuss the current crisis in the Middle East. However, the Israeli ambassador to Ireland was not invited.

The meeting on Thursday followed a request from the chair of a group of ambassadors of Arab countries. The ambassador of Morocco, Lahcen Mahraoui, sought the meeting with President Higgins via the Department of Foreign Affairs to discuss recent developments in the Hamas-Israeli conflict and the future of the region after the crisis.

Asked why the Israeli ambassador Dana Erlich had not been invited to the meeting and whether it would have been wise to invite her, a spokesperson for the President said: “The meeting took place following a request from the group of Arab ambassadors to meet the President received through the Department of Foreign Affairs.
"No such request has been received to date on behalf of the Israeli Ambassador.”
Other ambassadors in attendance belonged to Palestine, Egypt, the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Algeria, Kuwait, Sudan and Iraq.

At the meeting, President Higgins said the loss of civilian life must be brought to an end as soon as possible and referenced his and the Irish Government's condemnation of breaches of international law that saw attacks on civilians by Hamas as well as the response to those attacks by Israel.
The President also repeated his call for the release of all hostages saying that those actions were too in breach of international law, his spokesperson said.

President Higgins also called for diverse proposals to be brought forward and for lasting engagement that can achieve security for Israeli citizens and also deliver the rights of the Palestinian people. The President also said that discussions that focused on the future of the region must focus on the importance of a two-state solution.

Those Irish citizens who are directly involved in the conflict, as part of the hostages taken or those unable to leave the conflict zone were also addressed with the Ambassadors, and the distress that those citizens are currently being exposed to.
Last month the President was criticised by the Israeli ambassador for making what she claimed were misinformed comments on the current conflict.
Speaking to the
, Ms Erlich said President Higgins’ comments had an “inflammatory” effect in relation to the Israel-Hamas war.

"I know the role of the President here and I know the importance in which he is held within the Irish public – but there is also a responsibility on politicians and the media. Especially during a time like this,” Ms Erlich said.

President Higgins, who has been outspoken in relation to the conflict, last week called for an “immediate humanitarian ceasefire” and said “collective punishment is not something we can accept and claim to be advocates of international law”.
The Israeli embassy in Dublin has been contacted for comment.

title: Israel agrees to pauses in Gaza attacks, US says, but no reports of lull in fighting
body: A Palestinian girl wounded in Israeli strikes, waits at Al Shifa hospital, in Gaza City. Photo: Reuters

Israel has agreed to pause military operations in parts of north Gaza for four hours a day from Thursday, the White House said, raising hopes of a respite in more than a month of fighting that has killed thousands and stoked fears of regional conflict.

The pauses, that would allow people to flee along two humanitarian corridors and could be used for the release of hostages, were significant first steps, White House national security spokesperson John Kirby said.

title: Press Ombudsman welcomes Taoiseach’s support on Sinn Féin TD’s defamation action over Hamas response
body: Leo Varadkar
Sinn Féin TD Chris Andrews

The Press Ombudsman has welcomed the support of Taoiseach Leo Varadkar after he spoke in the Dáil about the legal proceedings initiated by Sinn Féin TD Chris Andrews against a newspaper and journalist.
The Dublin Bay South TD is alleging he was defamed in an article written by political correspondent Harry McGee and published in
about Sinn Féin’s response to the Hamas attack on Israel.
The Taoiseach said in the Dáil on Wednesday that the legal action taken by Mr Andrews is “frightening” and “designed to make journalists afraid”.
Mr Varadkar said involving the Press Council should be the “first step”, not suing a news organisation or journalist.
Sinn Féin TD Chris Andrews

Press Ombudsman Susan McKay said in a statement today “the Press Council of Ireland and the Office of the Press Ombudsman deplore the practice of powerful public figures suing individual journalists in response to public interest news reporting”.

Ms McKay said the Press Council and Press Ombudsman offer “an alternative mechanism” for resolving disputes and “the services my office provide are free and open to everyone and we respond swiftly to all complaints we receive”.

“The freedom of the press is at the heart of our democracy We recognise that this carries responsibilities and that is why the Press Council and the Office of the Press Ombudsman were established,” she said.

“A defamation case, even if not upheld, will almost certainly be financially ruinous for an individual reporter, and will cause severe financial problems for a newspaper, potentially impacting on its ability to invest in quality journalism.”
Today's News in 90 seconds - November 9th
Press Council chair Rory Montgomery joined Ms McKay in welcoming Mr Varadkar’s support and urged “public figures and in particular public representatives to follow his advice”.
“We offer an alternative form of redress based on upholding the highest journalistic standards,” he said.
“In relation to the suing of individual journalists, the Press Council shares the Taoiseach’s stated opposition to the use of Strategic Lawsuits Against Public Participation.
“To see a Member in this House not just suing a major newspaper but also personally suing a journalist is only designed to do one thing,” Mr Varadkar told the Dáil yesterday.
“It is designed to make journalists afraid. It is designed to make them think twice about what they write and that is wrong. There are other ways to get redress and corrections and clarifications.

“At the very least, the first step should be the Press Council of Ireland and not suing a news organisation, and particularly not suing a journalist individually. I think that is frightening actually.”

title: Adam White: From countercultural hero to A-list Trumpster – what the hell happened to Jon Voight?
body: The veteran star of ‘Midnight Cowboy’ and ‘Coming Home’ blames Marxist brainwashing for his years spent as an anti-war, feminist leftist. And now he’s publicly condemning his own daughter Angelina Jolie for her stance on Israel and Palestine. Adam White asks: what happened?
Former President Donald Trump awards the National Medal of Arts to actor Jon Voight in the East Room at the White House. Photo: Salwan Georges/The Washington Post via Getty Images.

Finally, Jon Voight has spoken out about Israel and Palestine. Sitting in front of an American flag, the Oscar-winning actor seems to be reading off an autocue. His stances are all fire and brimstone, finger-wagging, and operatic declarations that “the messiah will win this war” between Israel and Hamas.

It’s undeniably dramatic. He is also not a fan of the recent actions of Angelina Jolie, his Oscar-winning daughter and an advocate for an Israeli ceasefire. She, Voight insists, has “no understanding of God’s honour, God’s truth.”

title: Fierce fighting in Gaza as US says Palestinians must govern Gaza post-war
body: Palestinian children look out from a window with a grill at the site of Israeli strikes on houses, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip, November 9, 2023. REUTERS/Ibraheem Abu Mustafa

Israeli forces battled Hamas militants through shell-blasted buildings in Gaza City on Thursday as some 80 countries and organisations met in Paris to coordinate humanitarian aid and find ways to help wounded civilians escape the siege.

Residents in Gaza City said Israeli were fighting Hamas and other militants and that tanks were stationed around the city. They said Israeli forces were moving closer to two hospitals where thousands of displaced Palestinians were seeking shelter.

title: ‘Obviously the circumstances are difficult’ – Robbie Keane avoids politics as his Israeli side return to action
body: Robbie Keane is in his first season as Maccabi Tel Aviv manager.
Robbie Keane has kept his focus on football by declining to talk politics ahead of his Israeli side resuming action in European competition tonight.

But the Dubliner has praised the attitude of his Maccabi Tel Aviv players as they prepare to take on another side from a conflict zone, Ukrainian outfit Zorya Luhansk, in the Europa Conference League in the neutral venue of Poland.

Keane and his assistant manager, compatriot Rory Delap, fled Tel Aviv hours after the current conflict began last month, with Keane overseeing operations remotely from his Dublin base while the bulk of the squad remained in Israel. The panel hooked up in Poland on Sunday to prepare for this Euro tie, played in Lublin, Maccabi resuming European action while the domestic league remains on hold indefinitely due to the ongoing war.
Ahead of their first game in five weeks, Keane did not take questions about the political situation in Israel although his striker Erin  Zahavi did say that Maccabi were “representing all of Israel”.
Today's Sport News in 90 Seconds - 9th November

“We always talk about football in terms of 'war' and say ‘let's fight, let's win’, but the real war is in Israel. We left our families there, the people we love, our soldiers are fighting there,” Zahavi said.
Keane, who was criticised in Ireland and further afield for taking up the post with an outfit which was labelled as as “racist and apartheid Israeli club” by one Sinn Féin TD,  stuck to sport.
"Obviously the circumstances are difficult, but as soon as we all came back together it was like a few weeks ago," Keane said at a press conference in Poland.

“It just shows the togetherness that the team has had since I arrived and it will always accompany us. I  have been very pleased with the attitude of everyone and their application. So far it's been a good week for us and I think for everyone now, this game can't come around quick enough.

"Obviously we have been waiting to see the players, we have been in contact with them in the last few weeks, a lot. They have trained very well, they are in good shape, that’s every player. The mood in the last few days is very good. This is the essence of a team, what a team is all about, when people really want to play for each other.”

title: Five things we learned from the Sinn Féin ard fheis
body: ‘You never fail to hear our call for freedom’ – Palestinian ambassador receives standing ovation at Sinn Féin ard fheis
Around 2,000 Sinn Féin members gathered in Athlone from all over the country for the party’s annual ard fheis.
Here are the top five things we learned from the two-day affair at Technological University Shannon.

title: Letters: Rabin’s heartfelt plea for peace is worth recalling as bombs continue to fall
body: American president Bill Clinton watches as Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin, left, shakes hands with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat at the White House in September 1993. Photo: Getty
No one can but be appalled by the bombing by the IDF of the civilian population in Gaza.

To see so many innocent people, including children, being pulled from the rubble of their homes is soul-destroying. But I am also appalled at the senseless killing by Hamas of innocent people in their kibbutz and at a peace festival.
I see demonstrations on behalf of the Palestinian people even in my home town, but I don’t see one demonstration on behalf of those who were slaughtered by Hamas. Why?
Recent statements by Hamas officials show a total disregard for the civilian population.

When interviewed, Mousa Abu Marzouk, a senior member of Hamas, said the hundreds of kilometres of tunnel systems under Gaza “were to protect Hamas fighters from airstrikes, not [to protect] civilians”, and “it is the responsibility of the UN to protect them”.
Ghazi Hamad, another senior Hamas official, told Lebanese TV his organisation was determined to repeat the massacre of October 7.
How can there ever be peace when extremists on both sides want to annihilate each other, no matter the consequences for the civilian population?

Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli prime minister who was assassinated by a Jewish zealot at a rally in 1995 and had shaken hands with PLO chairman Yassar Arafat in 1993 on the White House lawns after the Oslo accords were signed, said: “ We say to you today in a loud and clear voice: enough of blood and tears, enough.”
Looking at the world from Canada, I am very impressed with Ireland’s stance on the current conflict between Israel and Hamas – it has echoes of Ireland’s stance in 1939.

As a life-long student of Irish history and Irish politics and an admirer of James Dillon, one of the Dáil’s great performers of that period, I was always intrigued that Ireland didn’t provide token support to the Allies by offering a base for American troops.

About 20 years ago, I attended a talk in Toronto given by Garret FitzGerald, and he explained why this didn’t happen. From 1939 to 1945, Ireland was an extremely unstable democracy, with the Civil War still very ripe in people’s memories.
In Ireland, World War II was considered a war between England and Germany. In such a scenario, Ireland could never associate with the Allies, aka England.

In 2023, things are different. Ireland is one of the most stable democracies in the world. However, the independent-mindedness that has its origins in World War II serves Ireland well on the wider world stage, even if it doesn’t align with the current narrative of the West.
There may be short-term pain, but there will be long-term gain.
As we watch the merciless, inhuman bombardment of Gazan civilians, with now over 10,000 dead, 4,500 of them children, none of us can say “we didn’t know”.
Al Jazeera reports in real time the broken bodies of babies, children, women and men being pulled from the rubble of what were their family homes.
Those who survive are brought to hospitals with depleted electricity and no anaesthetics for surgery. Refugees fill the corridors and operations are carried out on floors.
