The wider Gazan community has now lost all of its bakeries and the children are reduced to drinking salty water because of Israeli bombing of the water treatment plant. Journalists trying to tell the story are being targeted , with 38 already killed in Gaza.

Irish Nobel peace prize winner and former Peace People organiser Mairead Corrigan has called for the Genocide Convention at the World Court to be invoked, given the US veto on any action by the UN Security Council. She has specifically asked for independently minded countries such as Ireland, Spain, South Africa and Colombia to initiate this action to save the lives of Palestinians being “cruelly slaughtered”.
“Palestinians in Gaza are being demonised and suffering ethnic cleansing and collective punishment. This is a classic genocide and the Israeli government has to be accountable,” she said.
It is time for the Irish Government to stand for humanity and do something powerful. The use of the Genocide Convention gives us a way.
A very common phrase used by Irish politicians and the Irish business and entertainment world concerns how “Ireland consistently punches above its weight in global affairs”.

There is nothing wrong with confidence, especially in a country like ours that was downtrodden for hundreds of years by our bigger neighbour. However, confidence can sometimes tilt over to cockiness and even arrogance.
Since we are in boxing parlance territory, it would be a salutary reminder of what happened to boxer Amir Khan in 2016, when he insisted on going up two weights to fight Canelo Alvarez.
Khan claimed nobody in his own weight division matched him any more. Before the fight, he claimed that although he was smaller, his speed and agility would see him through.

The early rounds were going to plan until Alvarez, who had a reputation for being a brawler, caught Khan with a haymaker in the sixth round, leaving him prostrate and semi-conscious on the canvas with the fight over.

So, when this phrase about “punching above your weight” is used, remember that size does matter and maybe Irish politicians should tuck their chin in a little bit when in the company of “the bigger boys”.
What a breath of fresh air it was to read the comments by Tracey Wall, the clinical transformation lead with Children’s Health Ireland (
, November 7).
Her empathy for the children under the care of herself and all other excellent staff shone through.
Can we celebrate the achievement that is soon to be the delivery of a children’s hospital that will be the envy of many around the world?

title: Israel air strike kills 19 in third attack on Jabalia refugee camp in a week
body: Thousands of Palestinians trudged out of the north during four-hour window of opportunity
Israeli soldiers stand amid rubble during the ongoing ground invasion against Hamas in the northern Gaza Strip. Photo: Reuters

At least 19 people were killed in an Israeli air strike on a house near a hospital in north Gaza’s Jabalia refugee camp yesterday, the enclave’s interior ministry said, as thousands of civilians fled southward to avoid fierce Israeli-Hamas ground fighting.

There was no immediate Israeli comment or details from the scene of the reported attack, which, if confirmed, would be the third on Gaza’s largest refugee camp in a week as the war between the Gaza Strip’s Islamist Hamas rulers and Israel entered its second month.

title: Shadi Hamid: A ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas conflict is not a fantasy – here’s how it could work
body: Khaled bin Al-Walid Mosque is destroyed by Israeli raids in Gaza. Photo: Getty

The destruction in Gaza has reached staggering levels. More than 4,000 children have died. It is not sufficient to say war is tragic, although it is. It is true that Israel doesn’t deliberately aim to kill civilians. But for the Palestinians who mourn their dead, are they supposed to find solace in the notion that Israel didn’t intentionally target their loved ones, when the outcome is the same?

What might a plausible ceasefire look like in practice? The specifics matter. Any proposal must take seriously Israel’s legitimate security needs. First, Hamas must agree to release hostages and commit to halting rocket fire into Israel. In exchange, Israel would agree to stop its bombardment of Gaza as well as any ground incursions there.

title: Ceann Comhairle refuses request from Israeli ambassador to allow screening of Hamas attack in Leinster House
body: Ceann Comhairle Seán Ó Fearghaíl
Ceann Comhairle Seán Ó Fearghaíl has refused a request from the Israeli ambassador to allow a screening in Leinster House of graphic footage of the October 7 attacks by Hamas.
Ambassador Dana Erlich revealed her request had been declined at a private meeting with a small group of Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael politicians in Dublin’s Shelbourne Hotel on Wednesday.

Mr Erlich said she had asked Mr Ó Fearghaíl to facilitate the screening of a 43-minute film compiled by the Israeli government which shows graphic footage of the attacks last month that left more than 1,400 dead.

Footage in the film, which has been shown by Israeli embassies worldwide to journalists and other parties, was captured by GoPro cameras and mobile phones of Hamas fighters as well as CCTV and videos taken by first responders and victims.
A spokesperson Mr Ó Fearghaíl said he declined the request due to the graphic nature of the video and the belief that it would be inappropriate.

It is understood the Dáil chair’s view is that it would not be appropriate to sponsor such a viewing - but instead more appropriate to organise a briefing through the Irish-Israeli Parliamentary Friendship Group.
Ms Erlich met with this group in a private dining room at the back of the Saddle Room restaurant in the Shelbourne Hotel at lunchtime on Wednesday.
The meeting was shrouded in secrecy with attendees, all from the two main Coalition parties, reluctant to talk publicly about it afterwards and the Israeli embassy declining to confirm it took place.
Several politicians who attended said there was tight security and that they were asked to show ID or prove they were who they said they were.
One attendee said they showed their X social media profile as a means of proving their identity.
“They were like fellas you'd see in the CIA, black suits and ear pieces,” said a second attendee.

The meeting with Ms Erlich and her deputy Adi Ophir Moaz, who accused Ireland of funding Hamas tunnels in Gaza in a now-deleted post on X last month, was organised by Fianna Fáil Senator Aidan Davitt on behalf of the Oireachtas.

He was appointed chair of the friendship group, which has barely met since it was formed several years, by Mr Ó Fearghaíl after the previous chair, Fine Gael’s Jennifer Carroll MacNeill, was appointed a Minister of State last year.

Among the attendees in the Shelbourne were Fianna Fáil senators Catherine Ardagh, Lorraine Clifford-Lee, Diarmuid Wilson, Erin McGreehan, Gerry Horkan, Ned O’Sullivan, and Lisa Chambers while attendees from Fine Gael included backbench TD John Paul Phelan and senators Maria Byrne and Martin Conway.

It took place on the same day the Fianna Fáil parliamentary party met with the Palestinian ambassador to Ireland Dr Jilan Wahba Abdalmajid and Egypt's ambassador Mohamed Sarwat Selim back in Leinster House.

Ms Erlich was said by those present to be largely in listening mode, but in her contribution said the Israeli and Jewish community in Ireland are feeling vulnerable in the context of Ireland’s criticism of Israel’s actions in Gaza.
This comes in the wake of the Irish government's criticism of Israel’s actions in Gaza, which has killed more than 10,500 people.
Taoiseach Leo Varadkar last week said Israel’s actions were “something more approaching revenge” for the October 7 attacks.
“She was there looking for advice and on how parliamentarians think she could best put across the views of Israeli people,” said one attendee.
“She wanted to see how to rectify the perception in Ireland of Palestine good, Israel bad.”
Fianna Fáil senator Diarmuid Wilson told Ms Erlich that politicians were not anti-Israeli, but pro-democracy and human rights.
Concerns were also expressed by Ms Clifford-Lee about the plight of 40 Irish passport holders who are currently unable to get out of Gaza.
Speaking after the meeting Mr O’Sullivan said he was concerned about an increase in anti-Semitism in Ireland.

“My personal view is that the demonstrations that are going ahead, ostensibly pro-Palestine, are heavily marked by all the characteristics of classic anti-Semitism. I think the question of anti-Semitism has to be addressed in Ireland,” he said.

The situation of Israeli-Irish hostage Emily Hand, an eight-year-old girl who had been feared dead but is now thought to be held by Hamas, was also raised at the meeting with sources saying that with her ninth birthday next week there are tentative plans to mark this occasion in some way.
One proposal suggested by an attendee is that a member of her family would speak directly either in person or via video link to Irish politicians urging them to push for her release.
Another proposal suggested by one attendee afterwards was that a vigil for the young girl be held outside Leinster House.
An Israeli embassy spokesperson said: “Since arriving in Ireland recently, Ambassador Erlich has been carrying out a wide range of diplomatic duties, which includes meeting with TD’s, Senators.

“Since the barbaric Hamas attacks and abduction of civilians from Israel into Gaza on October 7th the Ambassador has been and continues to be very active in furthering such engagement and representing Israel in all appropriate forums.
“Ambassador Erlich is always open to meeting with members of the Oireachtas and plans to continue to do so.”

title: Cate Blanchett calls on EU parliament to stop ‘dangerous myth’ about refugees
body: Cate Blanchett has addressed the European Parliament (Jordan Pettitt/PA)
Oscar winner Cate Blanchett has urged the European Parliament to challenge the “dangerous myth” that “each and every refugee is headed here to Europe”.
On Wednesday, Blanchett addressed MEPs ahead of the plenary session and amid the conflict in Gaza and Israel.
The goodwill ambassador for UN Refugee Agency UNHCR said: “I am not Syrian. I am not Ukrainian. I am not Yemeni. I am not Afghani. I am not from South Sudan. I am not from Israel or Palestine.
“I’m not a politician. I am not even a pundit. But I am a witness.
“And having witnessed the human cost of war, violence and persecution, visiting refugees from across the globe, I cannot look away.”

The 54-year-old also said: “I urge each and every one of you here today to stand firm in challenging the dangerous myth pedalled far too widely and stoking far too much fear and hostility that each and every refugee is headed here to Europe.
Cate Blanchett with the Oscar for best actress for her role in Woody Allen’s Blue Jasmine (Ian West/PA)
“It has been tempting for some in Europe, to depict the challenge of refugees as a new one.
“The 1951 refugee convention, they say, is from another time.

“It was not designed to meet the challenge of so many people on the move, especially in a time of mass forced displacement, or when new forms of large scale displacement linked to climate change or natural disasters appear.
“The claim is that it places too many demands on our resources, on our schools.
Cate Blanchett stands with the Prince of Wales as he arrives for the 2023 Earthshot Prize Awards Ceremony (Jordan Pettitt/PA)
“Our hospitals, our job markets, or the new arrivals with their different languages and cultures will somehow undermine the values of those who host them.
“Apart from the monumental compassion deficit in this argument, it also demonstrates a dangerous disregard for history.
“Madam president, for centuries, Europe, like so much of the world has been criss-crossed by people who have fled home in search of protection from war.”
Ending her address, Blanchett said that flexible humanitarian funding has never been more urgent with “the number of forcibly displaced people at an all-time high”.

She then thanked the Parliament, EU, and governments and organisations who have helped those fleeing the war in Ukraine, adding: “This solidarity should not be limited to one group, but afforded to all.”
Blanchett, who has appeared in films including Carol and Ocean’s 8, became goodwill ambassador for UNHCR in May 2016.
In 2018, she addressed the UN Security Council on the Rohingya refugee crisis and recalled her experience visiting Bangladesh.
The actress co-created and executively produced the 2020 TV mini-series Stateless, which touches on issues of asylum and the Australian immigration system.
In 2023, she visited the Za’atari refugee camp in Jordan for the second time to draw attention to the stories and needs of refugees.

title: Ofcom gets 373 complaints about GB News’s Gaza-Israel conflict coverage
body: Viewers have complained to Ofcom about GB News’s coverage of the Gaza-Israel conflict (PA)
Viewers have complained to Ofcom about GB News’s coverage of the Gaza-Israel conflict.
The broadcast regulator got 373 complaints about November 1’s GBN Tonight, hosted by Patrick Christys.
The show, which airs weekdays from 9pm, is advertised as the “feistiest and most fun nightly news debate” and features celebrity guests, interviews and news coverage.
On Wednesday, Ofcom said there had been “complaints related to reporting of the ongoing Gaza/Israel conflict, with complainants expressing concerns about impartiality”.
Over the course of the programme, Christys spoke about Sir Keir Starmer marking Islamophobia Awareness Month and the Labour leader being under pressure over his stance on the conflict in Gaza.
Christys also covered antisemitism and pro-Palestine protests in the light of the conflict in Gaza.
A Palestinian man carries his belongings while fleeing the Naser neighbourhood after Israeli airstrike on Gaza City on Wednesday (Abed Khaled/AP)
Dan Wootton had been hosting a weekday programme from 9pm until actor-turned-politician Laurence Fox made on-air remarks about a female journalist.
On the Dan Wootton Tonight programme on September 26, Fox made a series of personal comments about political correspondent Ava Evans and asked: “Who would want to shag that?”
Fox and Wootton apologised with the former, who also hosted a programme on the channel, sacked.
An internal investigation into Wootton, who was suspended, was announced by GB News in September.
Ofcom is investigating the episode and has several other open investigations into the broadcaster.

title: Students block entrance to Trinity College, calling for ties with ‘apartheid Israel’ to be cut
body: Campaign group said ties with Israel make ‘every member of the college community complicit in Israel’s crimes and oppression of Palestine’
Trinity College Dublin Students' Union blocking the front entrance of the university in protest against the university's links with Israel. Photo: X/@tcdsu

Members of Trinity College Dublin Students’ Union (TCDSU) blocked the front entrance to the college and dropped Palestinian flags over the front of Regent House today as part of a call for TCD to “cut ties with apartheid Israel”.
The protest was part of the Trinity Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions (BDS) movement, a student campaign aimed at ensuring TCD cuts ties with Israel “for justice in Palestine”.

In November 2022 a Freedom of Information (FOI) request by the Trinity BDS group revealed TCD links with 15 Israeli organisations. This included seven companies, six other academic institutions and two individuals.
Trinity BDS has said the college’s Israeli links “make every member of the college community complicit in Israel’s crimes and oppression of Palestine.”

The group has highlighted the college’s ties with the Weizmann Institute of Science and said it “openly collaborates with the war-industry” and “supported the development of Israel’s nuclear arsenal”.
It has also criticised TCD’s ties to Tel Aviv University “which develops war technology, trains lawyers to defend war crimes and sends pro-Israeli delegations to foreign universities.”
TCDSU sent an open letter to Provost Linda Doyle last week calling for her “to listen to student and staff voices which have been demanding our college to take action.”
The letter said there is “a complete lack of a response from the college regarding Israeli war crimes in Palestine”.
Today's Sport News in 90 Seconds - 8th November

Following the escalation in violence in Gaza, TCDSU said in a statement that it stands “in solidarity with the Palestinian people, there can be no peace without justice, and justice is the end of the Israeli occupation”.

“TCDSU stand against all forms of violence, and we acknowledge the tragic loss of life caused by this war. However, standing with Palestine does not mean that we stand for violence,” the statement read.

"This cycle of violence is caused by systemic oppression, apartheid and occupation of Palestinian territories while the international community has stood back and watched for almost a century, despite the warnings of human rights organisations and the UN.”

This is not the first time TCD students have used a blockade in a demonstration – in September, access to the Book of Kells was blocked off by students to protest against the rising cost of on-campus student accommodation.
A spokesperson for TCD said: “We fully respect students’ right to protest in a peaceful and respectful manner.”

title: Letters: Let’s hope warring sides look to and learn from Good Friday Agreement
body: Two Palestinian men rest on a sofa near a house damaged in an Israeli strike in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip. Photo: Reuters
Every problematic situation is unique, but most such situations frequently have elements in common.

The issues in the Middle East have some features in common with the historical situation in the North of Ireland. During the plantation of Ulster, most of the Catholic population were robbed of their lands and forced to relocate to less fertile places.

This was further exacerbated by institutional discrimination against that population. Inevitably, this resulted in a gradual build-up of resentment, with the floodgates well and truly opening in the late 1960s.

We all know the horrors that were subsequently unleashed. Thankfully, the Good Friday Agreement went a long way to lancing that particular boil. While acknowledging the goodwill of many on the unionist side, it is to the great credit of the Catholic population that they did not seek the return of lands that belonged to their ancestors and which, in justice, they had a claim to.
There are definite parallels with the current situation in Isreal/Palestine. Hopefully, they can learn from the Good Friday Agreement. Surely it is worth a try.
An intelligent man like Alan Shatter continues to call out Hamas (‘Hamas cannot be allowed form part
of any resolution’,
, November 6). Israel will continue to be less safe due to the actions of Israel – surely he can see this?

All people from that area are semitic, so to call Palestinians antisemitic is ridiculous. It is sad to see anyone defending what we are witnessing. Ireland must continue to be strong and support what is right at this time.
If Israel and the US punish us in the future, so be it.
Elon Musk has warned that artificial intelligence (AI) represents one of the biggest threats to humanity.

Looking at my TV screen and seeing the evidence that the evolution of our species has left us no better able to resolve our differences than we were when we hit each other with clubs, it seems obvious that humans are the greatest threat to humanity.
Our innate intelligence is clearly sadly lacking. Can AI really be any worse?
The recent murderous attack by Hamas terrorists on defenceless Israeli citizens was and is rightly to be condemned by everyone.
Now the open-air prison that was and is Gaza is in danger before the eyes of the world of being turned into a cemetery.
The supine attitude of Western leaders to this appalling tragedy in the Middle East is shameful. Like Pope Francis, they should be demanding an end to the slaughter.
Whether you agree or disagree with Leo Varadkar’s comment on Israel and revenge, his intervention serves the valuable purpose of keeping the debate open.
The sad truth is that both sides are victims and both are wrong in the extremity of their response.

One thinks of the philosopher Hegel’s recognition that, in the dramatic genre of tragedy, the conflict is not always a simple case of good versus evil, but rather a clash between two perspectives, both of which have a claim on our sympathy.

Those who oppose such conflicts, whether recently in Northern Ireland or currently in the Middle East, might do well to recall the insight into mutual hostility found in the radical and original myth-making of the late 18th-century English poet, William Blake.

Part of his mythic schema involves an endless cycle of conflict between the figures Urizen (representing repressive Reason or authority) and Orc (associated with revolution and radically opposed to restraint or limitation ).

An endless and increasingly monstrous dialectic emerges: the more Urizen seeks to impose his authority on Orc, the more violent Orc becomes; and the more violent Orc becomes, the more vindictive Urizen’s response. And so on.
One way of escaping entrapment in this vicious cycle would entail recourse to an alternative to “dialectic”, which sounds similar but has wholly other connotations: that is, “dialogue”.

If Antony Blinken is the possible overseer of such a process, one must hope his habitually urbane way of proceeding proves a trustworthy indication of a genuine intelligence capable of seeing things in the round.

It has been very disturbing seeing images of terrified and dead Palestinian children. The October 7 murders of innocent Israelis was equally appalling, but the Israeli response is nothing short of barbaric. Israel could have gone about this differently instead of creating future generations of hateful enemies.
A recent letter writer suggested looking outside Ireland for priests to supplement the dwindling numbers left to serve the needs of Catholics.
I suggest instead that the church looks to the 51pc of the population who reside here, but who are excluded from the priesthood for one reason and one reason only – women.
What reason is there to exclude women from becoming priests, other than their being women?
Could it be that the men running the Catholic Church don’t like women?

Perhaps if more women had been priests and bishops, some of the abuses would not have happened and the church would not be losing such massive support among the Irish populace as a result of those abuses and the attitudes of those who protected the offenders.
If an organisation wants to survive, it needs to move with the times. The Catholic Church is no different. Let women become priests and solve the problem of dwindling vocations.

title: Editorial: Sympathy for Israel will run dry unless it can work for peace
body: Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Photo: Reuters

The only security for any people is to be found through the control of force, rather than the use of force, wrote US peace advocate Norman Cousins. Efforts to imprint just such a message on the mind of Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu have come to naught, despite ever more desperate appeals.

UN secretary general António Guterres issued a renewed impassioned plea for a cessation to the attacks in Gaza, as he revealed 89 employees of the UN agency, aiding Palestinian refugees, had been killed in Gaza in the past month. That is more “than in any comparable period in the history of our organisation,” he said.
Yet no matter how overt or uncompromising international condemnation has been, Mr Netanyahu remains implacable, rejecting calls for a ceasefire.
He has said he may consider “tactical little pauses” in fighting, to allow the entry of aid or the exit of hostages. But he also said he intends to take security control of Gaza indefinitely.
With such a scenario in mind, hopes of bringing any short-term end to hostilities seem remote.

But a month since the Hamas atrocity, the soaring death tolls are causing mounting concern in capitals around the world. Speaking in the Dáil, Taoiseach Leo Varadkar said: “I know prime minister Netanyahu promised ‘mighty vengeance’, his words not mine, ‘mighty vengeance’. But that is valid I think when it comes to Hamas, the terrorists who killed those 1,400 people in Israel, it’s not when it comes to Palestinian civilians.”

And as Mr Guterres also said: “The nightmare in Gaza is more than a humanitarian crisis. It is a crisis of humanity.” Unfortunately, the missiles raining down on the stricken territory do not discriminate, with hospitals, schools and even an ambulance all struck.
Outrage at the ceaseless scenes of mourning and despair is now provoking demands for the expulsion of Israeli ambassadors from countries.

But as Mr Varadkar said, Ireland would “disempower” itself from having influence if it expelled the Israeli ambassador. Tánaiste Micheál Martin was just as adamant that we need to keep all channels open.

“I think there needs to be more reflection in public discourse around the importance of diplomacy, what it exists for. It exists to maintain access when you need it to help your citizens. It enables dialogue on issues that you’re concerned about. Particularly in times of conflict and war, it’s the most fundamental and basic of channels,” Mr Martin said.

Jordan’s foreign minister Ayman Safadi has said the best self-defence long term for Israel, is to work for peace. Yet, as stated earlier, with temperatures running high, and violence likely to intensify with IDF now in the heart of Gaza city, hopes of any path to peace seem highly improbable.
Israel knows there is a risk of draining valuable reservoirs of sympathy, just as it must also understand shock and awe tactics exclusively will never yield a lasting solution.

title: Israel-Gaza conflict ‘will not diminish G7’s support for Ukraine’
body: Vows of ‘enduring support’ for Kyiv as foreign ministers meet in Tokyo
A man visits a makeshift memorial featuring Ukrainian flags bearing the names of fallen service members at Kyiv’s Independence Square. Photo: Reuters

G7 support for Ukraine in its war with Russia will not be affected by the intensifying Middle East conflict, Japan said yesterday as the group’s foreign ministers prepared to hold virtual talks with Kyiv during a meeting in Tokyo.

The Group of Seven (G7) wealthy nations – Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States – as well as the European Union, are meeting in Tokyo to discuss issues including Russia’s war in Ukraine and the Israel-Gaza crisis.

title: Schindler’s List author Thomas Keneally: ‘If I were Israeli, I would think Israel’s taking the wrong course’
body: An expert chronicler of historical injustice, the Australian talks about his new novel about the controversial Irish rebel John Mitchel and his feelings about the war in Gaza
Astute thinker: Thomas Keneally. Photo: Simone Padovani via Getty Images
Tom Keneally has nothing but good things to say about the Irish rugby team following their exit from the World Cup.

“Congratulations on how well you went,” he booms down the line from his home Sydney. “I was watching you blokes last winter and by God... I’m a rugby league lunatic, and I reckon Andy Farrell taught them to play a bit of rugby league. Your forwards were so bloody competent, and the backline rang like a bell.”

title: Israeli forces ‘in heart of Gaza City’ say Hamas leader is isolated in a bunker
body: Benjamin Netanyahu says Israel will assume ‘overall security responsibility’ for Gaza
A woman on the road south holds-up a makeshift white flag. Photo: AP

Israel said yesterday that its forces were operating deep in Gaza City in their battle to wipe out Hamas in the Palestinian enclave, and that the Islamist militant group’s leader was trapped inside a bunker.

Gaza residents said earlier that Israeli tanks were positioned on the outskirts of Gaza City, Hamas’ stronghold in the north of the territory – and home to about a third of its 2.3 million people – before the hostilities.

title: Sinn Féin TD Chris Andrews sues newspaper and journalist over coverage of his response to deadly Hamas attack
body: Sinn Féin TD Chris Andrews
A Sinn Féin TD is suing a newspaper and a journalist over coverage of his response to the Hamas attack on Israel on October 7.
The party’s Dublin Bay South TD Chris Andrews has initiated legal action over reporting of a comment he made the day after the attack.
Mr Andrews is the latest in a string of Sinn Féin figures to take legal actions against media organisations.

Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald was nominated for a ‘bully of the year’ award by an organisation that campaigns against powerful individuals using defamation laws to silence critics, known as SLAPPS – Strategic Lawsuits Against Public Participation.

Ms McDonald’s defamation case against RTÉ, related to Provisional IRA rape victim Máiría Cahill, has been flagged with the Council of Europe as a potential threat to media freedom by the Index on Censorship.

Mr Andrews’ case arose after Hamas gunmen launched an unprecedented assault on Israel from the Gaza Strip, killing more than 1,400 people and taking more than 200 hostages. Since then, Israel has declared war and has been carrying out strikes on Gaza in response, killing more than 10,000 people, according to the Hamas-run health ministry.

European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen issued a statement on social media saying: “I unequivocally condemn the attack carried out by Hamas terrorists against Israel. It is terrorism in its most despicable form. Israel has the right to defend itself against such heinous attacks.”

The next day, Mr Andrews responded to that statement with his own comment on the social media site X, formerly Twitter: “It seems that according to the #EU and #Ireland only Palestine has no right to defend itself against murder, torture and Apartheid…#Palestine #GazaUnderAttack #gaza.”
His comment was accompanied by a photo of an explosion, which appears to be caused by an Israeli rocket fired at a building in Gaza.

We need your consent to load this Social Media content. We use a number of different Social Media outlets to manage extra content that can set cookies on your device and collect data about your activity.
Mr Andrews is now taking a case over the coverage of his statement in
in an article a week later.

The Sinn Féin TD is represented by Dublin solicitors Sheridan Fitzgerald. The solicitors confirmed the case related to tweets in response to Ms von der Leyen. Mr Andrews’ legal representatives issued a solicitor’s letter to
following publication of the story.
A summons was issued by Mr Andrews against The Irish Times Designated Activity Company yesterday. Mr Andrews is also suing
political correspondent Harry McGee.
Mr Andrews and Sinn Féin have not responded to requests for comment.
is understood to be planning to vigorously defend the legal action.
Mr Andrews has served as a Sinn Féin TD the 2020 general election. He is currently the party’s spokesperson on sport. Previously, he was a Fianna Fáil TD from 2007 to 2011.

His family has a strong Fianna Fáil tradition. His late father, Niall Andrews, was a Fianna Fáil TD and MEP. His uncle David Andrews was a Fianna Fáil TD and foreign affairs minister during the Good Friday Agreement negotiations.

Niall and David’s father, Todd Andrews, was a prominent republican in the War of Independence and Civil War was also involved in Fianna Fáil’s early days, although he never ran for office. He was a former chairman of RTÉ and CIE and was also the first managing director of Bord na Móna.
Fianna Fáil MEP Barry Andrews is a cousin of Chris Andrews, as are former
presenter Ryan Tubridy and comedian David McSavage.
Chris Andrews is a member of the Oireachtas Media Committee, but has recused himself from meeting on RTÉ’s payments scandal, due to his relationship with Mr Tubridy.
His relationship with Fianna Fáil soured after he created a phantom Twitter account to criticise leader Micheál Martin and other senior figures sometime after losing his seat in 2011.

Mr Andrews was unveiled as the phantom tweeter by Eddy Carroll, the husband of senior party figure Kathryn Byrne. He had sent over 300 tweets which were highly critical of a number of figures within Fianna Fáil. Mr Carroll used photo and video surveillance to unmask Mr Andrews, who went to ground afterwards.

He joined Sinn Féin in 2013, before running for the party in the 2014 local elections. His ties with Sinn Féin arose from his involvement in campaigning for Palestine. Mr Andrews has been involved in Gaza Action Ireland for many years and has worked with the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights in Gaza city.

title: Arnold Schwarzenegger says love will always conquer hatred amid Israel-Hamas war
body: Arnold Schwarzenegger (Evan Agostini/AP/PA)
Hollywood star Arnold Schwarzenegger said “love in the end always wins” as he collected an award of courage for his long-term advocacy against antisemitism and bigotry.

The Terminator actor, 76, made the comments during the Holocaust Museum’s annual gala in Los Angeles, in which host Melissa Rivers told the audience “October 7 was the deadliest massacre of Jews since the Holocaust” amid the Israel-Hamas war.
Schwarzenegger, the son of a Nazi soldier, said “we have to speak out” from the hatred online – in a nod to the attacks in Israel and Palestine.

“The more we speak out about that issue, the better it is, so every day you have to talk about it… over and over again because we cannot let them get away with these lies and with this hatred”, he said.
“We have to talk to them and talk them down and let them know that the only way to go is through love and not with hatred.
“Hatred will never ever win, love in the end always wins.”
Arnold Schwarzenegger collected an award of courage (Isabel Infantes/PA)

Oscar-nominated film producer Mike Medavoy, who worked with Schwarzenegger on four films including The Terminator during his career, presented the actor with the award cut from cured oak wood in a nod to his bodybuilding nickname The Austrian Oak.
A dozen Second World War Holocaust survivors attended the ceremony, including Joseph Alexander, who turns 101 this month.
Mr Alexander placed a flame in a miner’s lamp in Schwarzenegger’s honour on stage, which was then transported by police escort to the Holocaust Museum in Los Angeles.
The former governor of California also spoke about visiting the site of the Auschwitz Nazi death camp (Ian West/PA)

During his speech, Schwarzenegger said: “For me to be here today is unbelievable because as you can imagine when you have been Mr Universe five times, Mr World, Mr International…you get a lot of trophies for your muscles – but this is a trophy for my heart.”
The actor also said he has always felt compelled to advocate for equality because “I come from a country who’s known to be a big part in the Second World War and have the most vicious Nazis”.
He continued: “I thought it was important to go out and let people know the next generation doesn’t have to be the same, that the next generation can change.”
The former governor of California also spoke about visiting the site of the Auschwitz Nazi death camp.
“It was amazing to be there and see that first hand,” he said.
“I wrote in the book I’ll be back because I will be back there with a whole bunch of Hollywood celebrities so they can see what went on there and put the spotlight on this issue.”

title: Kerry Sinn Féin councillor condemns Israeli strikes on Gaza and calls for boycott of Israeli goods
body: Tralee councillor issues emergency motion criticising Israel for heavy-handed response since Hamas attacks of October 7
Palestinians mourning in Gaza.
Sinn Féin Councillor Deirdre Ferris tabled an emergency motion at Monday’s Tralee Municipal District meeting condemning Israel and calling for a boycott of Israeli goods.

She asked members of Tralee MD, which is twinned with the Palestinian town of Beit Sahour in the West Bank, to condemn unreservedly the continued and indiscriminate killing of innocent civilians in the Gaza Strip through Israel’s relentless bombing.
Cllr Ferris supported calls for a ceasefire and said dialogue is the only viable solution to the conflict, while classifying the actions of Israel as the ‘slaughter’ of innocent civilians.
She also stressed that no one could condone the acts of Hamas on October 7, a day when Hamas mercilessly killed 1,400 innocent Israelis, taking hundreds more hostage.

“But in the four weeks since Israel started their bombardment of Gaza in retaliation, nearly 13,000 people are dead, thousands more are injured and missing under the rubble of what was once Gaza,” Cllr Ferris said.
She described Israel’s response as ‘disproportionate and unacceptable’ while condemning air strikes against hospitals, homes, refugee camps, and ambulances.

Cllr Ferris said Israel denies Palestinians their fundamental human rights by occupying Palestinian lands and systematically targeting people while setting up illegal settlements against international law.

“No one and nowhere is safe in Gaza, and nowhere is off limits to Israeli forces. Two and a half million people are currently cramped into an area the equivalent in size to the landmass of the Dingle Peninsula. There is absolutely nowhere for them to hide,” she said.
Cllr Ferris commended Ireland’s decision in the 1980s to boycott goods from apartheid South Africa, a policy she now wants to see extended to Israel.
“I want to see Ireland continuing that precedent in ensuring that we start boycotting the likes of goods coming into this county and country from apartheid Israel,” she said.

“…I want the people in Palestine and the Israeli Ambassador to understand that we in Kerry stand with them [Palestinians], and that we support them and are grieving with them…we hope this motion will give them the strength to know that they are not alone in the world, and that the world does not stand with apartheid Israel,” Cllr Ferris said.
The motion was seconded by Sinn Féin councillor Cathal Foley, with councillors Terry O’Brien, Mikey Sheehy, Sam Locke, and Johnnie Wall also speaking out against Israeli actions in Gaza.

title: Letters: US president Joe Biden may have Irish roots but he does not share our affinity with the oppressed
body: US president Joe Biden. Photo: AP
Surely it is high time to re-examine our fawning relationship with the US “first citizen” Joe Biden, regardless of his local origins.

He, and his country, are, and have always been, Israel’s chief supporter on the international stage, and he is literally tripping over himself to express his unqualified backing for Israel’s indiscriminate assault on Gaza.
His Irish roots have become so diluted that he no longer shares our affinity with the oppressed, and our yearning for peace based on truth and justice.
Shame on him.
Minnie Mooney paints a bleak picture for young adults in this country in her article last weekend (‘Ireland has nothing to offer Gen Z and that is a scary prospect for so many of our young people’,
, November 4).
Édaein O’Connell in your newspaper has expressed similar sentiments about the level of emigration to places like Sydney among her peers.

Without hope, there is despair – and for a lot of young people, Ireland has little to offer with its high cost of living and virtually no chance to afford a home. As Minnie says, “We are leaving the country in droves, and when we are gone, the Government will have only itself to blame”. Indeed.

As small businesses all around Ireland close their doors this winter, not just to customers but also to hope, the bright, intelligent young people that Minnie speaks so eloquently about will just pack up their bags and emigrate.
It does not seem that long ago that we had a fresh, young, intelligent leader who offered so much hope to people of his generation.
After almost 14 years in power though, I doubt very much he and his party will be given another chance by Generation Z, assuming of course that the latter will still be here to cast their ballot.

It’s sad to see that a journalist of the calibre Sarah Carey feels the need to use the tiresome trope of the term “misogyny” (‘The power suit is a win-win that saves us hours and levels the field with men’,
, November 4).

The article’s thrust was about a level playing field between the sexes, and the “suit” worn by men being the definitive “leveller”. Be that as it may, I fail to see the need for the side-swipe use of “misogyny”.

If one of Ms Carey’s male colleagues were to use the term “misandry” regarding Irish women, would that cause a stir? But then, a suit-wearing male journalist, happy in his level playing field, probably wouldn’t feel the urge for such side-swiping. Perhaps it’s time to really level the field, concentrate on the topic to hand, and desist from sexist tropes once and for all.
Many questions and no answers describe the current situation in the Middle East. The dangerous rhetoric increases daily. Comparisons to past wars are being made to justify slaughter in Gaza.
The greatest difficulty to peace is indeed the past.
In the meantime, no one appears to be “watching” the present.
In particular one statement stood out at the weekend (“Israeli minister says Gazans can ‘go to Ireland or the desert’ as he says nuclear bomb also ‘a possibility’,” Irish Independent, November 6).

The factual words of Taoiseach Leo Varadkar and Tánaiste Micheál Martin have hit a sore spot with the hard-line Amihai Eliyahu. Recent days have also seen a visit to Israel in support of former Australian prime minister Scott Morrison, whose evangelical beliefs coincide with Jewish hardliners.​
The Cuban Missile Crisis took the world to the brink of nuclear war.

The captain of the sole USSR nuclear-armed submarine inserted his key to allow the button to be pushed. His co-officer obeyed and did likewise. It was the action ofHowever, a KGB political officer on board refused to use his key and instead ordered the captain to “head for home!”
There are no “political officers” among the Eliyahus of Israel: this is the greatest threat presently to us all.

It does not suit any nation to have a hot war, or an international recession at this point in time, because the financial ramifications would be far more severe and longer lasting than 1929. Now is the time for “caring” heads of state: not to try, rather, to fix the two-state solution of Israel and Palestine.

The cheapest new electricity tariff is from 11pm to 7am when most people are in bed. It encourages people to run dishwashers, tumble dryers and washing machines between these times due to the low cost.

However, the fire brigade and all fire safety authorities regularly warn, and rightly so, to unplug all appliances at night. I have not heard any mention of this anomaly in the media, yet it is peoples lives that are at risk.
I had a great weekend at An Oireachtas na Samhna in Killarney at the weekend.
The town knows how to host the throngs.
However, and this is an issue that’s now nationwide, Christmas marketing has started.
Most shops with their merry, merry jingle bells; most hotels bedecked with Christmas trees and bunting; a few with cribs until someone cribs about the crib.
But please press pause.
This is November, ancient
Samhain of the old Irish – the month and season that leave summer and autumn behind, allowing its greyness to spill over our souls and head, recalling those gone onwards, allowing time to reflect.
It’s not the launch pad for merry, merry Christmas.
It’s a time of reflection, of pausing.
By the time the first week of December comes, the innocence of Christmas will be flogged to death as the ratcheting noise and tills clang.
Can we actually pace ourselves? Must everything be party time and money-gouging 24/7?
What next?
Selling shillelaghs and shamrock on December 8?
Slow down. Christmas will come in its own time.

title: Tottenham winger Manor Solomon suspended from Instagram for pro-Israel posts
body: Manor Salomon in a Instagram post from the Israeli FA
Instagram has suspended the account of a Tottenham Hotspur player after he used it to show support for Israel.
Manor Solomon, who is currently injured, found out that his Instagram account was deactivated while in Israel after being given permission to travel back to his home country by Tottenham.
Spurs are working to have Solomon’s account restored as quickly as possible and are in contact with Meta, the company that owns Instagram, over the situation.
Israel international Solomon had been using his Instagram account to show support for Israel, but his account was this week suspended with none of his posts available to view.
It is believed that Instagram most likely reacted to a number of reports received over Solomon’s account and there is optimism that it will be restored with all the content made available again.
Tottenham have made representation to Meta to get Solomon’s Instagram account reactivated as quickly as possible and back their player’s insistence that he did not post any anti-Palestine material.
Representatives of Solomon also insist the winger did not share any anti-Palestine content and only criticised the Hamas attack while supporting Israelis who had been injured and died.
The Israeli Football Association hit out at Instagram by posting a picture of Solomon on the platform with his mouth taped over and a message that read:
A representative of Solomon said: “It’s ridiculous. He didn’t make any anti-Palestine posts, just support for his own country. It’s ridiculous. Instagram is ridiculous.”
It is understood that Solomon was given permission by Tottenham to travel to Israel this week for a family matter that neither the club nor his representatives have commented on.

Solomon has been offered support by Tottenham since the Hamas attack took place and is understood to be upset that his account was suspended while other footballers and celebrities have not received the same treatment for sharing their views on the Israel and Palestine conflict on social media.

title: Editorial: Slow progress on securing humanitarian ceasefire in Hamas-Israel conflict is costing lives
body: Palestinians evacuate the site of Israeli strikes on houses in Maghazi refugee camp in the central Gaza Strip yesterday. Photo: Reuters
A s the world recoils from the catastrophic death toll in Gaza, UN chiefs have declared: “Enough is enough.”
On average, a child is killed and two are injured every 10 minutes during the war, the UN relief agency for Palestinians said.

Meanwhile, the Hamas-run health ministry in Gaza claims Israeli attacks have now killed more than 10,000 Palestinians. The BBC recently provided sobering context to the extent of the carnage. It compared figures with those in Ukraine, where the UN says around 9,700 civilians have been killed since the full-scale Russian invasion 21 months ago.

Some of the Palestinian dead would have been part of Hamas. Even if that proportion is as high as 10pc – which is said to be unlikely – it would still mean that Israel has killed as many Palestinian civilians in just over a month as Russia has killed in Ukraine since February 2022.

“An entire population is besieged and under attack, denied access to the essentials for survival, bombed in their homes, shelters, hospitals and places of worship. This is unacceptable,” the UN chiefs said in a joint statement. “We need an immediate humanitarian ceasefire.”
It’s all the more regrettable, then, that the diplomatic whirlwind undertaken by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken did not yield better results.
Hamas’s culpability from the outset must be kept in mind. But Israel cannot be absolved from its responsibility for the indefensible number of Palestinian civilian deaths.

Global criticism for the severity of the indiscriminate bombardment, and the fact that the air, land and sea attacks lack an endgame, is growing. Mr Blinken has said the efforts to secure humanitarian pauses are a work in progress.

Unfortunately the pace of that progress is costing lives. As the world’s greatest superpower, the US needs to use maximum influence to persuade its ally to allow a pause for sufficient aid to get through.
Keeping a lid on the volcanic anger building in the Arab world before it explodes is becoming more problematic as days pass, and deaths mount alarmingly.
The Biden administration has said it is deeply distressed, but against such utter devastation, more might be expected than expressions of discomfort.
“Life’s most persistent and urgent question is, ‘What are you doing for others?’” said Martin Luther King.

It’s a pertinent question for those with influence and agency, and who might use it to ease the terrible suffering in the besieged territory. To date, Israel’s sole objective has been to wipe out Hamas.

But there is no guarantee the offensive will achieve this. Violent escalation and regional destabilisation of an already volatile zone has to be avoided. A solution will not be found solely through a hammer-and-anvil approach. Some respite is needed right now.
Looking ahead: it may be hard to visualise an end to the conflict, yet one must be envisaged. The purely eye-for-an-eye approach just perpetuates the darkness.

title: Sinn Féin snubs Israeli ambassador and diplomats despite pledge to ‘talk to everybody’
body: Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald had previously vowed that she would ‘talk to everybody’ in situations of conflict
Israeli ambassador’s position is ‘now untenable’, says Mary Lou McDonald
Sinn Féin has not met the Israeli ambassador or other diplomats, despite the party’s pledge to “meet and talk to everybody” in a conflict situation.
Israel’s embassy in Dublin has confirmed that Sinn Féin did not invite its ambassador to a briefing it held last week for diplomats from several Arab countries, including the Palestinian ambassador.
The Israeli ambassador was also not invited to a similar briefing which the party held in 2018 and Sinn Féin have not held any other meetings with its diplomats, the embassy said.
‘Sinn Féin will not be inviting the Israeli ambassador to our ard fheis’
A spokesperson for the Israeli Embassy said the failure to invite ambassador Dana Erlich is “quite telling” of Sinn Féin’s position on the ongoing conflict in the region.
“While Israel is a democratic state within the Middle East, the ambassador of Israel was not invited by Sinn Féin to this meeting with ambassadors of several Middle East and North Africa countries.

“To exclude Israel from such a forum is quite telling of Sinn Féin’s position on the conflict and suggests that it only seeks to isolate Israel, rather than offer a forum for constructive engagement.”
Sinn Féin leader Mary Lou McDonald had previously vowed that she would “talk to everybody” in situations of conflict.
She told RTÉ’s
two days after the October 7 attack that she had met representatives of Hamas previously and added: “I have been to the West Bank and I have met everybody. That’s the correct way to approach this.

“We should know in Ireland, if you are serious about achieving a ceasefire, which is necessary, a path to peace and a respect for international law, in a conflict situation, you meet and talk to everybody. That is the only way that you can find a pathway forward.”
Sinn Féin foreign affairs spokesperson Matt Carthy previously said the party “will never rule out meeting or talking to anybody”.
The party did not respond to queries why it had not invited the Israeli ambassador or diplomats to briefings or meetings.
Ms McDonald last week said the position of Ms Erlich was no longer tenable.

However both Taoiseach Leo Varadkar and Tánaiste Micheál Martin have said that the Israeli ambassador is needed in Ireland, in order to keep lines of communication open between Ireland and the Irish citizens in Israel and Gaza.
Despite Fianna Fáil having both the Israeli and Palestinian ambassadors at its ard fheis, Mr Carthy said Ms Erlich will not be invited to the Sinn Féin ard fheis in Athlone this weekend.

“Sinn Féin will not be inviting the Israeli ambassador to our ard fheis as we do not believe it is appropriate for any political party to offer a civic welcome to a representative of a government that is engaged in a ferocious military offensive against a civilian population and that is breaking international law by targeting civilians, destroying civilian infrastructure, forcing mass population displacement and cutting off vital supplies of water, food, medicines and fuel.
“Neither have we invited the Russian ambassador – due to that state’s illegal invasion of, and ongoing aggression against Ukraine, in breach of international law.”
