title: Expelling Israeli ambassador could hamper efforts to secure release of hostage Emily Hand, Taoiseach tells Dáil
body: Leo Varadkar says Government doing its 'best' to get around 40 Irish citizens out of Gaza
Ireland would "disempower" itself from having influence on the Israel-Hamas conflict if it expelled the Israeli ambassador in Dublin, the Taoiseach has warned.
Leo Varadkar said calls from opposition politicians, including Sinn Féin, for ambassador Dana Erlich's diplomatic credentials to be revoked did not represent a "common sense approach".

Mr Varadkar claimed such a move would hamper efforts to secure the release of Israeli-Irish girl Emily Hand, who is believed to be a hostage of Hamas in Gaza, and would also make it harder for Ireland to secure the safe passage of 35-40 Irish passport holders out of the enclave via the Rafah crossing to Egypt.

His comments came as People Before Profit TD Paul Murphy claimed Israel is refusing to allow Irish citizens leave war-torn Gaza in “retaliation” for the Government voting in favour of a United Nations motion calling for a ceasefire.
His party has announced they will be tabling a motion seeking to expel the Israeli Ambassador to Ireland, Dana Erlich, on November 22.
Speaking about the conflict in the Dáil, the Taoiseach said he also has "enormous fears" that the violence in the Middle East could escalate and widen.
Asked about the prospect of EU action against the Israelis, Mr Varadkar made clear the EU is "nowhere near" moving to suspending its trade deal with Israel.
"On the matter of the Israeli ambassador, it's not the Government's intention to expel the Israeli ambassador and that is for very good reasons," he said.

"Even countries at war have ambassadors. We have not expelled the Russian ambassador and I don't think anyone in the house is as supportive of Ukraine as I've been, in meaningful ways, not just in words.

"We have a situation now where we have about 40 Irish citizens in Gaza, and we want them to be able to leave if they want to leave. And we have an Irish citizen (Emily Hand) who may be held hostage in Gaza by Hamas, and we wanted to get her out.

"We also, at some point, want to be able to talk about peace and reconciliation and an end to this conflict. And when you expel an ambassador you disempower yourself. You cut off links. You can't talk anymore. You have to rebuild those links. I can understand it as an emotional reaction, but it's not a common sense approach in my view, and it's not the way things get done in international affairs."

Earlier, Paul Murphy TD dismissed comments from Tánaiste Micheál Martin who said expelling the ambassador would break diplomatic links with Israel and hinder efforts to release Irish citizens from Gaza.
“We should be clear that what is happening right now, with diplomatic links, is that Israel is holding Irish citizens hostage in Gaza,” Mr Murphy told a press conference in Leinster House.
“Israel is refusing to allow Irish citizens and Brazilian citizens to leave Gaza in what very much appears to be retaliation for votes at the UN.

“If you look at those countries whose citizens are allowed to leave, they're those countries that voted with Israel against a ceasefire or abstained, and for Ireland and Brazil who voted in favour of a ceasefire; we're being punished.
“So already this idea of treating Israel nicely is not working and Irish citizens are being punished for the words of criticism that the Irish government has made,” he added.
Mr Murphy said a number of countries have broken diplomatic ties with Israel due to the on going war in Gaza. This includes Columbia, Bolivia, Chile and South Africa.
“We think it actually would have a big impact on the world stage if a European country was to take this step and to say we're going to expel the Israeli ambassador,” he added.
His party colleague Richard Boyd Barrett accused Israel of engaging in “ethnic cleansing” in the region and said financial sanctions should be imposed on the country.

“Our personal view is that there should be a full boycott, sanctions, comprehensive sanctions and divestment from Israel similar to the campaign of boycott and sanctions that was imposed on apartheid South Africa,” he said.
The Dáil also heard calls for a curtailing of trade between the EU and Israel.

Social Democrats TD Holly Cairns said trade between the EU and Israel is governed by the EU-Israel Association Agreement, which has a human rights clause, meaning either side can suspend the agreement “in response to serious breaches of human rights”.
Ms Cairns told the Taoiseach that if Israel’s “destruction of Gaza isn’t appropriate to trigger that clause now, then nothing ever will".
The party leader said Israel has a right to defend itself but said what is happening is “not a defence, it is an annihilation”.
The UN Security Council is “toothless”, the UN General Assembly is “powerless” and the UN is “rudderless”, she told the Dáil.
“The scale of the devastation is unprecedented. Nowhere is safe,” she said.
Taoiseach Leo Varadkar said Israel has a right to defend itself but must abide by international law.
He said Ireland “can’t and should not act alone” on EU trade deals.

“The truth is, there is a very significant divergence of opinion within the EU. While we were able to agree a common statement in Brussels last week, and we all stand by that, the truth is, there are very different views.”
He called for a humanitarian ceasefire and the release of hostages as well as humanitarian aid being let in.

Meanwhile, Sinn Féin TD Eoin Ó Broin said his party suddenly changed their decision to call for the Israeli ambassador to be expelled after Mary Lou McDonald attended a meeting in Belfast on the issue.

Mr Ó Broin said some party activists have a “strong view” on the conflict but said the decision to change Ms McDonald’s public stance came after a meeting of Oireachtas and Assembly members along with other Sinn Féin members in the North.

Ms McDonald was defending Sinn Féin’s position not to call for the ambassador to be expelled on social media the day before Sinn Féin published a statement in her name saying Ms Elrich’s position is untenable.

title: Editorial: We should look to example of John Hume and see that diplomacy isn’t always pleasant – but it works
body: 1998 Nobel Peace Prize winner John Hume. Photo: Getty

A new book on John Hume seeks to examine what motivated the peacemaker to put everything on the line and what sustained him through the dark days when every step forward seemed to be marred by a bigger and bloodier step back.
Stephen Walker’s

seeks to paint a personal picture of the architect of the Good Friday Agreement, which brought peace to this island. Hume thankfully endured and convinced the Provisional IRA to end its campaign of terror, violence and murder.

He was often harshly criticised for his stance of talking to those responsible for horrific atrocities, but his prevailing commitment to human rights and implacable opposition to violence meant his moral courage won through. Hume espoused the view that you’re not endorsing a position by keeping lines of communication open, and only dialogue can ultimately prevail. It’s a textbook case of diplomacy winning out.

The Hume doctrine should serve as a shining example of how to tackle any dispute. It’s strange that those who were brought in from the cold by his bravery now believe that not talking is the best course of action.

We live in troubled times at the moment with complex conflicts requiring more than simplistic soundbites. The era of social media doesn’t lend itself to deliberation of multi-faceted arguments. The populist quote of less than 180 characters prevails.

But if a halt is to be made to the bloodletting in Israel and Gaza, then mature discussion will be required and difficult issues will need to be grappled. Though a small country, Ireland does have a respected voice in international affairs and does not shirk its responsibilities in speaking the truth.

Articulating Irish foreign policy, Foreign Affairs Minister Micheál Martin says he believes Israel has broken international humanitarian law in its response to the Hamas attack of October 7. This does not take away from his condemnation of the assault by Hamas. Nuance is important.

The Tánaiste has also articulated why he believes the Israeli ambassador should not be expelled from Ireland. Cutting diplomatic ties will achieve nothing other than cutting out communication channels at a time when they are most important. Breaking off diplomatic relations and expelling the ambassador certainly won’t help the 35 Irish citizens the Government is trying to get out of Gaza.

Maintaining diplomatic relations doesn’t stop the Government from expressing a strong position. In fact, it makes it all the more valid as it is being articulated to a representative of the State whose actions are being criticised. Israel’s ambassador has been left in no doubt of Ireland’s position.

Expelling an ambassador, of whatever country, might make the headlines, but what do you do the next day when you seek to bring about a resolution? Cheap soundbites don’t resolve conflicts. Diplomacy isn’t always pleasant – but it is always essential.

title: Letters: Their golden oldies have lit up my life, and the Fab Four are still on song years later
body: Paul McCartney, George Harrison, Ringo Starr and John Lennon, at a recording studio in London (PA)

The Beatles were always far ahead of their time as they set the template for what could be achieved without limits. Their use of orchestras and instruments such as the sitar expanded the range of music all over the world.
How incredible it is for the remaining members of the group Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr (81 and 83 respectively) to bring us a new single,
, 53 years after they split up. The video is amazing as you see the Beatles; including John and George; perform, arrive for a tour of America and generally mess about.
I only became interested in The Beatles when I stumbled across a compilation album called
and from that moment on I became hooked. One summer I spent most of my wages from Dunnes buying up all the Beatles albums.
To this day, as my kids will vouch, at least 90pc of the music played in my car is The Fab Four.
Having enjoyed Sarah Carey’s article (‘The power suit is a win-win that saves us hours and levels the field with men’,
, November 4) on the power suit immensely, I could almost feel myself wearing such a suit, so good was her description.
I would nevertheless like to disagree with her statement about “the innate misogyny of Irish men”.
I note she does not say “all” Irish men. But just to say, in my life I have been very fortunate not to have experienced such misogyny.
I had a very broad-minded father (born in 1914), also a brother, husband and son who have never treated me or any woman  other than as equals.
It is not often that I do this, but I needed to compliment the
on Ellen Coyne’s article about the recently moderated event by Pat Kenny on RTÉ.

Ellen really struck a chord with me when she said: “Some of us want a revolution, while others want a dinner party.” The whole article was well written and without a doubt, reflects the majority view in Ireland.
The
newspaper was our family paper; the only paper we purchased every day, but I stopped buying it a number of years ago.
After Ellen’s article, I may well start a subscription service and/or start buying the paper regularly again.
I was left very uneasy reading your review of Jane Ohlmeyer’s book. (“British Empire lecturer Jane Ohlmeyer: ‘Ireland was the template for what happened in Israel and Palestine’”,
, November 4)
The impression given is that the Irish were somehow willing participants in the activities of the British Empire, claiming there was “a strong Irish presence in imperial rule”.

The fact is that the Irish were a conquered people. The 1542 “Crown of Ireland Act” established the Kingdom of Ireland, to be ruled by Henry VIII and his successors, with the core objective being to anglicise Ireland through a combination of conquest, coercion and colonisation.
Under this Act, the Irish were subjugated and even barred from joining an army.

This ban was lifted only in the 1800s to facilitate the expansionist ambitions of the British ruling class and it is well understood that Irish recruitment was driven by poverty and deprivation – a situation that was engineered to achieve that end. This scenario was replicated in other countries after they, too, were colonised.
The idea that the Irish people were willing participants in the brutal and savage campaigns of conquest undertaken by the British must be challenged at every turn.

While Ms Ohlmeyer acknowledges that the Irish were “rank-and-file troops” under the command of British officers, she seems not to make clear that the British Empire was under the sole command of the British establishment. They and they alone, must take full responsibility for it.

Let us, for a moment, pretend that no adults have died in Gaza because of the ongoing Israeli assault. Let us reduce the death toll to the children killed. Just the children. So what are we left with?

According to the latest figures, some 3,900 children – babies, little kids, teenagers – have been killed by Israeli forces in the past few weeks. They have died in the most awful of circumstances. Many more have been maimed.
In what world is this acceptable? We are witnessing a massacre that will be long remembered in the Middle East.
Israel is clearly engaged in the collective punishment of a civilian population, enabled by the US, the UK and several EU countries.

This is a flagrant breach of international humanitarian law. The Irish Government has called for a ceasefire but, bizarrely, remains worried about upsetting Israel and by extension, presumably, the US. Diplomatic language is best, we are told. Meanwhile, the death toll continues to rise.
The time for soft words and diplomacy is long over. Israel must be told to stop immediately. And Ireland needs to put itself firmly on the side of Palestinian human rights and political freedom.

Boris Johnson’s bungled handling of the pandemic is well known. However, the disclosures emerging from the  excruciating Covid inquiry demonstrate that his management of this emergency was much worse than was previously thought. It reveals an administration that was terrifyingly incompetent and dysfunctional.

He is said to have procrastinated and vacillated – taking advice from multiple often conflicting sources and frequently changing his mind – lacking focus or a proper medical understanding of the lethal pathology of the coronavirus.
This ignorance was also displayed by many others within his cabinet.

It is essential lessons are learned from this inquiry in view of the fact that it is predicted that pandemics will be more common in the future due to the impact of climate change and deforestation. ​

title: Ivana Bacik: If this war isn’t stopped now, the whole of the Middle East will sink into an even more terrible abyss of violence
body: People mourn as they collect the bodies of Palestinians killed in Israeli air raids on November 5 in Khan Yunis, Gaza. Photo by Ahmad Hasaballah/Getty Images
The case for an immediate ceasefire in Gaza is compelling. It becomes clearer by the hour, as the horrific death toll mounts.
It becomes clearer as we bear witness to the devastation unleashed by the Israeli state upon this small besieged enclave.

title: Alan Shatter: Hamas cannot be allowed form part of any resolution
body: Smoke rises amid damaged buildings in the Gaza Strip, as seen from Israel's border with Gaza in southern Israel. Photo: Reuters

Hamas is an evil antisemitic death cult and an EU-designated terrorist organisation no different to Islamic State (IS) and Al Qa’ida. It is not, as depicted by some marching on Dublin’s streets, simply a resistance movement fighting for the freedom of Palestinians.

In 2014 Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh told a crowd in Gaza “we are a people who value death, just like our enemies value life”. Hamas leaders like to celebrate the “martyrdom” of their dead, but those living in luxury in Doha are less enthusiastic about achieving their own martyrdom.

title: Horse-drawn hearse delivers children’s shoes to Israeli, British and US embassies to represent lives lost in Gaza conflict
body:
A horse-drawn hearse containing a real wooden coffin filled with children’s shoes to represent young lives lost in Gaza since the conflict began
Picture: Stephen Collins/Collins Photos
A horse-drawn hearse delivered children’s shoes to the Israeli, British and US embassies and to the Irish European Union HQ today as protesters called for an urgent ceasefire in Gaza.

Hundreds of protesters in Dublin city followed a hearse, carrying children’s shoes, in a symbolic protest to represent the number of children who have died in almost a month-long Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) bombardment and current ground assault on the 41km long Gaza enclave since October 7.

title: Israeli strikes ‘kill 21 members of one family’; US secretary of state Blinken in surprise meeting with Palestinian leader Abbas
body: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken meets with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas, at the Muqata in Ramallah in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Photo: Reuters

A spokesman for the health ministry in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip said on Sunday that Israeli military had struck a refugee camp overnight, killing at least 40 people, as calls by the Arab world for a ceasefire were rejected by the United States and Israel.
In a separate attack, 21 Palestinians from one family, including women and children, were killed in Israeli strikes targeting Gaza overnight, the health ministry said.

title: Pro-Palestine activists occupy Department of Transport in Dublin demanding no weapons for Israel pass through Shannon Airport
body: The Dublin for Gaza protesters at the offices of the Department of Transport
Pro-Palestine protesters Dublin For Gaza are this morning occupying the Department of Transport Offices in Dublin.
They are calling on Minister Eamon Ryan to “stand with the Palestinian people by halting any transportation of weapons bound for Israel through Shannon Airport”.

Dublin For Gaza spokesperson Rosie Leonard said: “US President Joe Biden is pledging military aid and weapons to the Israeli state - we call on the Department to ensure that Ireland plays no part in transporting these weapons of destruction to Israel”.

The group recently occupied the European Commission offices in Dublin in protest of Ursula von der Leyen’s visit to Israel last month, for which she drew condemnation from European states who said she was speaking without a European Union mandate.

"Shannon Airport is used as a stopover for the US military, using civilian airlines to transport US troops and weapons. The airlines chartered by the US military must receive an exemption from the Minister of Transport allowing them to transport weapons through our airports,” the group said.
“According to the government's figures, over 500 such exemptions have been made by the department this year so far.

"The people of Ireland are united in our humanity and abhor the depraved actions of the Israeli state - we call on Minister Ryan to stop granting exemptions immediately and ensure that our airports are not used to transport weapons and death machines to Israel, the group said in a statement explaining their occupation of the offices this morning.”
The group are demanding to speak to Minister Ryan and are calling for the minister to pledge that no weapons destined for Israel pass through Shannon.

The Co Clare airport became the focus of anti-war protests following the US invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq after 9/11, with tens of thousands of US troops stopping off there. There were also accusations at the time that detainees swept up in the months and years after the World Trade Center attacks had passed through the airport in so-called ‘extraordinary rendition’ journeys on their way to detention centres in Guantanamo Bay and elsewhere for interrogation and torture.
The Department of Transport has been contacted by the
for comment.

title: Sunday Independent/Ireland Thinks poll: Israel’s response to Hamas attacks is ‘disproportionately severe’
body: Palestinians react following a strike at a UN-run school in the Jabalia refugee camp in the northern Gaza Strip yesterday. Photo: Anas al-Shareef/Reuters
Israel’s response to the Hamas attack has been disproportionately severe and there is overwhelming support for an immediate ceasefire in the Middle East war, according to a
/Ireland Thinks opinion poll.
In the first assessment of public opinion here since the October 7 attack, a comfortable majority (65pc) also believes Hamas should be officially proscribed as a terrorist organisation by Ireland.

title: ‘What threat do children cause Israelis?’: Palestinian ambassador to Ireland tells of pain at Gaza bombardment, but does not condemn Hamas attacks
body: Dr Jilan Wahba Abdalmajid lost seven members of her family in Gaza bombings
Palestinian Ambassador to Ireland Dr. Jilan Abdalmajid says seven of her relatives have died in Israeli bombardment as she labels conflict "genocide".
“We’re living in a world where the people are on one side and their governments are on a different side,” says the Palestinian ambassador to Ireland.
Why is it, asks Dr Jilan Wahba Abdalmajid, that there are “protests around the world supporting the Palestinians” yet governments are doing “nothing” to stop the deaths and suffering in Gaza?

title: Eilis O’Hanlon: In a world full of horrors, why is it only ever Israel that excites deep loathing?
body: Israel’s war in Gaza is difficult to defend, but it has brought out those who simply hate Jews
Palestinians at the site of Israeli strikes on Maghazi, Gaza, last Friday. Photo: Reuters
Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s classic film

, which is showing this afternoon at the Light House cinema in Dublin, begins with RAF Squadron Leader Peter Carter, played by David Niven, returning from a “thousand-bomber raid” on a German city during World War II.
The film doesn’t identify the city, but the first ever thousand-bomber raid on a German civilian area actually occurred over Cologne in May 1942.

title: Nelofer Pazira-Fisk: Echoes of collective trauma call for humanity to be heard amid the terror in Gaza
body: People search through buildings that were destroyed during Israeli air raids in the southern Gaza Strip. Photo: Getty

“Somebody had to make a start. What we wrote and said is also believed by many others. They just don’t dare express themselves as we did.” These words were uttered by a 22-year-old German student, Sophie Scholl, as she was convicted of high treason for distributing anti-Nazi leaflets at Munich University in February 1943. That same month she was executed by guillotine.

Scholl was part of a non-violent resistance group called the White Rose. On the day she died, she said: “How can we expect righteousness to prevail when there is hardly anyone willing to give himself up individually to a righteous cause?”

title: Letters: Time for bishops to be humble and ask for priests from afar
body: There is a shortage of Irish priests to man dioceses here

Sir — On Sunday, October 29, a letter from Bishop Alphonsus Cullinan was read out before the 9am mass at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Tallow, Co Waterford. In it, several issues were presented for our attention. One was the lack of priests in the diocese.

In 1912, a young Cork priest, Reverend Edward Galvin (1882-1956), later a bishop, wrote from China to St Patrick’s College Maynooth asking it send priests, for the harvest was great but the labourers were almost non-existent. In time, many would heed the call and join Rev Galvin in China.
Contrary to popular belief, there is no shortage of priests for dioceses in Ireland; rather, there is an ever-increasing shortage of Irish priests to service them.

The time has come — in truth, it has been here for some time — for the bishops of Ireland to be humble enough to request priests from former mission lands such as in Asia, Africa and South America to come and help us.
Invite priests for a minimum of a two-year stay. Either share the already-allotted stipends for priests in the diocese or budget for these new helpers or shepherds.
This is something dioceses should have started tackling at least a decade or two ago.
I would encourage bishops to put out requests to their counterparts around the world to send, as soon as possible, labourers for the harvest here in Ireland.
It is now time for a new humility.
Sir — Our president, Michael D Higgins, is not afraid to speak out about injustice. However, like many of the left, he can sometimes be selective.
Prompted by an article in the

written by Professor Liam Kennedy, in which he detailed continued atrocities perpetrated against children by the IRA and loyalist gangs with the IRA showing the greater propensity to attack children, I wrote to Mr Higgins.

He was then a TD and was quite outspoken about the mistreatment of prisoners in Guantanamo Bay. I felt he was the right kind of person to approach on the subject of children being kneecapped and being beaten with crowbars and baseball bats.
So I wrote to him in November 2004, enclosing the

article. I pointed out that the attacks tended to diminish in periods leading up to various elections and, perhaps, raising the matter in the Dáil might embarrass Sinn Féin and he might, thereby, save a lot of children and others from savagery.

He responded on November 19 as follows: “Many thanks for your letter to me of November 9, and for the enclosed newspaper cutting. I was glad to receive same, and agree with the point which you raise in the letter. I will try to find a suitable way to draw attention to this issue.”
The attacks continued long after 2004 and no “suitable way” was found.

I’m sure Mr Higgins is a good man and many good men remain silent, but we, in Ireland, might contemplate taking the moral high ground in relation to Israel and Hamas when a large number on this island vote for a party that continues to honour those who attack children and who blew men, women and children to pieces.
Sir — I take issue with the front page of your newspaper of October 22 on two specific items.

First, you showed great disrespect to President Higgins by the use of his surname Higgins without the official title. The language used was also designed to sell copies, I guess, with the implication that the President had used “inflammatory” language the Israeli ambassador was not happy with.

President Higgins spoke the truth and was perfectly entitled to do so. I did hope that in your Letter from the Editor of October 29 you might address that disrespect shown to the President, but no, you spent most of your piece promoting the potential No 1 on the Christmas bestseller list. Priorities, I suppose.

My second issue was the front-page space you gave to the Israeli ambassador to spout her own inflammatory rhetoric. Implicit in her remarks was the belief that the entire world is against Israel. It wasn’t then; it may be now.

The entire civilised world was appalled at the actions of Hamas, and no one would deny Israel has a right to defend its people, but murdering thousands of civilians in a neighbouring state will certainly turn the civilised world against Israel.
As your excellent columnist Gene Kerrigan observed, the very existence of the Palestinian people is the real problem for the Israeli state.
Sir — I am sure Gene Kerrigan is genuinely appalled by the Hamas killing of Jewish civilians on October 7.

Thereafter, however, his political bias clouds his judgment, particularly in the soft ride and excuses for the left and its commentators (‘Stating the bloody obvious makes you an evil-doer’, October 29).

Whatever about Paddy Cosgrave, who at least tempered his comments to some degree, there have been innumerable examples of those on the left who haven’t been so circumspect. Numerous academics and left-wing activists have openly eulogised this rape and mass murder as an example of “practical decolonisation”.
I hope Mr Kerrigan doesn’t consider that to be “stating the obvious”.
Sir — The systematic bombing of Palestine and the indiscriminate murdering of civilians needs to be called out for what it is: a war crime.

Worse still, this situation is approved by the US and by the European Commission. Weak proposals for a temporary ceasefire are grossly inadequate, and Israel needs to be ordered to implement a permanent ceasefire with immediate effect or face the consequences of their actions.

I would like to ask what ratio of Palestinian deaths to Israeli deaths will be acceptable to Israel and its allies: 10:1, 20:1 or even 100:1? A very small proportion of these deaths are Hamas fighters — most are innocent civilians, predominantly children.

Sir — CNN, whom I trust as basically “progressive” or “left”, had a report from an eyewitness, Linor Attias, a volunteer paramedic. She found a young girl, about eight years old, in her kibbutz home, alone for hours, shaking, terrified and slowly bleeding to death because Hamas cut off her arm below the elbow.
How then can anybody now say Hamas targeted only the Israeli Defence Forces and did not deliberately commit multiple cruel atrocities — even on children?

And how then can any government not grasp that the undoubted perpetrators of such horror, Hamas, designated as terrorists by the EU as well as the US, now just have to be deprived of the power to do ever again what they have publicly declared they will do until Israel is annihilated?

Sir — The war in the Gaza strip is none of our business, and commentary from our Government is not going to make any impact. It is asymmetrical warfare between the US and Israel against Palestinian terrorists.

What is new about America going to war against terrorists? There is nothing new, either, in the media changing their focus away from the Ukrainian conflict because the American media want it that way.

Sir — An Taoiseach has got it right in his opinion that the Israeli military response is “approaching revenge” in Gaza. The initial response of the EU, US and UK, in particular, although very understandable in the context of the appalling slaughter of Israelis by Hamas, risked “sanctioning” an unacceptable and inhumane Israeli response.
Unfortunately, this is apparently what is progressively taking place over these past days and someone needed to flag it.

Sir — Declan Lynch (‘Ghosts of Berlin shocked to see coup still rolling along’, October 29) writes that US House Speaker Mike Johnson “is against almost everything that has happened in the modern world for the last century”.

While I’m not too familiar with Johnson’s politics, if he’s against the gradual destruction of the traditional family unit, the inability/refusal to recognise a person’s biological sex, the eradication of conservative thought in many academic institutions, the substitution of personal responsibility for greater state control in an individual’s life and many other pernicious developments from so-called liberals, then the new speaker gets my approval.
Lynch and his illiberal-liberal brigade are much closer to the far right than they may think. Both lack introspection and modesty, and both will lead us to our downfall.
Sir — How odd. Justice Minister Helen McEntee has just introduced several new offences — and none of them is new.

Non-fatal strangulation is now an offence, but this was already covered by provisions against assault. Stalking is now a crime, but wait — harassment has been a crime since the 1990s. Penalties have also been increased against assaulting gardaí and conspiracy to murder. I’m not a High Court judge, but I believe these too were already illegal.

What is the point of this pettifogging business of dissecting existing laws and explicitly naming specific offences? The Justice Department says it “makes clear the seriousness with which society views such assaults”.
If this sounds like the awareness-raising language of activism, it is any wonder? This legislation was dreamt up by the NGOs to whom Ms McEntee appears to answer.
The same lazy approach was taken with the mooted Hate Speech Legislation.
This duplicated much of the 1989 Prohibition of Incitement to Hatred Act, but surrounded this by enough tendentious jargon to make it, according to many former justice ministers, legally unworkable.
There is, of course, a more traditional way to show that society takes crime seriously. Enforce the law. Has anyone made the minister aware of this option?

Sir — Most companies and government bodies have switched from paper correspondence to online, some under the guise of reducing their carbon footprint. But not everybody in the country is computer-literate or has a smartphone or broadband.

A lot of websites, even state and semi-state websites, are so complicated it would require a degree in computer science to navigate them. When trying to make contact by phone and speak to somebody, you are told to press one for this, two for that, or press three and hold, while repeatedly being told “you can access all information and complete your business online”.
Then you hear “please hold, as our operators are currently busy” (presumably with people who can’t use these websites and haven’t the option of corresponding by post).
People should at least be offered the option of receiving online or postal correspondence.
When it comes to newspapers, some subscribe and read news on their devices, but imagine the outcry from your readers if the
was to go online only and was no longer available in shops.

Sir — In the 1950s, my father had his bike taken off him by the local garda for cycling to a dance with no lights. How is it that today, apparently, everyone on a scooter — and some on bikes — has to wear all black? It is amazing more people aren’t killed.

The real cyclists wear hi-vis and bright colours, yet our young people, and sometimes more mature people, favour black. When the new legislation comes in for scooters, could it not be made law to wear a hi-vis vest? Lives might be saved.
Sir — It looks like RTÉ is not done spending silly amounts of money. It spent half-a-million on investigations into the payments to Ryan Tubridy.
It also investigated why so much was wasted on
. There is just no end to the money RTÉ is squandering while still saying it’s going to need a bailout from the Government if people don’t pay their TV licence.
Does this inspire you to take €160 from your pocket?

Sir — Máiría Cahill (‘Nobody should ever forget the brutal death of 13-year-old Leanne Murray’, October 29) reminded us of the horror of the IRA bombing of Frizzell’s fish shop in 1993 and the subsequent barbaric retaliatory loyalist massacre of eight people and the wounding of 19 at Greysteel. She makes the valid point (referring to the victims) that “we built our peace process on the backs of these bodies”.
She abhors the eulogising of the perpetrators of these atrocities. Her attitude recalls for us the words of Sean O’Casey in his play,
, written 100 years ago: “I draw the line when I hear gunmen blowing about dying for Ireland when it’s the people who die for the gunmen.”

When one thinks of the victims of the Troubles in the North and the Israeli and Palestinian victims of violence in Israel and the Gaza Strip, the words spoken by another character in the same play are as apt and chilling now as they were then: “It’s the civilians who suffer.”

​Sir — Máiría Cahill reminded us of a very brutal massacre. I know 1993 is a long time ago — it was the year Joe Brolly won his sole All-Ireland medal — and that time has moved on, but Gina Murray is not likely to forget the bodybag that was unzipped when she had to identify her daughter.
Gerry Adams carried the coffin of the IRA bomber. Thirty years on, Sinn Féin has a duty to denounce mass murders like those that took place at Frizzell’s fish shop.

Sir — Questions were raised at the recent Oireachtas Health Committee hearings about the three-day reflection period in our abortion legislation, but these appear to have been ignored by the Department of Health and by the media.
There has been remarkable reluctance to look at existing data, and to collect new data, to estimate the number of women who change their minds about abortion in the course of the three-day period.
Indications from the data we do have (HSE payment data and the IFPA report for 2021) are that the three-day period works as intended. Is that why there is such reluctance to get more data?

Sir — When will villages and towns at risk of flooding get the flood relief schemes that were supposedly promised years ago? I can’t help wondering if Mr Ryan of the Greens has put this issue way down on his list of priorities until every town and village in Ireland has its cycle lane.

title: Israeli spies form unit to hunt down Hamas attack planners in Munich-style campaign
body: An armed police officer maintains surveillance after Palestinian group 'Black September' took hostages at the quarters of the Israeli athletes in during the 1972 Munich Olympic Games. (Phot: Hulton Archive/Getty Images)

Israeli Intelligence has formed a unit to hunt down the perpetrators of the October 7 attacks, echoing the bloody campaign to eliminate the Black September militant faction behind the 1972 Munich Olympics massacre.

According to unattributed briefings given to the Israeli press and others, Israel’s two main security agencies, the Shin Bet and Mossad, have launched a joint operation to track down and kill all those involved in last month’s massacre.

title: Budget boost for the Government in new poll: now get ready for Election 2024
body: For the second year in a row support for Sinn Féin has fallen notably after a cost-of-living giveaway, writes Jody Corcoran
Ireland Thinks Poll - State of the Parties
So, the next general election is bound be held this month next year — November 2024 — five months ahead of schedule. Not long to go then.
We know this from our opinion poll today, which confirms a trend: after a giveaway budget Sinn Féin support has fallen dramatically and Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil’s has risen significantly.

title: Letters: With so much bloodshed on both sides in the Middle East, the very stones must be crying out for ‘a time for peace’
body: Children at the Rafah border after being sent back by Israel to the Gaza Strip. Photo: Reuters
Unicef officials told the UN Security Council emergency meeting that “more than 420 children are being killed or injured in Gaza every day”.
Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu has quoted the Bible to justify Israeli military actions in Gaza: “The Bible says there is a time for peace and a time for war. This is a time for war.”
There are many versions of the Bible, and the truth of its messages are often lost in translations or manipulations.

Ecclesiastes 3:7-8 has one such version. “There is a time to tear apart and a time to sew together. There is a time to be silent and a time to speak. There is a time to love and a time to hate. There is a time for war and a time for peace.”
It’s not the first time that religion and religious beliefs have been misused to justify the unjustifiable.
The Middle East and the wider world is being torn apart at present by unjustified wars.
In this 21st century of weapons of mass destruction, no war is justifiable, and throughout history wars were never justifiable when peace by peaceful means should always have been possible.

Now is the time to sew international peace back together. Now is the time to speak out against war crimes. Now is the time to show love and never to hate. There should never be a time for war. The risk of nuclear war was never greater. If it happens, there will be no future. Earth will be uninhabitable.

Academic freedom is one of the defining characteristics of the university. Scholars must be free to research, teach, speak and publish without interference, and universities should encourage diversity of opinion on social, cultural and political topics.

Every individual should be free to boycott whatever they wish on a personal level, but calls for an institutional academic boycott of Israeli universities are a gross insult to the concept of academic freedom and must be resisted as a matter of principle.

Interestingly, there have been no calls for an academic boycott of Russian universities in response to the invasion of Ukraine or of Chinese universities in response to human rights abuses in Xinjiang and Hong Kong.
I envy Sinead Ryan’s acceptance that she “will take my chances with whatever, if anything, lies in the beyond” (‘Gone for good are the bad days when church ruled minds’,
, November 1).

I realise we cannot know if there is an afterlife﻿. If there is nothing after we die, we needn’t worry. But if there is an afterlife, which many religions believe, what do we need to do to ensure we end up on the right side for all eternity?

I’m reminded of the philosopher, Pascal, who took a more pragmatic approach. Believing that evidence cannot settle the question of whether God exists, he proposed that we should bet on God’s existence: we have lots to gain if God exists and nothing to lose if God does not exist.

The revelations from Dominic Cummings and Lee Cain, who worked for Boris Johnson during the outbreak of Covid-19, gives me a sense of pride that the Irish Government and our leaders had the “skillset”, using “competent people” to steer us through a particularly fraught and difficult period.
I hope that if there ever is an inquiry into our failings we won’t learn that the authorities considered our elderly’s fate “just nature’s way of dealing with old people”.

As we all know, Boris Johnson’s elevation to prime minister was primarily based on a lie and populist rhetoric over Brexit. Yet listening to Cain and Cummings, No 10 was not a beacon of calm stability, but a regime at war with itself. The fact Johnson was incapable of making decisions and had a chief adviser, Cummings, who deeply distrusted civil servants and some ministers created a caustic working team who showed a serious lack of competence and know-how.
This lack of expertise at the early stages of the pandemic led to misog- ynistic and hate-filled expletives that deflected from a virus that would kill many people.

There is a lesson to be learnt from listening or watching this inquiry, and that is our reliance on advisers or non-experts, including politicians, where events like Covid-19 happened, must be left to the most qualified and not to people who lack competence or use high office to grandstand.
Elon Musk stated that “the world needs to prepare for a time when there are no jobs”.
It sent a chill down my spine as I asked myself: “How will we all survive without Seanad Éireann?”
I very much enjoyed reading Seán O’Connor’s article regarding attending Sporting Fingal games with his late father (‘Me, my dad and Sporting Fingal’,

, November 1). I can very much identify with the sentiments therein, as my son Rory has completed 35 years accompany- ing me to Oriel Park in support of Dundalk FC. I have attended Oriel for some 60 years and am pleased to have “converted” my son.
We have of course had some wonderful, and not so wonderful days and nights, but as Rory says, it’s when a team is going through a rough-ish patch, that’s the time it needs a “shout”.
Indeed. Here’s (please God) for better or worse to next season and creating the memories Seán wrote about so movingly. One can but quote Bruce Springsteen – glory days. C’mon the Town.
Met Éireann says more rain would fall on “already saturated ground”. Isn’t that called “the fliuch of the Irish”?

title: Israel says it targeted ambulance in Gaza convoy with multiple people killed but claims vehicle was carrying Hamas militants
body: An ambulance in the convoy that was hit, at the entrance of Shifa hospital in Gaza City. Photo: Reuters

Israel struck an ambulance in Gaza City on Friday that it said was carrying militants, but which health authorities in the Hamas-controlled enclave said was evacuating wounded people from the besieged north to the south of the territory.

Ashraf al-Qidra, spokesperson for the health ministry in Gaza, said the ambulance was part of a convoy that Israel targeted leaving al-Shifa Hospital, adding that "a big number" were killed and wounded but without giving figures.

title: Editorial: Desperate plight of Palestinians calls for humanitarian truce
body: A Palestinian woman carries dishes she washed in the sea at the beach in Deir al Balah, Gaza Strip. Photo: AP

Finding nuance in war is a thankless but necessary task, as Joe Biden is demonstrating. The US president’s call for a pause in hostilities comes as his secretary of state Antony Blinken plans a visit to the Middle East, starting in Israel today, for a new round of talks on the conflict.

With Israeli troops at the gates of Gaza City, and as the Palestinian death toll rose above 9,000, a halt to the bombardment to allow humanitarian aid in and possibly hostages and wounded out (though the latter is unlikely) would be greatly welcomed.

Washington officials have said in recent days that they would consider supporting a temporary halt to hostilities if it were limited to helping humanitarian efforts. The subtle but significant shift in US policy comes as the White House faces intensifying pressure from human rights groups and world leaders who say the Israeli bombardment is collective punishment and a ceasefire is long overdue.
Washington, while being rightly critical of Hamas, has also been stressing the need for a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and for Israel to abide by the rules of war.
“This is incredibly complicated for the Israelis,” Mr Biden said. “It’s incredibly complicated for the Muslim world as well.”

Former Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi also highlighted complexities, saying: “Hamas made an assault. Supposing they came into a rave here and killed over 200 people and kidnapped others and killed 1,000 other people going into their homes. This was outrageous.

“Now, how Israel deals with it in terms of not losing the lives of others in Gaza, they have to honour the rules of war going forward. For a political purpose, should we have said something different about Hamas? No. It would not have been possible.”

The spiral of violence has seen unprecedented numbers of civilian deaths. With Israel escalating military operations, what is already a humanitarian disaster can only worsen. Given the unparalleled degree of suffering on both sides, a cessation to avoid irreversible consequences is vital.

The levels of deprivation and desperation cannot be left unaddressed. At a special emergency session, the UN General Assembly adopted a resolution calling for a “humanitarian truce” regarding the situation in Gaza. The UN secretary general wants to see the immediate and unconditional release of all hostages taken from Israel by Hamas. Diplomatic initiatives to suspend the violence, such as that of Mr Blinken, need global support. As he said earlier this week, the way Israel defends itself matters.

Palestinian civilians are not to blame for Hamas’s atrocities or the grave humanitarian crisis in Gaza. They are victims. As German economist Hans F Sennholz wrote: “War cannot be driven out by war, for the use of evil breeds more evil, hostility more hostility, and the use of force more force.”

title: Letters: Gandhi was right – human greed for territory is at the centre of global conflict
body: Mahatma Gandhi
The conflict in Gaza shows no signs of abating. Sadly, it is only increasing in scale and intensity.
To some extent, the equally deplorable war between Ukraine and Russia has been overshadowed by events in the Middle East.
There has also been hostility recently between Azerbaijan and Armenia over the region of Nagorno-Karabakh.
Essentially, all of these disputes share a common theme, and that is an avarice for additional land and territory.
Indeed, Ireland’s own history has been shaped by “land grabs” and the displacement of its indigenous population.
Dr Patrick McGarty (‘When Boycott became boycott: The day we gave the English language a new word’,
, October 30) provides readers with an invaluable insight on the actions of the Irish National Land League as it organised resistance to the eviction of tenants during the late 19th century.
Even in modern-day Irish society, acrimonious disputes over land inheritance, boundaries and rights of way are all too common.
Family relationships are fractured, neighbours alienated and friendships lost – and all for what? Something that none of us can bring with us when our days on this earth draw to a close.
Mahatma Gandhi undoubtedly got it right when he proclaimed: “Earth provides enough to satisfy every man’s needs, but not every man’s greed.”
Gandhi was most probably referring to the human species in general, but it is worthy of note that, invariably, all of these disputes and atrocities are triggered by males.
It begs the question: would women make far more pragmatic and resourceful national leaders?

Karl Martin claims that when it comes to commenting on the carnage in the Middle East, we in Ireland are “in terms of experience, the empty barrel that makes the most noise” (‘Very easy to scold others from our lofty position on the moral high ground’, Letters, November 2).
On the contrary, Ireland has a tremendous amount to offer when it comes to resolving supposedly intractable conflicts.

As the first Western country to ban the importation of produce from South Africa’s racist apartheid regime – a move led by the heroic Dunnes supermarket workers, with the government of the day ultimately forced to legislate accordingly – Ireland was a leading light of the international solidarity movement.

It inspired Nelson Mandela when the news reached him in his prison cell to say that “ordinary people far away from the crucible of apartheid cared for our freedom”. After apartheid in South Africa fell, he went on to say: “Our freedom is incomplete without the freedom of the Palestinians.”

We have done it before; let’s do it again. The Occupied Territories Bill and the Illegal Israeli Settlements Divestment Bill are waiting to be enacted. Fine Gael argues against them, but it did the same in 1984, until public pressure forced it to think again.

What is the appropriate term for an event in which 2.3 million people are trapped in an enclosed space, deprived of water, food and medical supplies and then bombed and blasted mercilessly for weeks on end by warplanes and heavy artillery?

Over the past three weeks, more than 8,500 Palestinians have been killed in Gaza. Among the dead are more than 3,500 children, a figure that exceeds the annual number of children killed in conflicts across the entire globe since 2019.
This is the deadly fruit of Israel’s current invasion of Gaza; its 11th such military incursion into this small but crowded strip of land since 2007.
All that’s needed for evil to triumph is for good people to remain silent.
The mounting corpses of Gaza are stark reminders that the time for sitting on the fence is over.

Now is the time for decent people and governments everywhere to demand an end to this genocide and its replacement by peace based on a free Palestine and on justice and equality between Palestinians and Jews.
It would be easy to hit back at Pat Spillane and instruct him to “stay in his lane” over his opinion piece (‘Rugby pundits are just cheerleaders – this World Cup was another failure for Ireland’,
, October 30) on Ireland’s recent Rugby World Cup failure and how it was received by the Irish media. But then, everyone is entitled to their opinion.
The facts are the facts: this Irish rugby loss is far and away the biggest, baddest loss of them all – probably because of expectations being so high.

I travelled from San Francisco to be there in person, and I still haven’t really got over the loss. I honestly thought we would win, and I’m very disappointed. But I disagree with Mr Spillane on several counts.
Rugby internationals outside of the World Cup are not glorified exhibitions. Exhibition matches do not involve playing the best players available every time.

You would think it extraordinarily bad luck for Ireland to lose 100 years worth of “exhibition matches” to New Zealand before 2016 if the All Blacks didn’t really care deeply about the outcome of every game.

If a touring nation beating the All Blacks in a test match series in New Zealand was just an exhibition series, perhaps a win for the tourists might have occurred more often than three times in the history of the game.
I agree that there are only six, maybe seven, world-class rugby nations. That said, Ireland wasn’t one of them before the last 10- to 15-year period.
The annual hurling season starts with fewer true contenders than the Rugby World Cup does.
Waterford are probably the equivalent of what the Irish rugby team used to be. I’m sure the long-suffering folk in Waterford would go bonkers for an All-Ireland title. And so would the GAA media.

Mr Spillane lists the following as negatives: “All singing, all dancing Irish supporters”; “IRFU maximisation of their commercial income”; and “IRFU promoting their star players at every opportunity”.
What exactly is it that is wrong with those three things?
My sense of it is that the GAA is also enjoying a fairly protracted purple patch. Irish sports fans should be more than content. To hell with the begrudgers.

title: President Higgins urges EU to take firmer line over ‘unacceptable’ violence against civilians in Gaza
body: President of Ireland, Michael D Higgins.

President Michael D Higgins has urged the European Union (EU) not to allow its statements on the Israel-Hamas war to have “ambiguous construction” as he said to do so is “little less than granting of impunity”.

President Higgins called for an “immediate humanitarian ceasefire” and said “collective punishment is not something we can accept and claim to be advocates of international law”, in a statement issued this evening.

“The ongoing horrific loss of civilian life in Gaza and Israel has to be addressed. It should concern us all. Violence by non-State as well as State actors must be described for what it is – breaches of international humanitarian law.
"If international law is to respected, it is important that hostages be released and an immediate humanitarian ceasefire be put in place.

"In this terrible ongoing loss of civilian life, that is having such a devastating impact on families on all sides, with the large proportion of those killed being women and children, it is important that there be a verification of figures, that the lives lost are not reduced to competing press releases,” President Higgins said.

President Higgins said it was “simply unacceptable” that hospitals and, “those being cared for within them are threatened by the basic lack of resources, damaged or indeed threated with destruction, or those within them forced to be evacuated”.
He said those in the international community who are anxious to support international law must press for an “independent verification of the facts”.

“International bodies, including the European Union and members of the broader international community, who remain silent or allow their messages to have ambiguous construction have a responsibility to commit to vindicating international law. This is needed to give credibility to what is a much-invoked multilateralism. Not to do so is to accede to little less than the granting of impunity to those involved in a conflict.

“When it comes to the protection of children, no other issues should stand in the way for even a minute. Friendships, alliances and partnerships are tested by what cannot be avoided if diplomacy is to return and replace war,” President Higgins said.

Mr Higgins said he was proud of Irish charities and other NGOs responding to “the present horror that is unfolding in Gaza”, saying that “great acts of courage and humanity are taking place in the worst of circumstances”.

"One can only admire the extraordinary courage and commitment of the medical personnel who, while enduring unimaginable difficulties, are staying with those for whom they care, putting their own lives at risk. That so many members of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA), including teachers, have already lost their lives in that task illustrates the terrible price that threatening civilians with terror, war and its response delivers. What they are facing are of this suffering.

“If we are to move past the present events, we need the capacity to verify what are the facts on the ground and to respond to them, removing all blocks to humanitarian relief, indicating how a space for diplomacy can be found, and out of all of this how a consistent diverse body of proposals might come forward, ones that can deliver a reasonable security to citizens of Israel, and at the same time achieve the delivery of the long-neglected rights of the Palestinian people; offering the prospect of peace to future generations who must share space and life together as neighbours,” President Higgins said.

title: Taoiseach ‘hasn’t been briefed’ on reports that Irish citizen captured by Hamas
body: Taoiseach Leo Varadkar visiting the demilitarised zone dividing the Korean Peninsula
Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has said he is not aware of reports from Iran that an Irish national is among hostages kidnapped by Hamas in the October 7 attacks on Israel.

Mr Varadkar was speaking after an Iranian news agency Nour News reported that Tánaiste Micheál Martin had asked his Iranian counterpart earlier this week to assist with freeing an Irish hostage believed to be held captive in Gaza.

While he confirmed that Mr Martin, the Foreign Affairs Minister, had made a number of phone calls to his counterparts in the region in the wake of the Israel-Gaza conflict, including Iran's Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, Mr Varadkar has not been briefed on the matter.
"What I can say is I haven’t been briefed on that matter," he said. “I haven’t briefed anything in relation to an Irish citizen kidnapped by Hamas.”

A spokesperson for Tánaiste and Minister for Foreign Affairs Micheál Martin said that they were unable to comment on individual cases, following the reports of an Irish citizen being held hostage by Hamas.

"The Department of Foreign Affairs is working to ensure all Irish citizens are able to leave Gaza as soon as possible. We are not in a position to comment on the detail of individual cases - it would not be helpful to do so,” a statement said.

Speaking about the broader situation in the region, the Taoiseach expressed his concerns about the deteriorating situation. He said the EU is calling for a “humanitarian pause” so that hostages can be released, aid can be allowed into Gaza and EU citizens can leave the area.

“The sad reality is though, no matter what the European Union calls for, Israel will decide to do what it decides to do and Hamas will decide to do what it decides to do and it is a situation now that is very seriously deteriorating, in my view," he said.
“I'm very concerned about it, and I am very concerned the impact on innocent civilians, initially in Israel because of the Hamas attack there.

"But now because of Israel's response, seeing thousands of people, almost all civilians, many of them children, losing their lives and this isn't going to bring peace. I'm sure of that, it can't possibly and the fighting needs to stop.”

title: Sinn Féin’s foreign policy would ‘weaken Ireland's influence in the world’, says Taoiseach Leo Varadkar
body: Taoiseach Leo Varadkar was speaking on the final day of a major government trade mission to South Korea (Niall Carson/PA)
Sinn Féin’s foreign policy would weaken Ireland’s influence in the world and damage relations with countries like the United States, Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has warned.

On the final day of a major government trade mission to South Korea, Mr Varadkar took aim at the main opposition party and criticised its platforming of officials from Hamas, the Palestinian militant organisation that carried out the October 7 terrorist atrocities on Israel.
“I do think generally Sinn Féin’s foreign policy would weaken Ireland's influence in the world,” Mr Varadkar said in Seoul on Friday morning.

“I think they would certainly risk falling out with the United States over issues like Cuba, Venezuela, perhaps their stance in the Middle East, would fall out with Spain over their support for separatism there.
“[They] have been very critical of the European Union and its institutions, not just historically but also recently.

“So for a small country that needs to have good relations with the US, with the UK, with the European Union, with other member states, I think it is the case that Sinn Féin would weaken and damage our relations with lots of different other countries and that would have consequences, I think.
“It would have economic consequences for a start, would reduce our influence in the world, and certainly would do nothing to help people like the Palestinians, for example.”

Mr Varadkar said that while he would not compare Sinn Féin and Hamas, he would have concerns about Mary Lou McDonald’s party sharing platforms with the organisation, which has been designated a terrorist grouping by the EU, the US, and the UK.
Sinn Féin representatives, including party chair Declan Kearney, have engaged with and met with Hamas on a number of occasions in recent years.
Hamas’s head of international relations spoke at an online event hosted by Sinn Féin which was opened by Ms McDonald in 2020.

The party’s foreign affairs spokesperson Matt Carthy told the Sunday Independent last month that Sinn Féin would not rule out further talks with Hamas – despite the group‘s responsibility for atrocities that left more than 1,400 people dead in Israel.
It is holding more than 200 hostages that were taken from Israel on October 7.
“I think it's fair to say that most political parties in Ireland wouldn't platform terrorist organisations on their social media,” Mr Varadkar added.

In response to the Taoiseach’s comments Mr Carthy said: “For decades Sinn Féin has developed important and long-standing international relationships with successive US administrations and on Capitol Hill. Coupled with our work in the EU, Australia and further afield we are proud of our record in building support for the peace process and for Irish interests.

“We are also very proud of record of international solidarity with South Africans in their struggle against apartheid, our track record on Palestine and supporting those who strive for peace and justice worldwide.

“On Cuba, Leo Varadkar may not know this, but this week the UN voted overwhelmingly to end the blockade of Cuba and Ireland supported that vote; so they have adopted the exact same position of Sinn Féin, which makes his comments even more bizarre.”

title: Orchestra promoting harmony amid Israel-Hamas crisis ‘extremely important’
body: Daniel Barenboim conducts the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra during rehearsals as part of the BBC Proms season in central London (Ian West/PA)

Musicians from Palestine and Israel performing together in the West Eastern Divan Orchestra could help bring about the idea of a more peaceful future despite the Israel-Hamas crisis, the widow of the orchestra’s founder has said.

The ensemble was established by late Palestinian academic Edward Said and Israeli conductor Daniel Barenboim more than 20 years ago as an “alternative way to address the Israeli-Palestinian conflict”.

“(The orchestra) was started after Daniel and my late husband Edward discovered that they became very good friends and they broke barriers and they extended it to their people and Daniel made an orchestra out of them,” widow Mariam Said told BBC Newsnight.

body: Some of the attendance at the vigil for Gaza which was held on Gorey's main street on Wednesday evening. Pic: Jim Campbell

Local people held ‘Free Palestine’ signs and called on the Irish Government to push for a ceasefire at the Vigil for Palestine on Gorey Main Street on Wednesday, October 23,

Cllr Ó Súilleabháin’s speech began in Irish and proceeded to outline details surrounding the conflict. “Thousands have been killed and we must do all we can to help bring this conflict to an end. We need to see the release of hostages, We need to recognise the need for emergency humanitarian aid. We need a ceasefire. We need to see respect for human rights law and international law, and we need a lasting peace agreement that supports Palestinian statehood. However, respect for the right of Israel to defend itself cannot be a cover for breaching international law,” said Cllr Ó Súilleabháin in his speech.

Proinsias MacDiarmada also attended the Vigil and said there was a good turnout on the day. “I was very impressed with the amount of people that turned up and beeped their horns in solidarity because it’s very sad what’s happening over there and it’s genocide as far as I’m concerned,” said Proinsias.

Proinsias MacDiarmada and Cllr Fionntán Ó Súilleabháin have both spent time in Palestine in the past. “I’ve been to Gaza and can tell you that they are amongst the nicest, most hospitable, welcoming and generous people you will find anywhere in the world, even though they live under siege and in abject poverty,” said Cllr Ó Súilleabháin.

In his speech, Cllr Ó Súilleabháin also mentioned the stark difference he noticed between Gaza and Tel Aviv in Israel when he visited both areas. “Gaza-an arid strip of ground around the size of the Gorey-Kilmuckridge Municipal District with over 2 million people squashed into something akin to the world’s largest concentration camp and surrounded by razor wire. Many live in abject poverty, in refugee camps with little sanitation or proper infrastructure, having been ethnically cleansed from their own land,” said Cllr Ó Súilleabháin.
