title: Letters: Targeting of civilians in Gaza, or anywhere else, is very clearly a war crime
body: A displaced Palestinian boy, who fled with his family from their house amid Israeli strikes, looks after his twin siblings as they take shelter at Nasser hospital in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip October 29, 2023. REUTERS/Mohammed Salem
As Tim Buckley correctly says, defence and revenge are not the same thing (Letters, October 31).

I would add that the mass killing of civilians and children in Gaza – over 8,000 so far – is not even revenge, it is something beyond that: the more than 3,000 children killed had no part in what happened in southern Israel.
These were innocent children with dreams for the future, no different from the children of Israel or those we see about us every day.
The deliberate killing of civilians is a war crime, whether carried out in southern Israel by Hamas or in Gaza or the West Bank by the Israeli military. Palestinian lives matter.
In relation to the recent conflict in Gaza, remember the Bosnian war, when the world talked while terrible atrocities took place .
Is history to repeat itself again and again?
May an Irish-born Jew be allowed to express his opinion on the war in Gaza?
I read each day the views of people who have never been to the Middle East or, specifically, Israel. They are quick to lecture Jews on how they should behave.
We Jews have been persecuted since the time of our enslavement in Egypt. My great-grandparents fled Russia from the pogroms instigated by Tsar Nicholas, stopping off in Cork, speaking only Yiddish.
They thought they were in New York and were happy to make their home in Ireland.
When Jews had no sovereignty over their ancient homeland, the antisemites would tell them to go to Palestine as they were not welcome in Ireland.
Now that a remnant of the Jewish people has restored sovereignty to their homeland, they somehow have stolen the land from the “ancient Palestinians”.

Let me make it clear: Hamas do not want any piece of land; their goal, clearly stated in their charter, is to destroy Israel and kill all its people based on their interpretation of the Koran and Hadith.
The October 7 massacre of Jews was more barbaric than any normal human being could even imagine.
The Palestinian Arabs have been offered a state multiple times, but always refused to accept.

Since modern Israel was established in 1948, and up to 1973, over 900,000 Jews who lived in Arab countries have been expelled (their ‘crime’ being Jewish due to the founding of the state of Israel), with all their possessions stolen.
Two-thirds went to live in Israel and the rest settled in the US and Europe. There has been no justice or compensation for these people. Why? They are Jews, that is why.

Israel is entitled under international law to knock out rocket launchers that are firing into Israel, even if civilians are being used as shields. Using civilians as a shield is a war crime, but according to the world the Jews are the war criminals.

October 7 was a watershed mom-ent for the people of Israel, and their aggressive defence would be fully justified if they were not Jewish. However, Jews have to live by different standards laid down by gentiles.
Benjamin Netanyahu turns to the Bible to justify his rejection of a ceasefire in Gaza, saying: “The Bible says there is a time for peace and a time for war. This is the time for war.”
Vladimir Putin also justifies his war against the Ukrainian people on religious grounds.

This is nothing new, as the Bible has been weaponised to justify the ethnic cleansing and enslavement of the peoples of South America, Africa, Oceania and down to the justification of apartheid in South Africa.
Netanyahu and Putin cynically contradict the biblical tradition of justice, mercy and peace as preached by Moses, the Jewish prophets and Jesus Christ.
God, whether she is called Yahweh, Elohim or Allah, is a god of compassion, whose sole passion is for justice and who takes the side of the powerless and oppressed.
Religious leaders need to reclaim this god of compassion and stand up for Gaza.

There is a gap in your reporting on Safe Access Zones, which might lead to public misunderstanding (‘Two Fine Gael TDs made last-minute appeal for ‘free vote’ on new law banning protests outside facilities which provide abortions’, September 27).

The report refers to the proposed law on Safe Access Zones as providing “a 100-metre exclusion zone around the entrance and exit to all healthcare facilities that provide an abortion”. However, the bill would affect all healthcare and medical facilities, regardless of whether they perform abortions or not, thereby criminalising the public expression of pro-life views within a 100-metre vicinity of any healthcare provider.

As such, the ban is not just limited to hospitals. Even a GP practice that exercises its right to freedom of conscience (as most do) would arbitrarily have a Safe Access Zone created around its premises, as a result of which, within those 100 metres, the expression of any pro-life view would be prohibited by law.
Journalists reporting on this draconian and unnecessary bill surely need to give an accurate picture of its full implications, or the public will be misinformed about its true nature and impact.
Andy Farrell has been named World Rugby coach of the year. Bundee Aki was not named men’s player of the year, but Bundee, you are Ireland’s player of the year. Well done to both.
Congratulations to all who completed the Dublin Marathon, my son included. I am thinking of taking part next year. I will make my mind up in the long run.

title: Editorial: The children of Gaza cannot be scapegoated for crimes of Hamas
body: The search for casualties at the site of Israeli strikes on houses in Jabalia refugee camp in the northern Gaza Strip, October 31, 2023. Photo: Reuters

Silence encourages the tormentor, never the tormented, said Elie Wiesel. Few knew more about war and its horrors than the Nobel laureate and Holocaust survivor. Given the horrendous scenes in Gaza, many may be numbed into speechlessness.

But the revelation that 940 children are now reported missing in the territory, according to UN children’s agency Unicef – some thought to be trapped beneath the rubble of buildings flattened by Israeli airstrikes – demands we find a voice to call a halt, however temporary, in the name of humanity.

“Our gravest fears about the reported numbers of children killed becoming dozens, then hundreds, and ultimately thousands were realised in just a fortnight,” James Elder, a spokesman for the agency said. “The numbers are appalling; reportedly more than 3,450 children killed; staggeringly this rises significantly every day. Gaza has become a graveyard for thousands of children. It’s a living hell for everyone else.”

Meanwhile Catherine Russell, Unicef’s executive director, has said that at least 6,300 children have been injured due to the Israeli attacks. This means that on average, 420 Palestinian children are killed or injured every day in the Gaza Strip, she explained. The organisation has pleaded for an immediate ceasefire.

“Without swift and sustained humanitarian relief, the conflict is much more likely to spread, suffering will grow, and Hamas and its sponsors will benefit by fashioning themselves as the saviours of the very desperation they created,” Antony Blinken, US Secretary of State, has warned.

A “public health catastrophe” is now imminent in Gaza, a World Health Organisation official also cautioned. Three weeks of mass killings have further enveloped the region in tragedy, adding new depths of trauma. Several dozen more people were killed yesterday in an airstrike on the densely populated Jabalia refugee camp. Some 8,500 Palestinians have died.
The grieving on all sides is harrowing and heart-rending. Among the 1,400 Israelis slaughtered in Hamas’s original massacre, 200 remain unidentified as their bodies were burned beyond recognition.
Yet imperative as it is for Israel to defend itself, the Palestinian civilians who make up the vast bulk of Gaza must also be protected.

Collective punishment of a nation will further corrupt historic wounds. Tel Aviv must do what it can to keep Israelis safe, but how it does this matters gravely. The children of Gaza cannot be scapegoated for the crimes of Hamas; a civilian population cannot be blamed and summarily punished for the atrocities of terrorists.

Nor can depriving the sick of water, food and medicine be defended. A pause to treat the wounded and get aid through is crucial. Not only is this the just and humane thing to do, it is in Israel’s best security interests to avoid the conflict escalating.
We may not know the people in the terrible scenes we are witnessing, but each is a somebody. The world must never look on Gaza as a nobody zone.

title: Letters: Only when we get tough on war crimes will we be ‘playing a blinder’ in Gaza
body: The search for survivors after Israel bombed Jabalia refugee camp, Gaza. Photo: Getty
I cannot agree with John Cuffe’s analysis of the Irish Government’s response (‘Our leaders are playing a blinder on Gaza – now let’s recognise Palestine’, Letters, October 30).

Consensus among human rights organisations, current and former special UN rapporteurs, the Harvard Law School and other legal experts is that the Israeli state is committing the crime of apartheid against the Palestinian people.
Senior government figures still refuse to use the term, although they cannot dispute the facts.

But Mr Cuffe is quite right: it is certainly “time for the Dáil to enact what has already passed in both houses of Oireachtas”. The Occupied Territories Bill had passed both houses with cross-party support and was due for examination at committee stage when it was stonewalled by Simon Coveney in the 2020 Programme for Government negotiations.
This bill will end Ireland’s complicity in war crimes in occupied territories throughout the world.

When the Government – or a future one – finally enacts this bill, I will wholeheartedly agree with Mr Cuffe that they are “playing a blinder” in response to this long-standing human rights catastrophe.

I’m watching the Israeli army bombing and intensifying ground operations in Gaza and am horrified to see this humanitarian disaster happening. I can’t understand why world leaders are not intervening to stop this.
Two million people live in Gaza. The UN has passed a motion to initiate a humanitarian truce. I call on all elected representatives to push for further action.
To remain silent in the face of injustice is to be part of injustice.
Perhaps Israel’s ambassador to Ireland, Dana Erlich, should cut us some slack (‘Ireland one of more challenging places in Europe, says Israel foreign affairs minister’,
, October 31).
We Irish live on an island that is far from any conflict zone. Uniquely in the world, our army spends more on biscuits than tanks and our Air Corps spends more on Domestos than fighter jets.

In short, we know nothing of the sort of danger that Israeli Jews, Muslims and Christians face each day from Islamist extremists like Hamas, IS and Al-Qa’ida. We are perhaps, in terms of experience, the empty barrel that makes the most noise.
Seeing images of terrified children after Israeli bombings in Gaza makes me wonder how many will grow up seeking revenge against Israel.
In 2023, it is heartbreaking to see such terrible scenes of inhumanity.
The October 7 attack on innocent Israelis was dreadful; so too is the price now being paid by Palestinian children.
Our world leaders must find a permanent solution to this horrendous situation.
The letter headlined ‘Netanyahu is weaponising the Bible in justifying his refusal to halt war in Gaza’ (November 1) saw a contributor query the Israeli PM’s inappropriate use of the Bible text.
But a bigger issue, the real conundrum, really, is missing the main message of the Bible. A new course called Hope Explored summarises the book’s central message as hope, peace, purpose.

A lot of conflict between Jews and Muslims might be avoided if they recognised that “One Solitary Life” fulfilling one of the shortest (and most important) messianic prophecies: the Suffering Servant described in Isaiah 53. That section can be read in only two to three minutes.
Shortly following this, we read in Isaiah of the most wonderful invitation this life affords anyone: “Seek the Lord while he may be found; call on him while he is near.”
Real peace becomes possible when we let the Prince of Peace embrace us and change our warped values.

As I write this, Storm Ciarán is on its way and threatening yet more wind and deluges on southern and south-eastern counties, the latest wave of wet weather in what has been a dreadful summer and autumn.
Serious flooding has occurred nationwide, wreaking havoc on homes and businesses. Many of these locations await the implementation of flood defence works.
It is notable that two places prone to regular flooding, Bray and Clonmel, no longer flood due to successful flood defence works.

Flood defence schemes on behalf of the State are subject to planning and environmental legislation at domestic and EU level. Many schemes are currently in the clogged planning pipeline due to third-party objections and judicial review.
Meanwhile, villages, towns and cities are being submerged in freshwater, seawater and foul water.

Section 181 of the Planning and Development Act 2000 empowers the relevant minister or local authority chief executive to declare a certain development to be exempt from the normal planning process in the interest of public health and safety, state revenue and state security.
A particular example beside where I live is a 7.5-hectare customs facility in Rosslare Harbour. It was an emergency response to the implications of Brexit on Rosslare Europort.
With one stroke of a pen, the finance minister signed an order under Section 181, authorising a substantial facility. No planning process; no public consultation.
Accordingly, in the context of the current flooding crises, flood defence relief works should be classed as similar emergency infrastructure.
With the trick or treat buckets put away, can the selection boxes and Advent calendars be far away?
It’s all getting harder to swallow.

title: ‘Ceasefire now’ – Angry anti-war protesters interrupt US Congress hearing on aid to Israel and Ukraine

An anti-war protester is taken away by police during a Senate Appropriations Committee hearing on President Biden's $106 billion national security supplemental funding request to support Israel and Ukraine, as well as bolster border security, with testimony by U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., October 31, 2023. title: Israeli airstrikes crush apartments in Gaza refugee camp as more than 50 Palestinians reported dead

Palestinians search for casualties at the site of Israeli strikes on houses in Jabalia refugee camp in the northern Gaza Strip on Tuesday. Photo: Anas al-Shareef

title: Editorial: A war without dialogue is doomed to be a war without end
body: Palestinians look for survivors after an Israeli strike on the Gaza Strip in Rafah yesterday. Photo: Hatem Ali/AP

It is one of those quirks of language, that the word ‘listen’ contains the same letters as the word silent. Amid the furious rhythm of the war drums, there is no chance of a silent moment; or less still of the dialogue that might put a stop to them. Towers of black smoke hang over all that is left of Gaza’s apartment blocks.
From the desolate pictures coming from the territory, concern deepens for those who inhabited the once densely populated areas.

title: Letters: Fault lies not with religion but in the failings of some of those who practise it
body: Critics often point to outpourings of violence to attack religion when they should take issue with people who act in defiance of church teachings. Photo: Getty Images

Is there no end to the letters from your readers disparaging Christians (Catholics in particular) and seeking to undermine their beliefs? It is not much of an exaggeration to say that these letters are now a weekly occurrence in your columns.

Yesterday, two of the usual suspects, Declan Foley and Tom McElligott, had their say (‘New GOP speaker’s hatred of God’s children does not chime with his Christianity’; ‘Godless Ireland has a lot to be proud of but we must not rest on our laurels’,
, Letters, October 30).

The Gospel reading at last Sunday’s mass was about Jesus replying to the question, “What is the greatest commandment?” His answer was unequivocal: “Love God and love your neighbour”, an Old Testament teaching which also applies to Muslims and Jews. When, therefore, critics point to violence, etc, to attack “religion”, what they are actually attacking is people who act in defiance of the actual teaching.
Jesus also said that loving God meant keeping his commandments.
Included in these commandments are clear, unambiguous instructions on sexual purity and on the sanctity of human life, which many in modern Ireland now choose to ignore.
“How much longer is the world willing to endure this spectacle of wanton cruelty?”
I quote from the final letter written by the British philosopher Bertrand Russell in 1970 in relation to the plight of the Palestinian people at the hands of Israel.
Over 50 years later we are still witnessing this military bombardment and punishment being meted out to an innocent people.
Stop – for God’s sake!

What abject failure has been displayed by the West during decades of Palestinian “displacement” and suffering of Palestinians. From the Balfour Declaration (1917) to the British withdrawal (1948) the “great powers” in Europe and the US have been complicit in the disgraceful treatment of Palestinians, treated as unfortunate collateral in the grand scheme of giving the Jews a homeland – something they are most certainly entitled to.
But there was no thought given to the rights of the people already there, the mass dispossession which followed, as they were terrorised out of their homes.
Many of these ended up in the “open-air prison” of Gaza.

It’s a bit late in the day now to be talking of the “two-state solution” when we have stood by and ignored the land grab which shows a pock-marked territory in the West Bank interspersed with illegal settlements (which are defended by the IDF…).

We have stood by as Palestinian houses and olive groves were levelled, water diverted to the “settlers”, thousands imprisoned including minors, and the basics of existence – water, food, electricity – doled out as decided by Israel.
Worst of all, we have allowed a situation of absolute hopelessness to develop where radicalism will automatically take root.
Will the West ever learn to respect the Palestinians as well as the Israelis?

There is a huge difference between defence and revenge; the governments and peoples of every civilised nation on this earth should say that to the Israeli government, in the clearest and most emphatic way that they can.

Following the reported reversal of ­government policy to remove planning permissions on undeveloped lands, Sinn Féin’s housing spokesman Eoin Ó Broin  has stated that land-use zoning is “a gift from the State to owners of land”.
Land use zoning is not a “gift” from anyone to anyone.
It is the legal process under which county development plans designate serviced lands capable of being used to build homes, institutional and commercial facilities upon.
Homes badly needed by our population of 5.2 million.
Zoning designation is but the first step.
Planning permission and procurement of construction financing follow. One is useless without the other.
Yes, land owners do enjoy a valuation increase. As do landowners whose property is acquired by the State for roads and other infrastructural projects.

It’s small wonder we have a housing supply crisis. Sinn Féin members  – and members of other political parties – are not shy about consistently opposing new home developments just to curry favour with local residents who have an innate resentment to any new projects in their area.
Bad and all as the current administration’s housing provision record is, it could hardly be worse under a Sinn Féin administration.
A question from a still-smarting Irish rugby fan now that it’s all over. We beat the Boks, the Boks beat the All Blacks, and the All Blacks beat us – does that make it better or worse?
Recently, while watching England play South Africa in the Rugby World Cup, I was impressed by how both teams sang their national anthems so passionately.
It’s a shame the same could not be done by Irish players who do not get the opportunity to sing our country’s national anthem.
Colin Shovlin
Co Donegal
If there’s one thing that gets me wound up, it’s putting the clocks back...

title: UK Labour Party suspends MP after speech at pro-Palestine rally
body: Andy McDonald will sit as an independent MP while an investigation takes place (Richard Townshend/UK Parliament/PA)
Labour has suspended its MP Andy McDonald, claiming comments he made at a pro-Palestine rally were “deeply offensive”.
Mr McDonald, who will sit as an independent MP while an investigation takes place, used the phrase “between the river and the sea” in a speech during a demonstration at the weekend.

title: Russia’s dwindling ‘Mountain Jews’ in spotlight after Dagestan airport riot
body: People storming the runway of Makchakala airport in Dagestan, Russia.

The Jewish community of the mostly Muslim region of Dagestan, focus of international attention since an attack on passengers flying in from Israel as the Palestinian-Israeli conflict in Gaza intensifies, traces its origins back to the 7th century.

The community, shrunk by emigration to around 300-400 families from a peak population of over 10,000 in the middle of the last century, is based in the even more ancient city of Derbent on the western shore of the Caspian Sea, on an old north-south trade route skirting the Caucasus mountains.

title: Letters: New US House Speaker’s hatred of God’s children does not square with his professed Christianity
body: Republican Speaker of the House Mike Johnson. Photo: AP

We who have lived in Ireland throughout the 1970s and 80s should be well aware of the hatred of Christians for other Christians, with the resulting disgusting and inhumane bombings and shootings to death of men, women and children – even some in utero.

The new Republican Speaker of the House in Washington Mike Johnson [who, among other things, has expressed his opposition to abortion and LGBTQ relationships], claims the Bible gives him the right to be, not only anti “others”, but to legislate to prosecute and imprison these children of God, solely because they are “others”.

How does this equate with the enormous love that God has for each of us? Or is it that we do not try hard enough to comprehend this massive love with its request to reciprocate it to ensure peace in the world?

The Taoiseach, Tánaiste and the Irish nation have played a blinder. Resisting the pressure from Israel and America, Ireland has regained its compassion, sense of fair play and more importantly, the ability to speak on behalf of the Irish people.

Our politicians are speaking on our behalf – they are not following those dubious geo-political playmakers as they domino their way around the Middle East and South America on their dodgy plan to end the so-called ‘War on Terror’.
Last week, US President Joe Biden ordered an airstrike in Syria as a “defensive" move.
Perhaps if he defended the people of Maine in the same week from the horrific slaughter of 18 innocents by, guess what, a US army reservist, then America might be a safer, saner place.

It’s evident our leaders can talk only so much. Time for Ireland in the UN to table a motion to remove the veto on security council resolutions from the US and the other five countries who possess it.
It is also time for the Dáil to enact what’s already passed in both Houses of Oireachtas – recognition of Palestine. A big step but we can do it.
A little reported nugget in the latest census data dump was revealed recently in your newspaper. Ellen Coyne’s article (‘Census 2022 highlights waning power of Catholicism in Ireland’,

October 27) reported that the number of people in Ireland with no religion is now 736,210 – a huge  63pc increase on the last census in 2016. There were also 3,823 people who said they were agnostic or atheist.

This is very welcome news for a small country with a large footprint worldwide. And particularly so when the new Speaker of the US House of Representatives, Mike Johnson has said he wants to bring religion back to the centre of politics and policy there.

Religion is at the root cause of the wars currently being fought in the Middle East. And the horrendous murders of Aidan Moffitt and Michael Snee in Sligo had their genesis in religious faith and extreme intolerance.
We should not rest on our laurels though. It’s only a year since a man of the Catholic cloth was allowed disparage homosexuals from the pulpit in Listowel.

People have every right to freely worship what ever god or gods they want. But when they seek to impose what may be genuinely held beliefs on others through politics and policy, that must be resisted by all sensible democracy loving persons. Anything else and we are heading back into the dark ages.

In the past year, the sentences handed out to the ‘Mr Bigs’ of the illegal drug industry have been paltry. The argument holds however, that many of those before the courts are just unfortunate pawns in the game.

If caught red-handed, they reel off the usual recipe for a suspended sentence – plead guilty, express extreme remorse, say they had a tortured upbringing. That is, all the things which apply to almost every criminal and which should have been factored in to the recommended sentencing for such crimes in the first place.

The Special Criminal Court was set up as a juryless criminal court to try terrorism and serious organised crime cases. So why are drug lords being tried before one judge in the the Dublin Circuit Criminal Court?

It used to be an ace up the sleeve that people watched for – but for me as a teacher, it was a note hidden up my students’ sleeves that I kept my eye out for. Now however, it is more likely to be a nicotine patch.

The state of Victoria in Australia has just started its senior-level exams and there have been a number of student vapers caught with patches on their arms. The exam can be up to three hours and that’s too long to go without a nicotine hit.
The ever semi-reliable Google tells me that many cigarette manufacturers are behind e-cigarettes, since old-fashioned smoking rates are, thankfully, declining.
No one can seriously argue that cigarettes or vapes are good for people and given the many who have died from the effects of cigarettes at any rate, it’s time to ban them in all forms.
Live long and healthy – something that’s a lot easier if you have no addictions.

Once again, the pundits are ascribing huge significance to the Springboks Rugby World Cup victory when it could just as easily be described as a random event occasioned by small margins. The Boks won three matches by one point (and lost to Ireland by four) and had the rub of the green on Saturday.

The All Blacks were denied a brilliant try by an almost imperceptible knock-on (itself occasioned by an illegal playing of their man in the air) and also had a penalty wrongly awarded against Ardie Savea when it should have been the other way around. They had a man sent off for shoulder on head, but the ref missed a clear elbow to Sam Cane’s head.
The bigger issue is that tries no longer decide the really crunch matches –penalties, and by extension, referees do, and that is not a good look for the game.

title: Thousands loot UN aid stores in desperation as Gaza besieged
body: Smoke rises following Israeli bombardment on Gaza City. Photo: Abed Khaled/AP
Thousands of Gazans broke into UN warehouses to grab flour and hygiene supplies, in a sign of growing desperation and the breakdown of public order in the besieged enclave.

title: Ciara Kelly: I see people talking about Israel and Palestine like they’re football teams, but taking sides will not lead to peace
body: The atrocities against both the Palestinians and Israelis must be called out by our leaders or the war will go on
Sadly, in the Middle East and across the world, it is the importance of respect that continues to be denied the respect it truly deserves. Photo: Getty

I’m wary of writing about the Middle East conflict. I don’t know enough to fully understand how the Palestinians view Israel. Nor do I know enough to fully understand the Israeli mindset. But I know a few things. I know Jews have been treated appallingly all over the world for centuries, pogrom after pogrom.

They’ve endured endemic discrimination and exclusion from society that culminated in the Holocaust, which attempted to wipe them out entirely. Six million were  murdered — three times the population of Gaza. It was an industrial genocide that resulted in the formation of Israel in 1948.

title: Adrian Weckler: Where now for Paddy Cosgrave, a revving engine without a lane?
body: Paddy Cosgrave in Profile
What’s next for Paddy Cosgrave and the Web Summit?

title: Letters: Grief of being childless still isn’t treated with humanity
body: Motherhood denied is a topic that needs more discussion
Sir — I would like to thank the editor of
for the recent article and, indeed, the cover of the magazine (‘Motherhood Denied: the agony of the women who can’t be mothers’, by Niamh Jimenez, October 15).
Motherhood denied is my story — and the story of many others. It needs to be talked about.

I was treated dreadfully in the workplace when I said this. I mentioned it three times over a year on the work WhatsApp group and I was told to stop going on about that “crap” by a senior staff member.

I’ve been subjected to comments such as “It’s fine for those who are childless and single” a few times, told we all have our own crosses to bear, told I could have had kids if I really wanted to, and told to “get over yourself, people go through worse”.

I’ve been forced to endure that mother who attaches the words “as a parent” in staff meetings. I work in education and I know she is following politicians who disclose their parentage on repeat — wrong on so many levels.
I have to listen to parents moaning about having to collect their children from activities and about having to wash so many extra clothes.
My grief has never been treated with the humanity it deserves. Society needs to learn that we are people and to treat us too with respect.
Trust me, mine is not the only story of nastiness and “please shut-ups”. I have shown the
article to many and they are so grateful too. I hope your cover story will lead some away from this type of cruelty.

Sir — When I was young and the local west of Ireland papers carried the death notice of a neighbour, added at the bottom were the words “American papers please copy”. The premise was that most of my locale had emigrated to the States anyway and the local paper was asking the global American ones to pass the message on. No internet or smartphones back then.
Can I implore American papers to please copy my message to themselves?
With Joe Biden bombing Syria last week — “self-defence” he said, and of course nothing to do with Israel — it reminded me of the weapons of mass destruction in Iraq 20 years ago. Another lie.
America, can I implore you — as a 71-year-old who has made it this far — please think of the rest of the world as you fight the imaginary and real enemies you are creating in your empire-building.
I’d like my grandchildren to live in a world free of warmongering. Your enemies aren’t necessarily my enemies. Stop the bombing now.
American papers please copy.
Sir — Taoiseach Leo Varadkar recently told a student debate at Trinity College Dublin that “people need to be able to express their beliefs without the fear of being cancelled”.

Reading your excellent coverage of the Israel-Hamas war, one could be forgiven for thinking that many Israelis and their supporters would like nothing better than for President Higgins to be silenced.
Terrorists always flourish when there is a political vacuum, and we in Ireland have particular knowledge of how intimately that works.

If one has to blame someone or something for the current war engulfing the Middle East, Benjamin Netanyahu is a good starting point. How many wars again have erupted during his long tenure? Then there is the way this political bully behaves towards his ultimate guarantor, the United States. Is it any wonder he and Donald Trump got along so well?
The sooner this horrendous war ends and Netanyahu is sent into retirement, the better.
Sir — The anger and frustration of the Israeli ambassador to the UN, as expressed last week, is understandable.
However, to say that “the secretary general, once again, distorts and twists reality” and to then call for his resignation is totally disproportionate.

Antonio Guterres was clear in describing the Hamas October 7 murder and abduction rampage as “appalling”, and he further said nothing could justify the killing, injuring and kidnapping of civilians at the hands of Hamas.
UN secretary general Antonio Guterres
No more than any other international confrontation, these hostilities have their own context that must sooner or later be recognised, if there is any hope for long-term peace.
Impotent as the UN often seems, expecting it not to consider the context of this or any other hostilities is to further impair its capacity in conflict resolution.
Mr Guterres spoke cogently, in measured tones, and with the prudence of a possible future arbitrator between the sides involved.
Sir — David Quinn poses the question: how is Israel to eliminate Hamas as a threat?
It seems a conundrum, but if our own recent history has taught us anything, it is that violence upon violence causes only further suffering and death. It never achieves a solution.

I don’t claim to have all the answers — I don’t even know all the questions — but vengefully besieging and wiping out the civilian population of Gaza because of the terrorists hiding in their midst does not seem to be in any way a proportionate response to the appalling Hamas attack.

Surely we can find a better way of resolving our differences in the 21st century than the wanton slaughter and destruction of the most vulnerable and most marginalised communities in any theatre of war, while providing a fertile recruitment ground for the very organisation we seek to eliminate?
An eye for an eye really does seem to leave everybody blind.

Sir — Reading the piece last Sunday by Alan Shatter disappointed me. For such a well-educated and intelligent man, he gives only one side of the Middle East conflict. Yes, the Hamas killings were awful and cannot be condoned — but the ‘revenge’ killing of thousands of innocent Palestinians is no answer.
President Higgins did exceed his brief — but he could not contain himself any longer. Just like me, who has never written a letter to a newspaper before.

Let Alan give the other side of the story — of 2.3 million Palestinians trapped in an open prison with no future, a human time-bomb waiting to explode; of land being taken for illegal settlements; and of a whole nation being treated as less-than-human. No wonder Hamas got elected in Gaza. There are so many strands to this dilemma that it must be taken as a whole.
Israel’s ambassador to Ireland, Dana Erlich, would do well to study Irish history and inform her masters at home on how to solve their problem.
By the way — we Irish are not anti-Israel. We are reacting as neutrals to an awful slaughter.
Sir — Thank God for Gene Kerrigan, one of the few sane, rational and compassionate journalists I know writing in Ireland today.

His piece about the Middle East (October 22) was clear and concise. I was not aware of the contribution of the late Brian Lenihan Sr in 1980. He set a good example for the present Government to help broker a cessation of military action and begin a genuine peace process.
The two-state arrangement has failed. Some new and imaginative solution must be brought forward in order to stop the bloodshed and the oppression of the Palestinians.
Sir — What has gone on in the Middle East since 1948 has been so blatantly wrong that, thanks to the West’s support for Israel, might has always been right.
The list of injustices perpetrated against the Palestinians is endless. The West, with its military and economic strength, has always supported the aggressor, to the detriment of the poor.

It is self-evident that there will be no peace without justice. Shame on the West for prolonging this conflict, for making the lives of so many people a misery with no hope in sight, and for the loss of countless innocent lives, especially children.
Sir — Will somebody please shout “Stop”? Only dialogue will bring peace, as it has done in our own country. Not bombs, bullets or tanks. They bring only carnage on a grand scale.

Sir — Congratulations to the secretary general of the UN for calling out the behaviour of Israel in Gaza for what it is. What Hamas has done is a despicable war crime. But how long will it be before the world can accept that Israel’s conduct in attacking Gaza is also a war crime?
Sir — Israeli ambassador Dana Erlich has a point when she criticises Sinn Féin and left-of-centre politicians’ comments on the conflict in the Middle East.
While we should have empathy for Palestinians, Hamas is a terrorist organisation that wants to destroy Israel and is willing to kill innocent people and inflict misery on its own people.

Sir — President Higgins has once again butted in where he has no business. Every time he speaks out it makes me squirm. He speaks of neutrality. There is no such thing. This country should join Nato forthwith.

​Sir — President Higgins and Mary Lou McDonald, when criticising Israeli settlers, should bear in mind the fact that Irish independence was funded by the remittances and donations of Irish settlers abroad.
Will critics of Israel support the return of land and resources to the natives of those countries and welcome back the invading Irish diaspora? Or is Israel ‘special’? It is a simple question.

​Sir — Israel claims its aim is to obliterate Hamas from the face of the earth, but its actions clearly show it is determined to wipe out the Palestinians once and for all. That has been the aim since 1948.
Sir — Is inheritance tax, also called Capital Acquisitions Tax (CAT), and probate bureaucracy adding to the number of vacant homes and causing financial hardship?

Before you can sell a house that belonged to a deceased person, it must go through the probate system. It can take over a year to get probate approval. In all probability, the inheritance tax will have to be paid before you can sell the house. If you don’t pay the CAT on the date required, you will be charged interest on the amount owed.
CAT is paid on amounts above the €335,000 (direct relative) threshold at a rate of 33pc.
Inheritance tax must be paid by October 31 for any inheritance dated in the year to the previous August 31.
This means that if you inherit a property at any time between September 1 and August 31, you must pay the CAT by October 31.

Average house prices in Ireland are around €320,000. In the Dublin region, the average is €437,500. This means that if you are the sole beneficiary of the family home — almost a third of Irish families have one child — you could have a big tax bill to pay up front. If you are not directly related — siblings, nieces and nephews — the tax-free threshold of €32,500 applies; all others have a €16,250 threshold at a rate of 33pc.
That is a big ask for individuals, especially if you are not directly related.
CSO data tells us that 27,000 homes are vacant because the former residents are deceased.

Over 90pc of vacant dwellings included in Census 2022 could be linked back to Census 2016 and almost 85pc back to Census 2011 as well. This is probably why the probate laws are described as “long and convoluted”. Probate error rates are at a remarkable 60pc, and that is by solicitors.

The question is, why can’t the probate system be streamlined? Why can’t the estate pay the tax on the house? Why are people not directly related to the deceased taxed disproportionately? This would help families already struggling during a cost- of-living crisis. It could also put houses back on the market.

Sir — When Britain’s “Irish Question” was about to be sorted, the British changed the question, so it is said. It appears now that a British Northern Ireland Minister, Steve Baker, wants, instead, to change the answer.

Mr Baker requires a 60-40 majority in the North to bring about a united Ireland. The call pays homage to the gerrymandered manner in which the territory was set up and how it was run in places like Derry.

The call for a united Ireland is a call for democracy and to reverse a century of British misrule. A united Ireland will not persecute or discriminate on the basis of national identity. Divide and rule and super-minorities are what Britain does.
Mr Baker’s concoction won’t cook well, and he should clear out of the kitchen.
Sir — It was with great sadness that I read of Brighid McLaughlin’s intention to retire her weekly Diary (
, October 22).

Her articles were the highlight of my week — they had light and shade, always with a huge sense of empathy and fantastic humour. Her Dalkey musings were insightful and pure comedic gold in equal measure.
Empathy and love always radiated from her writing, even when dealing with the most personal or poignant of subjects.
Wishful thinking, perchance, but I hope it is not too long before Biddy returns with her unique eye for the foibles of modern life.
Sir — I think I’m not alone in saying that Sundays just won’t be the same without Biddy’s Diary.
She has a great way with the auld cúpla focal, always able to make me smile with her regaling of happenings. Wishing her all the best for the future.
Sir — Brighid McLaughlin said farewell to us last Sunday. Perhaps, though, she is leaving the door half-open?
Sir — We are being bombarded with ads for Uisce Éireann on our televisions at the moment. Why the necessity to rebrand Irish Water and the expensive advertising campaign?
Is this name change going to help the people who are issued with boil-water notices or who have low water pressure?
Is it going to fix leaks or replace 100-year-old lead pipes? Or is this another “Irish solution to an Irish problem”, to quote a former politician.

Some years ago, your correspondent Shane Ross highlighted the overspending in another state agency, Fás, and asked the question: “Why, in a time of full employment, is this training agency spending €1bn a year?”
The answer to that scandal was a name change — from Fás to Solas.
Maybe this approach could be the solution to RTÉ’s problems? A name change and then continue as before.

title: ‘Sharp rise in racist Israeli hate speech and dehumanisation’ directed at Palestinians, says UN committee
body: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres after visiting the Rafah border between Egypt and the Gaza Strip last week. Photo: Amr Abdallah Dalsh//Reuters

A UN committee on racism voiced concern yesterday about a “sharp increase in racist hate speech and dehumanisation” directed at Palestinians by Israelis, including senior officials, since the October 7 Hamas attacks.
Israel’s diplomatic mission in Geneva criticised the statement which it said “failed all the victims of the October 7 massacre and the victims of anti-semitic attacks worldwide”.

title: Babies sharing incubators as hunger, thirst and spread of disease starts to take toll
body: Palestinian child wounded in Israeli bombardment is treated in a hospital in Deir al Balah, south of the Gaza Strip, Friday, Oct.27, 2023. ( AP Photo/Hatem Moussa)
Newborn babies are being placed in single incubators up to three at a time in one of Gaza’s largest hospitals, the facility’s director has warned.

Dr Bashar Murad, head of al-Quds hospital in Gaza City, also said that diarrheal diseases and respiratory infections were spreading among patients and those taking shelter at the hospital because of a lack of clean water.

title: Senan Molony: As Middle East conflict deepens, it could unleash horrors across the world
body: People mourn the children killed in Gaza during vigil in central London

The wisps of war are everywhere as the world faces into the most perilous period since the beginning of the 21st century. The Israel-Gaza conflict is about to deepen into a trough of horrors that will destabilise the entire region and make more likely a spate of rage killings on the streets of Europe.

EU leaders met this week in Brussels, where two Swedish football fans were randomly murdered earlier this month and a third left critically injured. None of those fans will have imagined that festering resentment over the burning of the Koran in Stockholm could have led to their deaths.

A relative holds a son of Hezbollah member Hussein Hariri, who was killed in southern Lebanon amid tension with Israel, on his coffin during his funeral. Photo: Reuters
The recent attacks by the US on Iranian-backed militia targets have set tongues wagging in certain quarters as to whether this may escalate tension throughout an already fraught Middle East.
But closer to home, the question is whether these attacks could have implications for the safety of Irish troops serving with UN forces in Lebanon.

title: How to tell fact from fiction in a war of disinformation
body: From beheading to bombings, the recent events in the Middle East have triggered a deluge of false claims, spread on social media. John Meagher on how truth became the first casualty
How to tell fact from fiction in a war of disinformation

Major world events, such as pandemics and wars, can trigger a deluge of falsehoods online, but the speed with which disinformation has taken hold in the Israel-Palestine war has taken even seasoned observers by surprise.

From war-themed video games pushing false narratives, to old footage reposted as today’s news and from fake accounts impersonating journalists to allegations about the use of so-called ‘crisis actors’, separating fact from fiction has become increasingly difficult as the conflict intensifies in the Middle East.

title: We can express solidarity with Palestinians and Israelis while condemning Hamas and bombing
body: A child wounded during Israeli strikes on Gaza undergoes treatment in an intensive care unit. Photo: Reuters
It is possible and important to be able to distinguish between the head of state or government of a country on the one hand and the citizens of that country on the other.
Benjamin Netanyahu has undermined the independence of the Israeli judiciary.
He has allied himself with his country’s most right-wing forces and faces criminal charges that could land him in jail.

If it is “anti-Israel” or even antisemitic to criticise Netanyahu and his administration, there is evidence to suggest that most Israeli citizens are anti-Israel or antisemitic: results of a recent poll found four out of five Jewish Israelis believe the government and Netanyahu are to blame for the Hamas invasion and the killings that followed.
Eighty-six per cent of respondents, including 79pc of coalition supporters, said the surprise attack from Gaza is a failure of the country’s leadership.

A total of 94pc believe the government must bear some responsibility for the lack of security preparedness before the assault, with more than 75pc saying the government holds most of the responsibility. There have been mass protests against the government. This is a nonsense.
One can distinguish between the Israeli government and the people of Israel.

One can express solidarity with the people of Israel without expressing solidarity with Netanyahu and the Israeli regime as it engages in collective punishment and breaches international humanitarian law.
Likewise, one can distinguish between Hamas terrorists and the people of Gaza.
One can express solidarity with the people of Gaza without expressing solidarity with Hamas, which has committed unspeakable atrocities against innocent civilians.
Neither Hamas nor the Israeli government will be on the right side of history.
How sad it was to hear the Dublin- born Israeli citizen talk about his deceased young daughter.

His harrowing comments reflected the two articles I read in last Saturday’s Review section, one by an Israeli correspondent in Jerusalem and the other by a young Ukrainian writer who is a regular columnist to your paper (‘Amid the death and confusion in Israel, we can take some hope from Ireland’; ‘Middle East conflict provokes difficult reactions for us’, October 21).
The Israeli writer was hoping that the inspiration of the

TV series would some day inspire Palestinians and Israelis to live in peace with each other, akin to Northern Ireland, where 25 years of relative peace have allowed a generation to experience something like normal life.

The Ukrainian writer was worried the conflict would divert attention from the illegal war being waged on her country by a despot in Russia. She is right to be concerned, but she also showed empathy for the innocent civilians (on both sides) caught up in the subsequent slaughter as one country tries to dominate or wipe out another.

The deep divisions within Israel were highlighted by the piece where an Israeli father was demonstrating outside a government meeting, calling for the release of his captive soldier daughter – only to be told by another Israeli that he was a leftist and he hoped that Hamas would kill his daughter and the father as well.

Such hatred between fellow Israelis of different political persuasions does not bode well for peace in the region, especially as most Israelis seem to believe that all the militant Arab countries and Palestinian militants want to exterminate them.

The Northern Ireland peace is still very fragile, and sectarian divisions are still deep as a lot of nationalists or unionists do not venture into pubs, restaurants or sports facilities in the other side’s districts. But at least peace reigns to some degree.

While this hard-line leadership exists within Gaza and equally hard-line Israelis occupy land and display extreme prejudices against their own and the Palestinian people, I fear this conflict will not be ready for a Northern Ireland-type solution for generations to come.
No one can deny that the current Government has been a very stable one, apart from a few minor hiccups.
There is absolutely no difference between Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael in economic policy , foreign policy or any other area.
The manner in which the Taoiseach and Tánaiste switched positions was seamless, as was the changeover of Finance and Public Expenditure Ministers.
These parties have now been in bed together for over seven years when one includes the four years of confidence and supply.
It’s way past time they went to see the preacher and tied the knot once and for all and merged.
There is no way they can face the electorate in a year or so and claim they are distinct parties. If they do they will be routed.
The Civil War ended over 100 years ago, and the appearance of Micheál Martin and Leo Varadkar together at Béal na Bláth drew a line under that era.

Kieran Burke lists facts that would be the envy of most European governments: unemployment in Ireland at its lowest point in 20 years, and Ireland is one of the wealthiest countries in the world and is the second-wealthiest country in Europe, plus it has the second-highest budget surplus (‘Why would anyone want a change of government when country is thriving?’ Letters, October 26).

One might be forgiven for rushing to the conclusion that there is some correlation between the latter and the fact that the Republic of Ireland is discharging half-a-billion litres of raw sewage every day into its waterways and coastal waters (‘Public health and nature at risk as wastewater and raw sewage enters waterways’,
, October 26)?
It will be some time before I can work up enough courage to put on my togs for a swim in Donegal, whose coastal waters I have always recommended to French would-be tourists – up until now.
Despite the recent unconvincing assurance from Eirgrid, Ireland is heading into another winter with our national energy security on an increasingly precarious knife edge.
Our EU partners have this year ensured over 90pc storage of gas supplies, while Ireland has none.
The Coalition’s energy policy, dominated by the Green Party dogma, has resulted in a potential shortfall of around 600 megawatts of electricity- generating capacity.

Given the volatility of wind, for now and the foreseeable future, it is naive and foolish to depend on such an unreliable source without sufficient constant back-up supplies of oil and natural gas. Uniquely, Ireland doesn’t even discuss nuclear.

The recent agreement signed by Transport Minister Eamon Ryan in London, where the UK will supply 90pc of our natural gas needs into the future, further crystallises the foolishness and irresponsibility of the Coalition’s energy policy.

As a result, present and future energy policy means Ireland’s total economic and societal well-being depends on unreliable Tory-led Brexit-embroiled Britain (which receives 30pc of its supply from Norway), rather than our own native source on our doorstep, with significantly lower costs and carbon footprint.
As people tune in to watch the Boks face the All Blacks for custody of the Webb Ellis Cup tonight, many Irish hearts are still in their boots over what might have been.
I would go with Johnny Sexton’s take on it: we lost but we won in terms of what we can take away from our time in France.
We can’t say that we didn’t stumble at the quarter-final hurdle, because we did. That said, we did more than enough to be proud of. Our 2027 team will be standing on the shoulders of giants.

The past is not where battles are won. Andy Farrell is on hand to make sure the lads who survived Paris will distil that sense of loss and refine it for a celebrator y elixir in Sydney next time round.
“In your heads” and in your hearts.

title: Heaviest bombing of Gaza yet as Israel ‘expands ground operation’
body: Explosions caused by Israeli airstrikes in the northern Gaza Strip, Friday, Oct. 27, 2023. (AP Photo/Abed Khaled)
Israel’s military announced last night it was “expanding” ground operations in Gaza, amid reports of the heaviest bombardment yet of the besieged strip and a total communications black-out.

Orange explosions seared through the night sky above northern Gaza as the Israeli air force appeared to unleash its most devastating attack yet on the enclave, which is home to over two million people.

title: Editorial: Every effort must be made to secure a ceasefire in the  Middle East
body: Palestinians arrive to collect drinking water in Rafah as Israel continues its bombardment of Gaza. Photo: AP

The United Nations General Assembly has adopted a resolution on the Gaza crisis, calling for an “immediate, durable and sustained humanitarian truce leading to a cessation of hostilities”. That resolution at least had the merit of breaking the deadlock at the UN over a response to the Israel-Gaza crisis that erupted on October 7 after Hamas launched a savage attack on Israel and its citizens. Until last week, member states of the UN Security Council had failed to reach agreement on four draft resolutions, an indication of the fraught geopolitical considerations.

Ireland supported the UN resolution, but this country was disappointed that a Canadian amendment, clearly condemning the brutal terrorist attack by Hamas and calling for the immediate and unconditional release of hostages, was not approved. While the resolution makes clear that Israel has an imperative duty in international law to ensure civilians are not deprived of objects indispensable to survival, it remains non-binding.

However, it does provide a snapshot of world opinion after three weeks of Israeli reprisals, which is clearly one of growing concern at the effect on Palestinian civilians in Gaza. The Security Council, which can also pass binding resolutions, has been unable to do so on the crisis without either Russia or the US wielding a veto.

While Ireland’s role in such a perilous situation can only ever be limited, it is not lost on anybody here that our troops serving in UN peacekeeping missions on Israel’s border with Lebanon could find themselves on the front line should hostilities spread.

Yesterday, Egyptian president Abdel Fattah al-Sisi warned against any expansion of the conflict, “regardless of where it comes from”. He said a move in this direction meant the region would become “a ticking timebomb that impacts us all”.

Following the UN resolution, Foreign Affairs Minister Micheál Martin rightly said the dire humanitarian situation in Gaza required the international community to speak strongly. The resolution, he said, emphasised the vital importance of the humanitarian assistance civilians in Gaza so desperately need.

Images — especially of children — emerging from Gaza, where thousands of lives have been lost in Israeli reprisal attacks, have shocked the world. It is probable that the sentiment behind the UN resolution has widespread support in Ireland (the extent of that support will be one of the aspects of the crisis explored in a
/Ireland Thinks poll next week).

Unfortunately, it does not look as though there will be a resolution to the crisis soon, particularly given the increasingly strident language of the Israeli authorities and prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

The Israel Defence Forces yesterday released an “urgent message for the residents of Gaza”, in which it called on civilians from northern Gaza to temporarily relocate south as a precursor to further attacks. While such a call, if heeded, will at least have the benefit of reducing civilian losses, the inevitable consequences will be more loss of life, while also adding to the build-up of desperate Palestinian civilians on the border with Egypt.

The sickening nature of the Hamas attack and the subsequent war have exposed hardline policies followed by the right-wing government in Israel. Regrettably, it is clear that Netanyahu now intends to escalate Israel’s response, perhaps significantly, and at the cost of an incalculable number of Palestinian lives. Part of the motivation for this would appear to be a determination to postpone serious consequences for what remains of his political career.
Ireland, meanwhile, should continue to work for an urgent humanitarian ceasefire, the protection of civilians and regional de-escalation.

title: Israel’s foreign affairs minister says Ireland one of the more ‘challenging’ places in Europe
body: Israel's ambassador Dana Erlich
Israel’s foreign affairs minister has described Ireland as one of the more “challenging” places in Europe.
People Before Profit TDs have called for the Israeli ambassador to Ireland, Dana Erlich, to be expelled.
However, Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has ruled out such a move, saying there would be “no advantage” in expelling Ms Erlich as lines of communication should remain open.
Israel’s foreign affairs Minister Eli Cohen said he spoke to Ms Erlich and said she is representing Israel “in one of the more challenging arenas for Israel”.

“Today I spoke with Israel's ambassador to Ireland, Dana Ehrlich, and thanked her for her firm stand in representing the State of Israel in one of the more challenging arenas for Israel in Europe,” he wrote on X, formerly Twitter.
“Alongside our heroic fighters at the front in the south and north, we have men and women working day and night to strengthen international support for the State of Israel.”
The minister also included a screenshot of a photograph from an article from Israeli news outlet Ynet, showing Ms Erlich covered in blood, with a blood-stained Israeli flag behind her.
The article described Ireland as one of the “most hostile countries to Israel in Europe”.
It also said President Michael D Higgins is a “prominent critic of Israel globally”.
It comes after the Government said it has no plans to pull Irish troops out of Camp Shamrock in the Lebanon.
This is despite a shell hitting their Naqoura HQ in southern Lebanon in recent days.
There are almost 500 peacekeepers serving across three United Nations in the region and just under 340 with the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon.
The peacekeepers currently in the Lebanon are due to return home and a new tranche of soldiers will travel in early November as part of a rotation deal.

title: Rally for Gaza to be held in Donegal on Saturday
body: Donegal rally for Gaza is being held tomorrow, Saturday October 28.
A public rally to show support the Palestinian people of Gaza is being held in County Donegal on Saturday.
The rally is calling for the end of the ongoing unrest in Gaza which has seen the death toll raise to over 6,000 people since October 7.
The rally is also calling for an end to ethnic cleansing and for the expulsion of the Israeli Ambassador.
Organised by the Ireland Palestine Solidarity Campaign, the group is calling for as many people as possible to “come out and stand with the Palestinian people.”
The event, which will feature guest speakers, gets underway on Saturday afternoon at 1pm outside An Grianán Theatre, Letterkenny on the Port Road.

title: UN calls for truce between Israel and Hamas as bombings intensify in Gaza with internet and mobile services down
body: UN General Assembly approves resolution calling for a “humanitarian truce” in Gaza

The United Nations General Assembly on Friday overwhelmingly called for an immediate humanitarian truce between Israel and Palestinian militants Hamas and demanded aid access to the besieged Gaza Strip and protection of civilians.

The resolution drafted by Arab states is not binding but carries political weight, taking the global temperature as Israel steps up ground operations in Gaza in retaliation for the worst Hamas attack on civilians in Israel's 75-year-old history on October. 7.

title: Leo Varadkar says EU position on Israel-Palestine conflict is evolving
body: Leo Varadkar says EU position on Israel-Palestine conflict is evolving

Talks in Brussels dragged on Thursday night as efforts continued to form 27 EU states into a credible and coherent mosaic on the Middle East conflict. Taoiseach Leo Varadkar was among those searching for a common position that would be “balanced” – recognising the right of Israel to self-defence (or even retaliation) in the wake of barbarism while mindful of the need to keep loss of life in Gaza to a minimum. Mr Varadkar, who has been even-handed in all his comments so far, may have been unimpressed by wording drawn up by functionaries that talked of the establishment of humanitarian corridors and their safe operation during “pauses”.

title: ‘Essential not to lose focus’ on war in Ukraine, Leo Varadkar warns
body: ‘Essential not to lose focus’ on war in Ukraine, Leo Varadkar warns

Irish premier Leo Varadkar has said it was “essential” to not “lose focus” on the war in Ukraine as global attention focuses on the Israel-Palestine conflict. The Taoiseach was speaking ahead of a two-day meeting of the EU’s 27 leaders in Brussels on Friday. Mr Varadkar said on the first day of the summit that some countries wanted attention to be drawn away from the Russian invasion of Ukraine and towards the threat of an escalating conflict in the Middle East.

title: Adam Taylor: Why hasn’t Israel’s threatened ground offensive started?
body: Released hostage Yocheved Lifshitz (85) told of her captivity in the underground tunnels of Gaza. Photo: Reuters

In the aftermath of Hamas’s October 7 attack on Israel, some expected Israel to almost immediately launch a ground offensive against Gaza. Speaking to the nation shortly after that attack, which left more than 1,400 Israelis dead, according to official figures, prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu told the nation he had ordered “an extensive mobilisation of the reserves to fight back on a scale and intensity that the enemy has so far not experienced”.
Yet despite a speedy mobilisation in which hundreds of thousands of Israel reservists joined their units and remarks that the mighty Israel Defence Forces are “ready”, no ground offensive has begun.

title: Letters: Benjamin Netanyahu needs to walk the plank for failures on all counts in Isreal’s war on Gaza
body: Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Photo: Reuters

Should Benjamin Netanyahu not be walking the plank for the failure of his country’s security system on his watch? As a result of that failure, innocent Israeli civilians were murdered or kidnapped in an attack to be eternally condemned.

Did he sidestep the plank by divert- ing attention in knowing that attack is the best form of (his) defence? Hence the massive carpet-bombing of Gaza and the slaughter of thousands of its innocent civilians.
The Gaza bombardment has gone too far, and the reaction to the dreadfully inhumane situation on both sides must rebound on Mr Netanyahu’s cabinet.
This Gaza action will also not only be long remembered, but will strengthen and multiply Israel’s enemies. As a result, Israel’s right to defend itself will be put under enormous pressure.
It is difficult to understand how the conflict is allowed to continue with superpowers standing by.​
I don’t have all the answers, but I feel that those of us living in a peaceful country should try to find a solution to the Middle East tragedy.
Could the international community seek a little bit more land for the Palestinians? They are living on a tiny piece of land that is grossly overcrowded.
People feel so pressurised there. Israel is entitled to exist peacefully alongside Gaza. There is no point in killing so many civilians and wrecking their homes and livelihoods.
Please, those of you with influence, try to organise a peaceful solution. Give Gaza its own water and electricity supply so they are not dependent on Israel.
I am not taking sides, but these horrendous deeds that will only end in more bloodshed horrify me.

The Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, 1961, specifies that ambassadors are diplomats of the highest rank, formally representing their head of state, with plenipotentiary powers to represent their government.
The role of ambassadors in times of peace tends to be symbolic as they deal with matters of economics, culture, visas and more.
In times of war, the role of ambassadors is far more important. When the conflict in Ukraine began in February 2022, there were calls for the Russian ambassador to be expelled.
In recent days, similar calls have been made by politicians and others to expel the Israeli ambassador.

Expelling ambassadors in a time of war is a serious mistake. While we may not like the ambassadors in question and we may not like or agree with the actions of their governments, it is vital to keep diplomatic lines of communication open at such critically important times.

Neutral countries, particularly, should be playing an important role in promoting a ceasefire and negotiations in those conflicts in Ukraine, the Middle East, the Sahel region of Africa and elsewhere.

The ambassadors of these countries are vital, especially if efforts are being made to end the conflicts, but also to help protect Ireland’s interests and the interests of Irish citizens who may be endangered by the conflicts.
Ambassadors are the most important element in the international diplomatic system and provide a vital communications system in times of crises.
“Meeting jaw to jaw is better than war,” as Churchill said.
In Seán O’Casey’s play
, Captain Boyle states: “The whole world’s in a terrible state o’chassis.”
In reality, was it not ever thus? But the words of US president Franklin D Roosevelt at his inauguration ceremony – “The only fear is fear itself” – are as valid today as they were in 1933.
Today, the world is dominated by greed for power by a handful of men (women are far too wise).
Alas, for them, they overlook spirituality. We, the plain people, can but be bystanders or we can be spirituality active?

In Matthew 15: 10-11 we read: “Jesus called the crowd to him [the plain people of today] and said, ‘Listen and understand’. What goes into a man’s mouth does not make him unclean, but what comes out of his mouth, this is what makes him unclean.”

Today, we are obliged to be truthful or silent regarding the crisis in the Middle East. The vitally important part is silence, which, in my opinion, if used with intent can assist in creating peace in our world.
There is a house – one of many – in Ireland where in the 19th century on a Sunday the family sat in silence the entire afternoon, pondering on the Gospel they had heard at church that morning.
Some years ago, I got permission to visit that room, and the absolute beautiful peace had me wishing I could remain for ever.
We who believe in the Trinity have the ability to sit in silence anywhere, indoors or outdoors, alone or in company, and invoke in our minds. I invoke the peace and love of the Holy Trinity on earth.
We have much to gain by this invocation.
I would like to compliment Kieran Burke on his letter (‘Why would anyone want a change of government when country is thriving?’, Letters, October 26).

He is 100pc right when he says recent opinion polls indicate there is a desire for change to a more nationalist form of administration. He makes the point about what nationalism has brought our neighbours in the form of Brexit.

I always say politics is not a science. I think the Irish electorate are very volatile, with a tendency to give a bloody nose to whoever is in government. They nearly always believe somebody out there can do a better job.
But Mr Burke is right when he talks about positives such as a high budget surplus, low levels of unemployment and high life expectancy. Yet people will always find something to complain about.
I have a terrible fear voters will follow in the footsteps of our nearest neighbours and make the biggest electoral mistake of the 21st century.

title: Editorial: Israel must exercise restraint or countless lives will be lost
body: A view showing part of the destruction caused by the ongoing Israeli airstrikes on Gaza City yesterday. Photo: Abed Khaled/AP

The delusion that the price of aggression could ever be cheap has to be one of the most damning of our times. The terrible miscalculation is so cruel because the burden of suffering is borne by the innocent who had no part in the lethal bargain to begin with.

Hamas has unleashed a black whirlwind of death and every day the toll grows. What it wants is to see an escalation in the killing and destruction and it seems like its perverse wish is going to come true.

Israel has a right to defend itself but given that thousands of civilians including children have already died and the lives of many more are in danger, some pause in the violence is vital if there is to be any prospect of avoiding untold carnage. Taoiseach Leo Varadkar is in Brussels where he made a strong case for a humanitarian ceasefire in Gaza.

Speaking at a two-day summit of European Union leaders, he said Hamas has set a “trap” to ignite a regional conflict. Such a conflagration would upend years of diplomacy and burn the bridges that have been built to draw Israel and Saudi Arabia closer.
This outcome would suit Russia, he hinted, because it would take the focus off Ukraine.

Such international dimensions must be weighed up, but right now the most immediate concerns are humanitarian. Indiscriminate bombing is taking an appalling toll. Depriving millions of people of water, food and medical supplies can not go on.
Ireland respects Israel’s right to defend itself and, as Mr Varadkar said, it condemns terrorists for attacking civilians.
Yet, as he also stressed, Israel’s defence must not jeopardise the security of the whole region.
It is distressing that, for a fourth time, the UN has failed to pass a resolution calling for a ceasefire. And it is imperative that Hamas release all hostages.
An all-out ground invasion is drawing closer, but many of Israel’s allied military advisers are reported to be counselling against this because the fallout may be impossible to contain.
No one knows how many lives could be lost in open-ended house-to-house fighting. Israel’s prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu has pledged to “crush Hamas”.
But in times of conflict patience rewards better than anger.

If there is to be such an invasion, giving the requisite time to allow civilians to get out of firing zones is a moral imperative. Intelligence-led targeting of known combatants may take longer, but will be infinitely more effective. The possible human, military and global consequences of rushing in are incalculable.
Allowing Hamas to dictate the pace of events knowing it will maximise the calamity for civilians, could easily backfire.
The Chinese military strategist Sun Tzu said “Victory is reserved for those who are willing to pay its price.”

But the civilians and hostages who have found themselves blamelessly drawn into the bloodletting can never be considered as part of any “settling of accounts”. It would be unconscionable for them to be part of footing a bill.
